PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on Thursday, 10 August 1995, of Raymond Harold Whittorn CBE, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Balaclava from 1960 to 1974.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the injust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brownhill (from 54 citizens), Senator Calvert (from 33 citizens), Senator MacGibbon (from 26 citizens) and Senator Troeth (from 10,516 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne (from 148 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 32 citizens) and Senator Jones (from 2,075 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Calvert (from 487 citizens) and Senator O'Chee (from 613 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian National Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Building Materials
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit our opposition to the announced imposition of Sales Tax of 12% on basic hardware and building products by the Federal Government from July 1 1995. The petitioners note particularly that:

1. This new tax will directly affect ordinary Australians in the form of rising prices of building, maintaining and improving their home and by consequential job losses and company closures in an industry which has faced many economic pressures over recent years.
2. The new tax offers no net benefit to Australia and should be abandoned.
Your petitioners request that the Senate should not pass this legislation when it is presented and/or work to prevent this taxation measure from being implemented by the current Federal Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in the world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Federal System of Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We, the undersigned citizens respectfully:
(a) express concern at the efforts of the Federal Government to undermine the role and responsibilities of the States, and the Prime Minister's unwillingness to meet with State Premiers;
(b) oppose any attempt to create regional governments in opposition to existing state and local governments; and
(c) reject the ultimate objective of the Labor Party which is to do away with the States and the Senate and to have ultimate and unquestioned power residing entirely in Canberra.
And your petitioners will in duty bound ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

`Observe the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and grant all children social justice and equity in relation to a pre school developmental program which will provide the foundation for a quality education and future employability, by removing the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care based on parents marital and employment status'
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
`remove the 12 hour (or day) child care assistance restriction for long day care children based on parents marital and employment status'

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

Despite its knowledge of the brutality of the Indonesian occupation of East Timor (the twenty year occupation is estimated to have cost the lives of over 200,000 East Timorese—a third of the population), the Australian government continues to aid the Indonesian military. Since the 1991 Dili massacre, as the repression in East Timor has increased, so has the cooperation between the Australian military and the Indonesian Defense Force (ABRI).

Since 1992, there have been at least eight joint military exercises with Indonesia. ABRI has been invited to participate in Kangaroo 95, the largest ever war games on Australian soil. There has also been a marked increase in the number of ABRI personnel trained by Australia (a 500% increase in the number of personnel trained between 1991 and 1994). Among those trained in Australia, have been the KOPASSUS forces, who have been noted for brutality during the occupation. Since July 1994, bilateral military cooperation between Australia and Indonesia has increased by $A2.5 million to $4.6 million.
The Australian government's complicity in aiding genocide in East Timor must stop!
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
Withdraw the invitation to ABRI to take part in Kangaroo 95;
Stop training the KOPASSUS regiment;
Withdraw the $4.6 million allocated to bilateral military cooperation.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled. Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

PARA.TAB: Demand an immediate end to all nuclear testing and the banning of all nuclear weapons;
Stop all mining and export of uranium from Australia;
Remove Australia from the nuclear cycle—close all U.S. bases;
Support and demand a free and independent East Timor and end all military ties with the Suharto dictatorship in Indonesia.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I point out to the Senate that the petition tabled in my name represents the views of over 11,000 people who strongly object to the decision by the government to restrict child-care assistance. This is a breach of its promise at the last election that child care is a right, not a privilege. There appears to have been little or no consultation with the peak child-care bodies in each state, which has been widely criticised by the industry. As the burden of this decision will fall on lower income families, the gap between rich and poor will widen even further in Australia.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That—

TAB.TAB: (1)(a)In view of deepening public concern that no adequate explanation, supported by authoritative documents, has been given by the Government for its decision to pay, from public funds, the legal costs of Dr Carmen Lawrence's attempts in the courts to stop the Marks' Royal Commission;
(b)in view of the Government's refusal to respond to orders of the Senate that it explain and account for this expenditure of public money;

(c)given that current best estimates suggest these expenses are running at $10 000 a day, and may now exceed $100 000 excluding the additional legal costs to be paid to the other parties in each of the failed legal challenges to date; and
(d)given that there is a pressing and responsible need to determine how and why this decision was made, whether it is legal and what it is costing;

PARA.TAB: the Senate resolves as follows:

TAB.TAB: (2)A select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on Payment of a Minister's Legal Costs, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before 19 September 1995, on the following matters:
(a)what is the legal basis for the decision to pay Dr Lawrence's legal costs in challenging the legality of aspects of the Marks' Royal Commission;
(b)what was the sequence of events leading to the Government's decision to pay such legal costs, in particular:
(i)who initiated the process leading to that decision and when and how was this done,
(ii)what official advice was sought and given about the proposal or any possible proposal to pay such costs, and
(iii)what advice or communications on the proposal or any possible proposal did the Government receive from what sources outside government, including private lawyers or legal firms;

(c)what advice, from within or outside government, was given, and what government decisions were taken, in relation to the legal standing Dr Lawrence or any other person might have in any proceedings challenging the legality of the Marks' Royal Commission and what bearing did this have on the decision to pay the legal costs from public funds;
(d)what advice was given to government, and what consideration was given by government, to the following:
(i)estimating the likely total financial liability of the Commonwealth arising from the Government's decision to pay legal costs,
(ii)whether any cap or limit should be placed on such expenditure, and
(iii)procedures to monitor the nature and growth of the Commonwealth's financial liability in the matter and the efficiency and effectiveness of the expenditure;

(e)bearing in mind that government was funding the legal challenges from public funds, what role did government play in relation to any of the legal challenges to the Marks' Royal Commission, including in relation to the decisions to challenge, or to appeal against lost challenges, and in relation to the nature of the arguments to be put to the respective courts on behalf of Dr Lawrence or any other person; and
(f)any other matter arising in the course of the inquiry which is relevant to the foregoing terms of reference, inquiry into which would facilitate reporting on those terms of reference.
(3)The committee consist of seven senators:
(a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine.
(4)The committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)(a)The chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the members of the committee.
(b)In the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate.
(c)The deputy chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(d)The deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(e)In the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.
(6)The quorum of the committee be four members.

(7)The committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)The committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.
(9)(a)The terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media.
(b)Written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard.

(10)The committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(11)The committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(12)The committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes, with concern, that:

TAB.TAB: (i)landmines are a massive global problem, with between 80 and 110 million mines laid in some 65 countries and more than 2 million or so added every year,

(ii)the United States State Department estimates that 26 000 people per year are killed or maimed worldwide by landmines with mine clearance efforts only managing to remove some 100000 land mines each year,

(iii)the military usefulness of anti-personnel mines (APMs) is outweighed by the indiscriminate and long-term social and economic costs to affected people and countries by mines which are often used to terrorise and target the civilian population rather than to meet defined military objectives,
(iv)the principal victims of landmines are civilians and, as a consequence of vast areas of countries being rendered uninhabitable, economic development is impossible and refugees cannot return home,

(v)the 1980 United Nations (UN) Convention on prohibitions or restrictions on the use of Certain Conventional Weapons (CCW) which may be deemed to be excessively injurious or to have indiscriminate effects and its Protocol II on prohibitions or restrictions on the use of mines, booby-traps, and other devices (the Landmines Protocol) has very largely failed to deal with the problems of landmines, firstly because of lack of adherence and observance and secondly because it applies only to international conflicts, and not non-international conflicts;

PARA.TAB: (b)welcomes the news that Belgium has recently passed a law completely banning the production, transfer, sale, export or use of APMs;
(c)declares its support for a total ban on anti-personnel landmines to cover production, stockpiling, transfer, and use; and
(d)calls on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to take action to ensure that the revision of the UN CCW convention should aim for a total ban on the production, stockpiling, transfer and use of anti-personnel landmines and include:
(a)an extension to apply in all circumstances,
(b)provisions for effective verification and compliance to be introduced, and
(c)provision for regular automatic review conferences covering the operation and provisions to be introduced, and

(ii)to implement a ban on production of APMs on its territory or by companies registered within its territory, as well as the stockpiling, transfer, sale and use of APMs, whatever the outcome of the UN Review Conference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

The purpose of this Bill is to put arrangements in place for the provision of general revenue assistance to the States and Territories for the 1995-96 financial year, consistent with the decisions taken at the Premiers' Conference of 11 April 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: The April 1995 Premiers' Conference was held in conjunction with the Council of Australian Governments meeting which agreed to a program for the implementation of the National Competition Policy and related reforms and to an associated set of financial arrangements. The central elements of the National Competition Policy were incorporated in the Competition Policy Reform Act 1995 which received Royal Assent on 20 July 1995.

The Bill will amend the States Grants (General Purposes) Act 1994. The existing Act currently covers the provision of general revenue assistance for 1994-95 only, with interim arrangements for continuing payments to a maximum of six months. The Bill extends the provision of the existing Act for a further twelve months.

The general revenue assistance for the States and the Territories to be appropriated by the Bill is estimated to be almost $15.7 billion, or around 12.7 per cent of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1995-96. Accordingly, these payments constitute a significant element of the Commonwealth Budget and, in combination with the Loan Council Allocations for borrowings by all levels of government agreed at the April 1995 Loan Council Meeting, have an important bearing on the spending and borrowing of the public sector as a whole.

The 1995 Premiers' Conference reaffirmed the continuation of the real per capita guarantee for the indexation of financial assistance grants to the States and Territories in 1995-96. The real per capita guarantee was made to the States at the 1994 Premiers' Conference for the three year period to 1996-97.

At the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments held in conjunction with the 1995 Premiers' Conference the Commonwealth agreed to extend the guarantee to 1997-98 and thereafter on a rolling three year basis. The provision of the rolling three year real per capita guarantee reflected the Commonwealth's desire to foster cooperative Commonwealth-State relations which would, in turn, offer a sound basis for working together to progress microeconomic reform. The Commonwealth recognised that this would best be achieved through provision of a degree of certainty for the States about the level of funding they could expect from the Commonwealth over the medium term.

The major part of the assistance provided under this Bill is the provision to each State and Territory of a share of the pool of financial assistance grants which is estimated to be around $14.9 billion in 1995-96. The 1995 Premiers' Conference agreed that the distribution of this assistance should be in accordance with the per capita relativities recommended by the Commonwealth Grants Commission in its Report on General Revenue Grant Relativities, 1995 Update, and estimates of State and Territory populations as at 31 December 1995 as determined by the Australian Statistician.

The Bill authorises the payment of special revenue assistance to the States in 1995-96 estimated at $437 million. Of this amount, $412 million relates to payments to New South Wales and Victoria under the guarantee arrangements associated with the Medicare Agreements. The Commonwealth will fund $58.9 million of these payments and the residual will be funded from the financial assistance grants pool. The remaining special revenue assistance relates to pool-funded special revenue assistance for the Territories. The Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory will receive $15 million and $10 million respectively in order to ease their transition to State-like funding levels.

The Australian Capital Territory will also receive $49.1 million in the form of Commonwealth funded transitional allowances and special fiscal needs. This payment is outside the scope of this Bill and has been included in the Appropriation Bills.

In 1995-96, the Government will provide an estimated $369 million in identified arterial road grants to the States and Territories. In accordance with the agreement reached at the 1995 Premiers' Conference, in each of 1995-96, 1996-97 and 1997-98, one third of identified road grants will be cumulatively distributed on the basis of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's relativities which underlie the distribution of financial assistance grants. Thus in 1997-98, identified road grants will be fully distributed on the basis of the relativities underlying financial assistance grants. Until then, that part of identified road grants not distributed on the basis of the Commonwealth Grants Commission's relativities will continue to be distributed on the basis of the 1994-95 shares.
Mr President, this Bill is an integral part of the Commonwealth's financial relations with the State and Territory Governments and of the Budget.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Economics References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 30 January 1996—
(1)The extent to which `outworking' or other subcontracting methods are used in the Australian garment industry.

(2)The extent to which garment industry practices or contract provisions related to delivery times, quality standards, piecework rates and related matters, impose working conditions on outworkers and their families which do not meet standards of fairness and equity which the community expects to prevail in the labour market, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the adequacy of piecework rates of pay and, in particular, whether these rates adequately cover:
(i)minimum award rates of pay, and
(ii)holiday and other conditions and entitlements;
(b)the delivery times required for particular orders;
(c)the effect on the work-safety and the well-being generally of outworkers and their families;
(d)the proportion of labour costs contained in the firms' finished articles at wholesale and retail level, compared with on-site manufacturing costs;
(e)the extent to which the current system promotes the employment of children under 15, the conditions under which they are employed, and the effect on their school attendance and general well-being;
(f)the extent to which the current system brings about abuses of social security and taxation laws; and
(g)any other matter which in the opinion of the committee is relevant to the issues listed above.

PARA.TAB: (3)Steps which could be taken to address any deficiencies identified in paragraph (2), in particular, the conditions which prevent outworkers accessing standards of fairness and equity in the labour market and the action which needs to be taken to address contracting policies and procedures between principal companies, retailers and subcontractors.
(4)Implications for government adoption of relevant International Labour Organisation conventions and recommendations on outworking, once these are finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: We are rightly disgusted with child exploitation and slave labour conditions in other countries. We need to do something about these conditions in Australia. I pay tribute to the government's establishment of the tripartite working party under the chairmanship of former Attorney-General Mr Michael Duffy. That to some extent will look at what happens to children in our own backyard.

PARA.TAB: We must ensure that the exploitation of home workers, mainly women, migrants and, one suspects, also children, in conditions which we fought for decades to eliminate from Australia, does not continue. It has been claimed that contract conditions between manufacturers, which include some of the most expensive brands, and outworkers are fair and reasonable. On the other hand, there are persistent reports of damage to health, injuries, long hours in poor conditions and pitifully low pay. All of this was documented in some detail in the report by the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Union called The hidden cost of fashion. It is indeed time that we as a society got to the bottom of what is actually happening. It is essential that the industry is compelled to follow reasonable standards regarding minimum rates of pay for piece work, to ensure that award rates are not undercut, and that the safety and wellbeing of outworkers and their families are protected.

In this context it is also relevant to examine the capacity of the industry to pay fair rates and to ensure that children are not employed under conditions which affect their school attendance, health and general wellbeing. Another matter which needs to be examined is the extent to which these practices are used to avoid tax and to circumvent social security provisions. It is also important to examine the extent to which our consideration of these conditions impacts on ILO conventions and our observance of those conventions in Australia. In my discussions with the other parties, I was advised by the coalition that they had some concerns about those two last points and, in a simplified set of terms of reference, those two items were omitted. However, I believe that they are essential to remain in the terms of reference, and I have therefore moved my motion accordingly.

However, in the motion I added, yesterday, by amendment, a general clause which satisfies one of the concerns of the coalition, namely, that it might not be broad enough and, because it is fairly detailed, some matters might escape the consideration of the committee. So I have included a clause which says that any other matters which are relevant to the above terms of reference can be considered. I have also taken account, following discussions with Senator Ferguson as the Chairman of the Economics References Committee, of the load of that committee, and I have amended the reporting date to 30 January. I certainly did not think it was wise to have a reporting date which would clearly put it in danger of clashing with an election which most people now expect to take place in February or March next year. I have received indications of support for this motion from the government and from the WA Greens. I wish to put my appreciation on record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say, as Chairman of the Economic References Committee, this was one of the items that were discussed at our committee meeting this morning. I would remind Senator Spindler that he is a full member of that committee but that he was not even present for the discussions of these terms of reference.
—I put in an apology.

—I understand you put in an apology, but let me say that this issue was raised towards the last day of the sittings in June. It has been on the Notice Paper since that time. Since then it has been a subject of discussion this week between myself and Senator Spindler but, in fairness, let me say that it has been the history of these committees to at least discuss terms of reference such as these at committee meetings where every committee member can have some input.

PARA.TAB: I took advice this morning, particularly from Senator Childs, who has been a long-serving member of that committee. Senator Childs explained to the committee—and he may say so himself directly—the change that has taken place in past years whereby terms of reference are passed on to the committee by the Senate, rather than committee members themselves generating certain terms of reference. So the workload on many committees has made it almost impossible for the committee to do its work properly with the participation of most members of the committee.

I am sure all of the matters that have been raised by Senator Spindler and the concerns that he has expressed are concerns of every member of the community. Certainly, there was no disagreement at our committee meeting this morning about the concerns that Senator Spindler raised and whether or not they should be addressed by the committee at some future date. What concerns me is that, in discussion with Senator Spindler, I said it was impossible for us to handle these terms of reference this year.

The committee already has two terms of reference which have been ongoing. We had a telecommunications inquiry, which we are trying to complete and report on by the end of this parliamentary session. Another reference was referred to us by a member of the Democrats with regard to Eastlink and the problems proposed by that. We accepted that reference. We have not yet had any hearings. We are also trying to complete that reference by the end of the parliamentary session. We may not, but we are trying to complete it by the end of the parliamentary session. I said to Senator Spindler that it would be impossible for us to do anything with regard to a reference to outworkers in the garment industry prior to Christmas. Certainly, it would be something that we would have to do next year.

We all know that an election is going to be held some time and that many senators on this side are on three or four committees, as are many government members because of their numbers. It is just not fair to ask a committee to handle terms of reference like these without proper discussion at the committee meeting. For that reason, amongst others, we will be opposing this motion, not because we oppose the concept and the terms of reference. I think it ought to be a matter of discussion for the committee. The terms of reference should be discussed by all members of that committee who will be a part of the deliberations. We do not want another reference thrown at the committee from this chamber by an individual senator, particularly in this case a senator who was a member of the committee and who has never attended the meetings and discussed the matter with other members who were present.

In recent times we seem to have a habit of references being generated from this chamber by individual senators, often without consultation with the committee, sometimes just by consultation between either the chair of the committee or some individual members of the committee. We have situations where matters have been referred to committees by individuals who are sometimes members who then take no further part—or very little part—in the hearings or the deliberations of the committee once the matter has been referred.

I listened with interest to Senator Childs's contributions this morning because, when you have someone who has been a chairman for some 10 years, all members of the committee appreciate his experience and his point of view. There are certain procedures that should take place prior to a matter such as this being referred to the Senate—some consultation even. Maybe Senator Childs will expand on those reasons. I and other members of the committee agreed unanimously that those procedures ought to be followed before any final terms of reference were decided on or before the committee accepted those particular terms of reference which Senator Spindler wants to bring forward today.

I am of the view that committees must be allowed to manage their own programs. I think everybody would agree that the pressure of committee work is becoming greater and greater and that the pressures on individual senators as members of those committees is becoming greater. It is important that each individual committee is allowed to manage its program so that it does not have a backlog which impinges on the work of the secretariat. It makes their job much harder because they then have several references, with submissions coming in from several areas at the one time. I do not believe that the pressure we are putting on the secretariat and the secretaries servicing these committees is fair if we allow references to come willy-nilly before committees.

I repeat: I have no objection to the principles of this reference. If we have some discussion at committee level and if we go through the sorts of procedures that Senator Childs outlined to our committee this morning, I am quite sure at the end of the day that we can come up with a reference which covers the concerns of Senator Spindler but certainly which has a realistic reporting date and which may include other matters which Senator Spindler has not included in his original terms of reference.

As I said, I am going to oppose this motion of Senator Spindler's, purely because I do not believe that those procedures have been followed to the fullest. I do not believe it is a realistic timing that has been put on the reporting date and also I think there are other matters that need to be discussed before we finalise any terms of reference. So, Senator Spindler, I appreciate your concerns in that area, as I indicated to you when you first raised this matter. There are some concerns that I certainly agree with. I think there is possibly a need for the committee to have a look at a reference in this area. But this is not the time for this motion to go through without further discussion. It would be premature to pass this motion today.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also oppose this motion. I want to indicate at the outset that the spirit of the proposed reference is acceptable. I believe that subsequently the reference will be agreed to. I think as early as next week we could reach agreement on the broad principles that are proposed for the reference; but that should be on the basis of proper process. It is on the issue of process that I want to speak.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler has not, at any stage, discussed this matter with me; and we are both members of the committee. This is a development that has actually been occurring in recent times in this chamber. People move motions in the Senate as a whole, with a date of return, and, often, the committee has no say in the date of return. The difficulties that the committee has in working through its references are not considered before the senator moves the issue in the chamber itself. Also, the actual detail of the motion should be a result of collective discussion. This motion is not. For that reason, it is wrong to put it up in this chamber today and expect it to be carried.

The committee has started the discussion this morning of what would be an appropriate term of reference. There is no disagreement with the principles outlined by Senator Spindler. As far as I am concerned, and not just in this case—but this is the straw that has broken the back—senators, because of their political agenda, make the move in the Senate and do not allow a committee to consider its priorities, workload and the agenda it wants to follow over time. If you want to threaten the references committees of the Senate completely, you will not allow committees to have strategic planning of the agenda they want to follow. When every committee has difficulty in getting people to attend meetings—I think most people are, on average, members of six committees—you will find you will not have the commitment because people have not had the initial involvement and agreement that they want to follow that particular reference.

For all those reasons I oppose the motion being moved. I think if we now start the process of appropriately consulting all members of the committee and anybody else, then within another week or so we will be able to finalise a term of reference on this matter that is acceptable to everybody. I ask the Senate to reject on this occasion the proposal put forward by Senator Spindler.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this matter. There are some important issues that have been brought up so far in this debate. The committees of the Senate are supposed to be the servants of the Senate and the democratic process. Anybody who believes that a reference is important must take full cognisance of the workload of the committee which they choose, the competence of the committee to deal with the issues, the nature of the inquiry and the length of the inquiry. Ideally, the wording should be run by the committee before the reference is put to the Senate. But there are times when the majority of the Senate may approve a reference and you still get problems because the committee feels they do not like the wording.

PARA.TAB: In the end, if the committees are not to be driven by the two-party system there needs to be some means by which the democratic process can work. There has to be give and take on all sides—there is no doubt about that—but to suggest that the committees must be left alone to run their own agenda and that individual senators should not—

TALK.START.PARA: —`Must be consulted' was my wording.

—Sorry, but I was also echoing the words of Senator Ferguson, through you, Mr Chair. There is a problem here. We have to strike a balance; there is no doubt. But there is a democratic process. Every senator was elected to this chamber and has an equal democratic right. If a motion is passed, fine. There can possibly be some changes in wording; it is better, obviously. In this case what results is that the committee gets together and decides on wording. Maybe they will decide on a reference that they would not be willing to do by themselves. Every now and then it is necessary to bring a debate to a point so that kind of discussion occurs in that committee. Maybe the committee would never have had that discussion if this motion were not put.Therefore there has to be give and take. We must not ever forget that this is not just a party process; this is a democratic chamber meant to represent the states, meant to represent every elected senator. Of that we must always be cognisant.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation provides all members of the Senate with a moral dilemma. I know some members of the Senate have found it more convenient to use it as some kind of political platform for an offensive polemic, using some form of inverse racism. That does not seem a very useful approach to a problem which is serious and which should extend far beyond the sorts of political exchanges which, I must say, have not graced this chamber and which, I believe, have damaged the status of the chamber and the reputations of the people involved in that kind of absurd political point scoring.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it is reasonable to suggest that that sort of thing would be inevitable, given the evident political purpose of this bill, which does not appear to be aimed at getting an agreed outcome which would be satisfactory and would resolve the genuine differences that exist within the community about the need for this kind of legislation. Consider the nature of the legislation—in fact, the words of the title of the bill, Racial Hatred Bill. That word `hatred' is not conciliatory. It is a word aimed at confrontation. We have seen in this chamber a confrontationist style of debate at times on an issue which merits proper, reasonable and rational discussion aimed at a proper and reasonable outcome.

I thought Senator Jim Short yesterday gave one of the most impressive speeches I have heard in this chamber on this matter, outlining the genuine differences that exist in the community over this legislation—differences which exist, I might say, within those ethnic communities who are claimed by the government to be `protected' by this bill. Senator Short's speech dramatised the fact that many people in ethnic communities in Australia feel more threatened by this bill than protected by it.

I must say that I am of the strong view that, where you have this kind of evident conflict and evident disagreement, it is absurd for the government to press on with legislation which, it knows, is causing division within the society and which is not satisfactory according to plentiful evidence presented to this chamber, by Senator Short in particular, revealing divisions within the ethnic communities themselves, within those communities that this bill is allegedly protecting.

I am of the general view that there is a need to do something to discourage people from racist, improper, offensive and, one could almost say, un-Australian behaviour. There is a need to do something. In fact, many elements of legislation provide penalties for some of the racist things that are dealt with in this bill. Some of the penalties in this bill are lower, smaller and less significant than the penalties that already exist for some actions which are not based on racism but which are a manifestation of racist activity, particularly causing property and other damage.

What concerns me about this bill is that it appears to me to be seeking a worthy end. But that does not justify using unworthy means to achieve that end. This is what concerns me immensely about many of the people with whom I have an enormous sympathy who are publicly supporting this bill—and my sympathy with them extends however only so far as that debate is a rational one. It does not extend to a sympathy for those people who support this bill and who classify as racist all of us who have concerns about this bill.

I am unhappy about a trend that appears to be emerging in Australian public discussion where those who oppose worthy legislation, or actions seeking some kind of worthy end, on the grounds that the means applied are disgraceful are then categorised somehow as opposed to anything that is anti-racist and, therefore, by inference are racist. I reject that. I regard it as offensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—And I regard those parts of this debate which have gone down that track as demeaning this chamber and the people who uttered them. And I thank Senator O'Chee for his support.

PARA.TAB: I am a first generation Australian. My name is not an Anglo-Saxon one. I am here in this country and was born in this country because my parents saw it as a land of opportunity, a land of freedom, a land where there are no thought police, where there is no authoritarianism, where there is the rule of law and where there are many of the massive advantages which do not exist in the countries from which so many migrants have come to make their home.

I can say this, too: my father was Jewish. I believe my Jewish family and my Jewish associations—that atmosphere, if you like, of Jewishness of which I am immensely proud in my family—pushes me far more in the direction of protecting freedom in view of what has happened to Jewish people over time than pushing me in the other direction of putting anti-vilification, or in this case hatred, above the basic principle of individual freedom. It seems to me that one of the magnificent achievements of the Jewish contribution to the world is the insistence on the rights of the individual and of the extraordinary contribution that Jewish thinkers have made to the development of civilisation.

That is why I must admit I am disappointed that a lot of the very aggressive pressure in favour of this legislation comes from particular elements of the Jewish community that, I must say, have a sound case in favour of the legislation but apparently are not prepared to acknowledge that there is also a particularly sound case against it. That is why I say that we have a moral dilemma.

I simply cannot see why there is any need to use the word `hatred' in this legislation. What is the government's objective? It does not seem to me to be aimed at getting overwhelmingly universal support for legislation that could do some good and could go quite some way down the track of actively and effectively discouraging racism.
For example, I am nonetheless attracted to the view that was put in submissions by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry. It makes this very sound point:

SPEECH.PARA: This submission is the result of the historic concern of the Jewish Community with racism—
it is quite a proper concern—

particularly as it affects members of our community, our assessment of the contemporary prevalence of racially motivated harassment and violence and a consideration of the proposed legislation based on extensive research and consultations in this field.

The Jewish community throughout the world has traditionally suffered enormously from racially motivated harassment. It has diminished most in those countries where individual freedom is paramount. Racially motivated harassment and violence has always been greatest in authoritarian countries where freedom is not regarded as significant.

PARA.TAB: It is extraordinary to me that the Executive Council of Australian Jewry has not made that connection. It is prepared to pursue strongly the view that, at almost any price in terms of the limitation of freedom, there is a sounder case for having this kind of legislation, which creates an offence for thinking and speaking what you think, than for maintaining individual freedom.

The submission bothers me, because we have what one could say is almost support for the politically correct view that people should not say things that are offensive to others no matter what sort of inhibition it provides on personal freedom. That kind of political correctness is only a short distance from mob rule. There is a sort of mob rule in Australia—it is the mob rule of political correctness—and I for one will not have a bar of it.
The Executive Council of Australian Jewry submission goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Violence, harassment, vandalism and offensive behaviour result in a range of penalties under current federal and state laws.
That is quite true. That point has been made by opponents of the legislation. The submission makes a very sound point:

The particular feature of acts such as these, when committed for racist reasons, is that the intended targets are not restricted to the victim of the particular offence. The fire-bomb attacks on a number of Perth Asian restaurants were aimed not at the owners of particular businesses but at intimidating the entire Asian community. A swastika and a threatening slogan on the wall of a synagogue is not equivalent to defacing private or public property, as the intended victims of intimidation are Jewish people as a group. It is accepted that the murder of a police officer is a crime on a different level to that of murder as it is a crime against society and it is the ECAJ's firm belief that racially motivated crimes are also crimes against good order and challenge the basis of our society.

There is no doubt about that. There is a case for legislation of this kind dealing with offences which are more than simply offences against individuals, in particular victims, which are aimed at terrorising members of those communities. There is no doubt that happens. We have to determine whether the risk of this kind of activity not being punishable, and the risk that it poses to our society, is so great that it merits a serious threat to individual freedom that this legislation imposes. In my view—and it is an on-balance view—this threat that concerns the Executive Council of Australian Jewry goes nowhere near overwhelmingly addressing the central feature of our society, which is individual freedom. The submission goes on to state:

Anti-Jewish racism (anti-semitism) in Australia manifests itself through acts of violence against persons and property, harassment of individuals and groups of Jewish Australians, intimidation and threats directed against individuals, organisations and institutions within the Jewish community.

The Jewish community knows only too well how it has to cope with the problem. I remind the Jewish community that, in authoritarian countries where freedom is limited, the need to cope with this sort of problem would be far greater than is the case in this country. The ECAJ contends that there is abundant evidence to demonstrate that this protection against serious attempts to undermine tolerance by stirring up hatred between groups is required. The submission goes on:

Although many acts which would constitute racial incitement and racial vilification might also be covered by existing public order laws, it is important to make clear that the gravamen of racial hatred offence is the racist content of it and not simply the fact that abusive or offensive words are used. The ECAJ considers it important that there be a clear unequivocal statement on the statute book that the Australian community disapproves of racial incitement and racial hatred.

I agree that there is a need for it to be somewhere in the statute book. Why does it have to be there at the risk of Australians' freedom of expression and at the risk of putting Australians in gaol for what they think and what they say? My major concern is that the determination of an offence under this law is going to be subjective.

PARA.TAB: The important consideration is whether it is `reasonably likely'. Who is going to determine whether it is reasonably likely? There are no stated criteria. You are going to be found guilty and face a gaol sentence if somebody thinks that what you did may have been reasonably likely to create some kind of violence. There is a different onus of proof in terms of a conspiracy to create violence. It is illegal to conspire to do something illegal. I find it unacceptable that subjective criteria and not objective criteria would be used.

I also have some concerns that equality before the law is being challenged in this matter. We should all be equal before the law, particularly those people being charged with an offence. Are victims to be treated differently before the law? Is the law going to treat people differently because, say, victim A is different from victim B? I am a first generation Australian. If I am subject to some kind of attack, will the nature of the attack on me be different from the nature of the attack on, say, my wife who is, I think, a sixth generation Australian?

It seems to create divisions in a society, not resolve them. You are making people different because of the way they are to be dealt with in this kind of legislation. You are not uniting the society; you are aggravating and underlining the differences. I thought the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties stated this fact very clearly when it said about the legislation in New South Wales:

SPEECH.PARA: The experience in New South Wales suggests the legislation has simply been a lightning rod for inter-ethnic disputes, which have provided the bulk of the references to conciliation.
The Victorian Council for Civil Liberties went on to say:
While . . . the State has a legitimate role in such conciliation, it does not accept that it should be under the guise of legislation imposing restrictions on free speech.
I totally support that view. The VCCL also said:
Legislative attempts to define matters which are essentially subjective and impressionistic are doomed to failure.
This legislation is doomed to failure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of notable speeches from speakers on the Racial Hatred Bill. I do not believe I can comment any better on the failings of this bill and its intent than my colleagues Senator Jim Short and Senator Bill O'Chee. Senator O'Chee, an Australian of mixed race parents, spoke passionately about tolerance in Australia, and I would suspect that during his life he has had a far better opportunity to assess the tolerance of Australians than I.

PARA.TAB: Racism is not something that legislation alone can prevent, just as drug addiction cannot be eradicated by harsher gaol penalties. Racism is borne out of ignorance and fear and overcome only by education. As Senator O'Chee said, you must not tell people what they must think and you cannot tell people what they must feel.

In recent weeks and months we have celebrated VE Day and VP Day. Many Australians fought against the Germans and the Japanese. I suspect that many sentiments expressed during reunions this year would indeed fall foul of this bill's ideals. Surely we have come to a ridiculous state of political correctness if returned soldiers cannot have some understandably passionate sentiments against a country that was once our enemy. That is not to suggest the veteran per se is a bigot or a racist; that is not to suggest that, given an opportunity, he would commit any crime against a citizen of either Japan or Germany. But it is perfectly understandable, and surely totally acceptable, for old soldiers to have particular sentiments. As Senator O'Chee says, you cannot legislate for what people feel, and neither should you.

In Australia in the 1960s, attitudes against the Aboriginal community were appalling but they were allowed to flourish because laws were in place that allowed them to. In the intervening years, legislation has been put in place that prevents publicans from refusing service to non-whites; legislation is in place that prevents employers from discriminating against Asians, Catholics or the disabled. But legislation cannot prevent people from having feelings of resentment against any group for whatever reason, and that is the flaw of this bill.

The old adage that you can lead a horse to water but you cannot make it drink is appropriate here. The purpose of the legislation is to prohibit conduct including threats to cause physical harm to a person or group; threats to destroy or damage property; and incitement of racial hatred and acts likely to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or group on the basis of race, colour or ethnic origin.

The legislation has been condemned not just by the coalition but outside this place as well because it is flawed, inappropriate and ineffective. The legislation is inappropriate because it assumes that Australia is a racist country, and I do not really believe that to be the case. We are rapidly developing into one of the most multicultural societies in the world. It is over 30 years since the white Australia policy was abolished. It is over 40 years since Polish, Greek and Italian migrants were first welcomed to Australia. It is over 20 years since Vietnamese and other South-East Asian migrants first came to Australia to live.

The coalition has been at the forefront of that migration, so our opposition to this legislation does not stem from any lack of understanding. As previous speakers have said, we believe that only by education, not coercive legislation, can racism be overcome. The government naively believes that forcing people through the threat of criminal and civil sanctions is the appropriate course to take. That approach has not worked in the United States—it is almost a weekly occurrence to see some form of racial attack in the US—and it has not worked in the United Kingdom.
The bill intends to amend the Crimes Act to allow for three criminal offences and it is these sanctions that are particularly flawed. As the Parliamentary Bills Digest suggests:

SPEECH.PARA: The tests of intention have caused some difficulty in countries such as the United Kingdom. One problem is that it often depends upon the people to whom the act is communicated (i.e. the audience of a speech or the readers of racist material). If the people at whom the act is directed are unlikely to be incited to hatred (such as members of Parliament and other public officials), or if the intention of the act is to get them to support a change in policy, then no matter how offensive the words, an offence will not have been committed.

The bill also proposes to amend the Racial Discrimination Act by inserting another section: prohibition of offensive behaviour based on racial hatred. This section is so subjective as to be a legal minefield. How does one define `insult', `offend' and `humiliate'? What is insulting to one may be humorous to another. I do not believe that people have really thought that through well enough.

PARA.TAB: To call someone `a silly old bugger', depending on the circumstances, might be an affectionate, familiar description or an offence. Some people find no offence in being called a `pom'; others may take offence. Our endeavours to strive for political correctness in terms of sexual discrimination have been well criticised in Helen Garner's book The First Stone.

The trouble with this legislation, and with people trying to outlaw offensive behaviour, is that it tends to increase our intolerance and has the potential to have quite the opposite effect. The coalition is opposed to this legislation. I am personally very opposed to it. I believe that the better objectives to strive for are education and tolerance rather than to enact legislation which has the potential to become a witch-hunt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —For 207 years the fabric of this nation has not been torn by racial intolerance, and it has not been torn because of our high level of tolerance. Citizens from more than 100 nations have been drawn into this melting pot and, on the whole, multiculturalism has worked, and worked extremely well. We are a multicultural nation and we are extremely proud of it.

PARA.TAB: Today we find ourselves debating the Racial Hatred Bill 1994, a bill which potentially pits race against race in court battles which will leave various communities divided. I ask: for what? The government's bill goes much further than is necessary, let alone appropriate, to combat racial harassment. It goes much further than is needed to send a message to the community that that type of conduct is unacceptable because I think that message is already understood in Australia in 1995. For a moment let me delve into the proposed section 60 of this bill. This section is a fundamental denial of the right of free speech and on that ground alone the bill should be opposed. Section 60 establishes a new class of offence which impacts upon expressions of opinion rather than expressions of violent intent. It is not that those people who are victims of racial harassment or racial vilification are helpless, because they do not feel that they are. It is always a question of balance as to whether they have some remedy that is not presently available to them, such as that which is now being proposed.

I will not support a criminal sanction for expressing a view and encouraging others to adopt it when you are not inciting people to damage property or persons. To create an offence of inciting racial hatred, without linking that incitement to damage to people or property, makes it an offence to try and get other people to agree with your point of view, however offensive that may or may not be. That means an offence is committed even if there is no urging of the other people to act in a violent way on that view.

I ask: why should a person be put in gaol for encouraging others to adopt a view, however racially prejudiced that view may be? I think the famous Voltaire quote is appropriate when we talk about this legislation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.

Conversely, if a person incites others to damage property or persons, then of course criminal sanctions are called for and are available at common law and perhaps under some state law. Section 60 is the offensive provision and one that I could never support in isolation.

PARA.TAB: This bill before the Senate today also allows for civil action to be taken for hurt feelings and injured sensibilities. Surely, the government is not trying to tell us that it is government's role to make behaviour that is simply socially unacceptable unlawful, because this issue must always be handled by education. It is education, not the law, that is essential for changing such behaviour.

You cannot legislate to make people think in a certain way, however unfortunate and politicly incorrect that may be. It is worth saying that neither side of politics can claim the high moral ground on this issue. Both sides of politics want a highly developed multicultural and tolerant society. But to take the view that you can access civil action to make people think in an appropriate way or have a certain opinion of you at best drives views underground where they are likely to do more damage. If people are allowed to express their bigoted views through the media or publicly, they are then more open to public accountability and ridicule.

This bill will see otherwise law-abiding citizens dragged before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The other aspect of this argument is how will courts interpret such subjective terms as `insult' and `offend', as Senator Baume quite clearly pointed out. Experience in other jurisdictions demonstrates how it becomes an enormous dilemma.

We also have the constitutional questions arising from this legislation. Some prosecutions and civil actions taken under the proposed legislation are likely to breach the High Court's implied constitutional right of freedom of political speech. Some statements that the bill makes criminal or unlawful will occur in the field of political discussion. Laws prohibiting such discussion will be unconstitutional unless the government can show a counterbalancing public interest. Democracy is under threat whenever we consider a bill that restricts what people say, even where the vast majority of people believe the remarks themselves are offensive. Criminal sanction against somebody who incites violence against persons or property for any reason is already in place.

You arguably cannot do it at common law. You cannot do it under existing criminal law, whether it be the Crimes Act in New South Wales or the Summary Offences Act. In a liberal democracy it is not wise to proscribe behaviour unless it is absolutely necessary. That applies whether you are dealing with a bill of rights, anti-discrimination legislation generally, whistleblower legislation or sexual privacy legislation. Where change is not necessary, I think the old cliche is appropriate—it is necessary not to change. To identify forms of behaviour that are appropriate or acceptable immediately gives an excuse for other near acceptable behaviour not covered by the particular new legislation to be accessed.

There is some real cynicism, I believe, in this particular piece of legislation, apart from the title itself—`racial hatred'—where hatred is a thought and not necessarily an action. We have a diverse group of people who oppose the bill. They have been mentioned before—they range from Archbishop Hollingworth to Phillip Adams and Father Frank Brennan. There has been a very wide range of community opposition to this bill, and I think the government should have taken more note of that.

There may be criticism of us for delaying the passage of this bill. I reject that. It is not as if this legislation has been suddenly necessary. It has been talked about by the government for years—not weeks, not months, but years. It has taken them a long time to get round to it. I think this sort of political agenda—apart from political correctness—of the government has been to try to distract from the more important issues that are pressing this nation.

This is Australia. This is a country of unique social harmony and coexistence. This is a unique blend of cultures, a multicultural melting pot and a nation of immigrants. Now, in 1995, we have this really sanctimonious and unnecessary federal legislation—to satisfy whom? Even Mr Isi Leibler, representing the Ethnic Coalition, has been quoted as saying that our exposure bill does little more than reiterate existing criminal law. If his legal view is correct, so what? The existing criminal law has not done a bad job in ensuring that this remains the racially harmonious country that it is.

I think the final word probably rests with Mark Twain when he said, `It is by the goodness of God that in our country'—which, of course, is not Australia, but that does not matter—`we have those three unspeakably precious things: freedom of speech, freedom of conscience, and the prudence never to practise either of them.'

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Racial Hatred Bill, which is a very disturbing bill in many aspects. In the 17th century we had the French satirist Voltaire, who is quoted as saying, `I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.' Then we had in the 1800s the liberal philosopher John Stuart Mill, who wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the peculiar evil of silencing the expression of an opinion is that it is robbing the human race; posterity as well as the existing generation; those who dissent from the opinion still more than those who hold it. If the opinion is right, they are deprived of the opportunity of exchanging error for truth; if wrong, they lose what is almost as great a benefit, the clearer perception and livelier impression of truth produced by its collision with error.

In consideration of this Racial Hatred Bill in the 20th century I think these quotes are just as apt if we take the bill in the context of freedom of speech. That is the area which concerns me immensely today.

PARA.TAB: If I were to sum up the views of my constituents at the moment, I would say that they are first and foremost concerned that they will be prosecuted in some way for thinking thoughts about multiculturalism or immigration which may be construed by somebody else under this legislation as racially vilifying. That is the concern—that we are going to have the thought police interpreting everything that somebody else is saying.

They also feel that their right to comment on the social structure of their own country will be effectively abolished under this legislation, and I can tell you they are not particularly happy about that prospect. They have a right to speak their mind and they wish to exercise that. They do not wish to exercise a position of racial vilification or hatred; they just want to speak their mind.

Many of these people recognise racism and are totally opposed to it, particularly when it culminates, in extreme cases, in threats against person and property. As a Western Australian, I can only say that the recent fire bombing of the French Consul building in Perth—which, incidentally, is just around the corner from my office—was something that was considered absolutely outrageous by every person to whom I spoke and who commented on the issue.

That behaviour is not tolerated. People certainly do not tolerate the firebombing of Chinese restaurants, the spraying of racist slogans on walls, or the posting of seditious bills in bus shelters. They simply do not go along with that, and that is the whole issue. It is not a case of trying to lock up people because they think something or they might say something. The fact of the matter is that they are not racists at heart; they simply want to have the freedom to express an opinion. They have an inherent understanding of what is right and what is wrong. They certainly view those types of firebombings, bill-posting episodes and activities as particularly antisocial and, I might say, totally unAustralian.

Like most people, Australians are prepared to give all people a fair go regardless of their race, colour, ethnicity or nationality. But, likewise, the coalition is totally opposed to racism. It has a proud record of commitment to the elimination of racism and, to suggest otherwise, as this government continues to do, is absolutely and utterly absurd. They choose to forget, in their rewriting of history, our attitude to multiculturalism and our attitude to the way in which we tolerate a very diverse nation. We accept and enjoy, I might add, a very diverse nation. They choose to forget that it was, after all, the coalition which abolished the White Australia policy—a decision which led to the migration of a wide range of people from all over the world.

I have been to multicultural functions where I have actually heard Labor politicians saying that they were the ones who got rid of the White Australia policy. Of course, we have become used to the lies of the Labor Party to get re-elected. We have become used to the untruths as well. I detect your frown, Mr Acting Deputy President, at the use of the word I used to describe their behaviour. Nonetheless, I think the way in which the Labor Party continues to rewrite history on some of these issues is very sad because it was, after all, the coalition that established the Office of Multicultural Affairs. It was, after all, the coalition that established SBS Television and a wide range of multicultural settlement services which form the foundation of today's multicultural policies.

But to listen to the talk of this mob today, and in years gone by, you would consider that we not only opposed the introduction of all of those measures but that in fact it was the Labor Party who did the introducing. That is wrong. Therefore to suggest that we are in any way a racially-based party is just absurd, and offensive in the extreme. Clearly, the coalition is not racist, and I think I have been able to demonstrate that, in the last few sentences particularly, and I will continue over the months and years to come to demonstrate our attitude to the type of Australia that we have.

It is our position that the focal point of the Racial Hatred Bill should be the prohibition of racially-based threats of physical harm to property or person. The stronger penalties that have been proposed by the coalition reflect the fact that racially-motivated threats of violence have absolutely no place in Australia, and neither do the people who make such threats and carry them out. However, the coalition's position upholds the value of freedom of speech—one of the most sacred cows of our democracy and, of course, of our constitution. No political party should be seen to be throwing the baby out with the bathwater and just simply saying that our constitution matters no longer or that we can restrict freedom of speech and get away with it. We cannot, and that is not what the people of Australia want. They want to retain their freedom of speech, but not from racial motivation. But that position, of course, is to be contrasted with the government's legislation which, undoubtedly, compromises freedom of speech through its restrictive limitations on incitement to racial hatred.

This is what most people out there in the community are worried about. They, like the coalition, do not want to see people facing criminal sanctions every time they say or think something which may be interpreted by somebody else as incitement to racial hatred. We will have consistent claims by every Tom, Dick and Harry that this is racial incitement. It was absurd to suggest that the firebombing of the French consuls building in Perth would not have happened had this bill been in place. There were criminal penalties to be imposed against the initiators of that attack, and they are currently going through the judiciary system. What is wrong with the current system which will see those people brought to justice? You do not need this bill to have those people brought to justice. There is no word from anyone that will justify this bill in relation to those particular people and their vicious, horrible, despicable actions.

As I said in my opening statement, just because we disagree with what someone says does not mean that they do not have a right to say it. Certainly, they should not be sent to gaol by the thought police for comments which intend no harm to other races. There is a clear difference between the expression of an opinion and a blatant threat of physical harm to a person or property. It is equally disturbing that the government's bill allows civil remedies to be sought through applications to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. This would apply in the case of comments being made which are insulting or which offend. Quite frankly, the impact of all of that is absolutely and utterly mind-boggling. The potential for people to be dragged before the commission just because they have referred to someone as a Yank or as a Pom is quite real under the present legislation. That takes us from the sublime to the ridiculous.

For a start, it will probably nip Aussie humour right in the bud. A lot of sport commentators, for example, would have their vocabulary seriously curtailed. It is true that legislation of this type may play an important role in deterring many people who are already actively engaged in organised racially motivated criminal offences, although many of them are probably clever enough to sidestep these laws. This is a classic case of using a sledgehammer to crack a nut, and it has gone far beyond that which is necessary. It is for those reasons that I have made these comments. (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Racial Hatred Bill 1994 and the coalition has indicated that in the form as presented to the parliament, it will have no option but to oppose this piece of proposed legislation. It is, however, a matter of regret to us that the government has denied the parliament the opportunity—it seems to us—to make an historic and bipartisan declaration about racial hatred and vilification in this country. It is a great pity because there is no doubt that eliminating racism is a cause that enjoys universal support in this place. Also, it would seem that there is widespread support among senators and members for the idea that it is appropriate for the federal parliament to have on its statute books laws which target the worst forms of racial vilification. It is also a great pity because I believe that, in itself, the bipartisan adoption of anti-racial vilification laws would have sent a strong and clear message to the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: Instead of allowing the parliament that opportunity, the government has introduced this bill in a shroud of secrecy—as it was at the time—without any real consultation with the coalition and, as far as I know, at that time without consultation with the minor parties. As a result, it produced a bill that the coalition finds it cannot support, for reasons that I will refer to shortly and that have been mentioned by previous speakers. One might wonder whether, in fact, that was really the government's intentions.
