I would have thought that if the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) were thinking about anything other than trying to score a few political points, they might have gone down a similar path to that which has successfully led to the establishment of the national reconciliation process. They, however, approach this bill in a very different way—a very political way. Such a process would have at least given us a chance at trying to develop a bill that could have had bipartisan support on what is undeniably an important issue for all Australians. I am disappointed that that has not happened in this instance, disappointed because I personally support the principles that lie behind anti-racial vilification legislation.

All Australians should be able to live their lives without fear for their personal wellbeing that extreme forms of racial hatred, vilification and intolerance necessarily produce. As the national parliament, we have an obligation to see those rights protected. That can best be achieved by trying to change attitudes and by further encouraging society to recognise the values of tolerance and the inherent evil and irrationality of racism.

Eliminating racial hatred can be genuinely achieved only if people of their own free will recognise that such attitudes are unjustifiable. Changing those attitudes must be the first priority of government. It must also be recognised that it has not been—and will not always be—possible to, by force of logic alone, change the attitudes of proponents of racist views. For that reason, those who suffer from the worst manifestations of racism should have recourse to and the protection of the law. In addition to providing that protection, I also believe that properly drafted racial vilification laws can provide the basis for public education towards eliminating racism. The mere existence of such law sends a message to the community about the type of behaviour that is unacceptable within our society.

I recognise that there are many in our community who, with absolute sincerity and good faith, nevertheless argue against the principle of racial hatred or racial vilification laws. Much of the concern surrounding this type of legislation is based on the fear that it will by its very nature impact on the rights of free speech that are a fundamental part of our democratic society and a protection in themselves. Concern about free speech is interlinked with a belief that such laws achieve little in changing people's behaviour and that in a society which prides itself on the success of multiculturalism they are an over-reaction to what is not a great problem—to quote a former Labor senator, John Button, `a legislative steamroller to crack a few nuts'. Frank Brennan summed up some of those arguments in an article for Quadrant, in which he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The criminal law is a very blunt instrument for reshaping the hearts of racists and clearing the air of racist sentiment. This proposed interference with civil liberties would do nothing to enhance . . . human rights. At this time, in this part of the world thought police armed with criminal sanctions are not the answer.

To my mind, the proponents of racial vilification legislation must answer three fundamental questions most frequently raised by the critics. Are race hatred laws an over-reaction to the needs of modern Australian society? Are such laws actually effective? Do they represent an intolerable threat to free speech? I want to touch briefly on these three issues. Australian society is certainly one of the most racially tolerant societies in the world. We are spared the type of racial conflict and strife that we so frequently see encountered in other parts of the world. In part that has been the result of the policies of multiculturalism that I mentioned, which have been embraced by governments, both coalition and Labor, during the last two decades. More fundamentally it reflects the basic decency, tolerance and humanity of the Australian people.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless there is present within our society a small minority of people who propound racist views of the worst kind, those who do undeniably promote and seek to incite racial hatred and vilification. Dr Nguyen Trieu Dan, a Vietnamese community leader, wrote some little time ago in the Age of a Melbourne University study of year 11 and 12 students in Dandenong. Of 100 Vietnamese refugees students who took part in that survey, 69 claimed to have experienced racism in their school environment, 59 per cent in the streets and 14 per cent claim to have suffered either physical threats or actual injury.

Many other reports, including the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission inquiry into racist violence, have documented specific cases of race related violence. There can be no doubt that racial vilification and violence do occur in Australia. The fact that racial vilification is comparatively less prevalent in Australia than in virtually any other country is, I believe, sound justification for arguing against these types of laws. We have an obligation to defend the rights of and provide legal protection to every individual, be it one person or 1,000. The fact that a problem exists, no matter what the scale, is in my mind justification enough for legislative action. So it seems to me that the principle of such legislation is not an over-reaction.

The second question I posed is whether the type of legislation we are considering today can actually be effective. I have already stated that I think there is an educative role played by the very existence of such legislation, but fundamentally this legislation on its own cannot change beliefs. That is something I think even the most ardent supporters of racial hatred laws can see. What such laws can do is influence and contribute towards a change in behaviour. What they also do is offer some protection to the victims of the racial vilification and violence.

New South Wales has introduced and implemented such laws. South Australia under a Liberal government, New South Wales under a coalition government and South Australia under a Liberal government are also about to introduce such laws at a state level. So as to the issue of whether they can be effective, whilst one would not want to overstate the outcome, there is no doubt that laws do contribute to modifying behaviour.

The final issue of this type that I mention is the question of the infringement of free speech and whether it can be justified. That, of course, is the area in which the critics are at their strongest. Racial vilification or hatred legislation certainly does represent some type of restriction upon free speech. There are some within our society who would argue that free speech is one of those paramount rights that should never be infringed. Certainly that has been the tenor of a few of those arguing against this type of legislation. Free speech, I agree, is a fundamental right, but it is not and, I would suggest, never has been, an unfettered right.

We already limit free speech when it is considered necessary to maintain other individual rights and the general order of society. I, of course, refer to laws in such areas as defamation, pornography, consumer protection and copyright. In this instance we are confronted with what one commentator has described as `the delicate contest'—the contest between the right to free speech and the right of Australian citizens to lead their lives without fear from racially inspired vilification and violence.

It is my belief that it is possible to balance the competing interests, firstly, by ensuring that racial vilification laws deal with only the most serious manifestations of racism and, secondly, by ensuring that any legislation contains appropriate exemptions to protect debate, commentary and the promotion of ideas and beliefs within our community.

For me, it is difficult to find a sound basis for those that argue that principles associated with freedom of speech should take precedence over other rights and freedoms when we are dealing with threats of violence and damage to property and what is in effect interference with the ability of individuals to conduct their lives in a normal fashion free from persecution and discrimination.

We have now had racial vilification laws operating in New South Wales for six years. I do not think anyone seriously argues that the right of free speech in New South Wales has been detrimentally affected by such laws. The New South Wales parliament, as I said, led then by a coalition government, has demonstrated that resolving that delicate contest is not beyond the skills of legislators and parliamentary draftsmen.

Having said that, however, it is a fine balance. That is why, perhaps more than usual, the precise form of legislation dealing with racial vilification is so absolutely important. If the balance is tipped too far in favour of restricting speech and the promulgation of written or artistic material, then my strong view is that the legislation should be opposed.

It is principally because we believe that the government has failed to achieve an appropriate balance in the drafting of these measures that we have taken the decision that we must oppose them. In our view, this bill unduly restricts the rights of free speech that I have been referring to. It goes well beyond the legislative measures taken by various state parliaments, including New South Wales, despite the government's claim that state acts were to be a model upon which it would base its own bill. It goes beyond the recommendations of the various reports that the government has claimed were a significant motivating factor in its decision to introduce legislation in this area. It does so in relation to both the criminal and the civil offences that it seeks to create, but particularly in relation to the criminal offences.

The bill before us creates three new criminal offences, two in relation to threatening a person or a group of people or their property because of their race, colour, national or ethnic origin; and a third, which is our area of great concern, that creates a criminal offence in terms that it proposes that intentional public acts that are reasonably likely to incite racial hatred—not personal injury or injury to property—against another person will be prohibited with a penalty of up to one year's imprisonment. This clause goes well beyond the criminal offence created under the New South Wales legislation, which, as I said, the government has claimed to be its model.

In the New South Wales legislation, it is an offence to publicly incite hatred towards, serious contempt for or severe ridicule of a person or group of persons on the ground of race, but by means which include threatening or inciting others to threaten physical harm or damage to property. That qualification is not included within the third offence that this government is seeking to establish in its legislation.

In my view, therefore, and in the view of the coalition, the government's proposal tips the scale intolerably against the principles of free speech. It creates an offence that will be difficult for the courts to determine. It provides no exemptions for fair and accurate reporting. Perhaps most fundamentally, it creates an offence for advocating a particular belief as distinct from particular forms of behaviour and action, which is the primary test of the New South Wales legislation.

I am surprised that the minister referred to the Australian Law Reform Commission report into multiculturalism and the law and the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody in his second reading speech to justify the government's position. In many respects, he did so in a way that was disingenuous. A casual perusal of his speech would lead one to the view that the bill met the recommendations of those reports.

If he had been truly frank, he might have acknowledged the fact that, whilst those reports recommended an extension of the law to provide protection against extreme racism, both specifically opposed criminal sanction. The ALRC regarded criminal sanctions as too great an infringement of civil liberties. The minister also made mention of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report on racist violence. Whilst that report supported some criminal sanctions, it too was concerned about criminal laws dealing with the `incitement of racial hostility' and recommended against them.

I am equally concerned about the effects of the proposed civil offences in the bill. Again, this bill departs dramatically from the New South Wales model. In the form that it is in before us, it would become unlawful for a person to do an act in public that is reasonably likely in all the circumstances to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or group of people if that act is done because of the race of the offended person or persons. Again, I argue that that form of words presents an unacceptable threat to civil liberties in Australia. The New South Wales legislation provides a far more rigorous test, referring to inciting `hatred towards, serious contempt for or severe ridicule of a person or group of persons on the ground of race'.

I mentioned the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission report. While it supported civil actions, it did quite clearly recommend against the form of words that this government has chosen to include within this bill. Irene Moss in that report specifically argued that the threshold for prohibited conduct must be higher than `expressions of mere ill will' or conduct that results in `hurt feelings or injured sensitivities'.

My concern about the way in which this bill has been drafted primarily relates to its impact on civil liberties. It quite simply goes too far. In seeking to address an evil, it introduces the risk of creating another evil.

There are a number of other issues of lesser concern that I have with the bill. It does not clearly define the term `race' so as to include ethno-religious groupings such as Muslims or Jews. It does not clearly define the word `public'. An example is whether a closed meeting or an organisation or private property would constitute a public act. I am concerned that, despite the minister's assurances, it does not clearly delineate responsibilities between the Commonwealth and those state jurisdictions with similar laws. I said at the outset that I am disappointed the government has introduced this bill in a form that we find unacceptable. If it had been in an acceptable form—a form that could have been negotiated—I would have been pleased to support it.

I hope if the Senate successfully defeats this bill that it might be possible for the parliament to consider a more appropriate bill at a future date. Certainly it is our hope that the exposure draft of an alternative bill prepared by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the coalition, which is currently being considered within the community, may form the basis for such an opportunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed Racial Hatred Bill aims to deter racial vilification in our community. It is meant to signify the absolute unacceptability of intimidation on the grounds of a person's race or ethnicity. Nobody in the Australian community would not believe that that is a worthwhile aim.

PARA.TAB: This bill was originally proposed by the Keating government in 1992. It is finally before federal parliament to placate those parts of the constituency who wanted it then but who had to wait because of a then forthcoming election. The proposal has been welcomed by many who have suffered racial vilification. However, the issue is complex and there is no consensus in the community about the actual form that this legislation has taken.

I have serious misgivings about this legislation. Let's look first at the form that the government has chosen to apply to the worthwhile aim of deterring racial vilification in our community. The bill proposes in its first section three new crimes under the federal Crimes Act: firstly, the threat to harm a person on the basis of racial, national or ethnic origin, with a maximum penalty of two years imprisonment; secondly, the threat to damage a person's property on the same basis, with a maximum penalty of one year's imprisonment; and, thirdly, incitement to racial hatred in a public place, with a maximum penalty of one year's imprisonment. Various specific concerns about the creation of those criminal offences have been dealt with at the committee level and are also worth flagging. I will be flagging them further in the committee stage of this bill's debate.

I am sure that, like myself, all honourable senators have been contacted by many members of the community. On the one hand, my office mailbag and phone lines have made me aware of the deep desire within what we would call the ethnic communities that this bill be passed without delay because of their own experience of racial hatred and their hope that this legislation would put an end to it.

On the other hand, there has been an enormous amount of mail from people who did not identify themselves as belonging to the ethnic community, calling for this bill to be rejected because of fears that it would curtail freedom of speech or would make people subject to draconian new government powers. I have grave doubts that the hopes and aspirations mentioned by the former group will be carried out through this particular legislation. I have sympathy with those who express concern, for different motivations sometimes from my own, but who nevertheless raise very valid objections to the form that this legislation has taken.

Firstly, let us be clear that the bill makes it a crime to threaten violence or damage. The harm itself is already an offence under existing state laws. Not only do we have racial vilification laws as part of the criminal codes of New South Wales and Western Australia, all states in Australia have laws that look at the threatening of violence or damage whether it has a racial motivation or not. So we need to look here at the fact that the federal bill deals purely with threat.

If this legislation is passed it will create a crime of words. This will take the legislation across a certain threshold into the realm of thought police—the most commonly voiced concern in the community and one which I share.

However, the bill only applies to threats made by private individuals in a public place. Institutions, political parties and incorporated bodies will not be affected, and the definition of a `private place' has been kept extremely liberal to protect the freedom of speech implied in Australia's constitution.

My major concern lies elsewhere. I do not believe that we will become a less racist, more tolerant society by passing a law that imitates exactly the type of intolerance that we are trying to readdress—that is, intolerance of people expressing racial sentiments. We would be guilty of doing just what we are accusing racists of doing—singling out groups of people by labelling them unacceptable. It is a them and us adversarial way of thinking that underlies this bill. It is the same them and us attitude that underlies racism within our community.

I believe that there are three phases on the road to overcoming oppression. The first is that people who have been oppressed will often, and understandably on their release from that condition, go straight for the power that the oppressor represented. Identification with the oppressor is a natural first response. I believe that that is the natural first response of people who have experienced the humiliation, offence and insult of racism directed at their person. The comments I make in relation to this bill should in no way undercut the seriousness of the issue.

This legislation is copying the oppressor. What we need instead is a more positive way forward. Nelson Mandela is an outstanding example of the third phase of overcoming oppression. By not using against whites the same sort of power that was used against blacks he has reached a far more powerful model, that of working together in a community in which all belong.

I am aware that someone like I may have less credibility in this area than someone who has suffered oppression and racial vilification, but I think my belief is similar to that of many of the victims of racism and racial vilification who have come to the realisation that they do not want to identify with the oppression which they have suffered. To say that people who are racist are criminals is to distance ourselves from the racist streak that is in all of us. It separates people rather than produces a positive sense of belonging in our community.

By passing this bill we would be promoting the very attitude that we want to oppose—that is, of some people being superior and others inferior—rather than promoting the idea that we are all human beings who can work together. My response to the Racial Hatred Bill comes from wanting that same powerful stand of resisting all violence to all people, even against racists, as a way of promoting racial tolerance and harmony in the community.

I believe that to talk about violence and to differentiate different degrees of violence according to motivation is to set a false hierarchy. To say that racist violence is somehow worse than sexist violence or ageist violence is missing the point of what this bill is essentially aiming to achieve, which is harmony and tolerance. To actually make a hierarchy and not insist that all violence is unacceptable and all threats to damage people's property and all threats to hurt human beings are unacceptable in our community is the valid message. To say that one is worse than the other would create a false dichotomy—one that may well haunt us.

Many people say the bill would be a signal to would-be perpetrators. Let us ask ourselves what kind of signal we are sending. I believe it is one of threat. The bill's intention is not to imprison those who use words to threaten, but to tell them to shut up. You do not even have to enforce these laws in order for a coercive message to be sent. In fact, that is why some support the bill. It sends what they believe is a strong deterrent message; a message that people who are against racism also have teeth. But the government's action in this area falls into the same category as the action taken by a lot of governments, which is to take the legislative path and promote criminal sanctions as the easy way to address the complex and difficult problems that exist within our community.

This smacks very much of the easy retort when journalists revealed misdemeanours which the Australian federal government had been involved with in relation to the bugging of one of our consulates. They were threatened with being gaoled for revealing that fact.

Even more recently, the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) had a quick knee-jerk reaction, presumably to placate the feelings of Indonesia, that anybody who burns a flag should be made a criminal and receive a criminal penalty. It does not matter that the people of East Timor were protesting against the loss of lives within their own community. I think there was a rightful response to that knee-jerk reaction which was to say, `What would be achieved? What are we doing by preventing people from voicing their strong feelings, their strong emotions?'

When the Arthur Tunstall joke was raised in the community—and I think this has been an indication of how little people understand the impact that this bill has or does not have—people said, `If we had this legislation, the racial hatred legislation, we would have been able to deal with that.' I ask you: how? This legislation does not cover something like that, nor would I be arguing that it should. That does not mean that I in any way would associate with the racist tenor of the joke that was told—no way.

However, I believe that the most appropriate mechanism for addressing that problem is to let people express their opposing views to show that those kinds of expressions are out of place in a harmonious and tolerant society that values diversity, that affirms people's racial differences and different cultures which they bring to our community. I believe that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) actually dealt with it very adequately by speaking out strongly. We do not need to be waving a gaol penalty around to prove the point that those kinds of off-taste jokes are acceptable in this day and age in our community.

Similarly, when the even more serious incident occurred of the tragic desecration of the grave of Eddie Mabo in Queensland, people were saying, `If we had racial hatred legislation it would have dealt with that. It would not have happened.' Sadly, that is totally inaccurate but it does not mean that there is not redress in cases of that seriousness.

For a start, the Queensland state laws would cover the desecration and damage to a grave. The penalties that are associated with that would highly likely involve the serious end of the continuum and may well involve imprisonment according to the other mitigating factors that were involved. So the state penalties already cover that. Furthermore, this particular bill would not cover that because this bill could have been brought into operation only if somebody had threatened to do that. It is not the actual damage or the actual racism expressed in the words that could be dealt with by this bill.

The actual publicising of that incident, I believe, illustrates that our community has changed radically over the years. There was a time, and I still regret that it is there, when many people would have seen racism as permanently institutionalised within the Australian community. We have moved far from the White Australia Policy. It does not mean that everybody within our community is at the same stage in that, but certainly we have moved. We have institutionalised racism still in existence in our criminal justice system, in our prisons and in our police lock-ups because we have criminal justice systems that overimprison people. Those people could have a very good argument for saying it is their race that causes their overimprisonment.

Would this racial vilification law address the institutionalised racism of the Australian society? No, it would not. In fact, it could well be counterproductive by adding a weapon to that armoury of institutionalised racism when, as Father Frank Brennan pointed out, Aboriginal people who are complaining about the treatment they are receiving could easily become a target for being sentenced under this law.

I believe that the culture of coercion that this bill seeks to set up is merely that. I do not have a fear of these laws being enforced. I believe that is a major comfort to the people who have asked for the bill: they believe that it will be enforced. I do not think the bill is enforceable; there are far too many problems.

However, if it were to be enforced it would create even more problems and I believe we would see the unintended consequences of a possibly well-intentioned bill. There are those who say, `No, no, we do not ever intend it to be enforced. It is just there as a signal. It is a deterrent.' When will our society learn—as America has failed to learn—that creating new criminal offences and toughening penalties is not a deterrent. It is perceived to be a deterrent by those who do not contravene the law. Over and over again it has been proven to have failed to affect those who do contravene the law.

Deterrents will not operate unless the three psychological principles of deterrence are applied. The first principle is that the punishment must fit the crime; it must be appropriate. It must be perceived to be appropriate by the person who has committed the offence in order for it to act as a deterrent.

The second principle is that it must be consistently applied to everybody across the community—not just to the powerless and those who cannot afford legal defences. Nobody should be immune: not politicians, radio announcers or all those who really are indemnified by the framing of this legislation. In order to be a deterrent it has to be consistently applied across the community.

The third principle is that it has to be immediate in its consequences. It is rather like house-training a puppy: if you smack it a long distance from the misdemeanour that has occurred you have no hope of teaching it anything. These laws are framed in such a way that they are ineffectual by the time they arrive on the doorstep of anybody who may have caused a racist offence. It does not reach the people who may be expressing racist views because, I can assure the Senate, no-one who expresses racist views believes that they are racist. They always think that they are right. So there is no point in waving legislation at them and trying to make them into criminals.

Having expressed my concerns about the criminal sanctions in the bill, I would like to say that I welcome the second part of the bill which deals with access to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Section 9 of the Racial Discrimination Act already implies an avenue for complaint, but this bill will make it explicit and symbolic. It will send a signal that it is unacceptable. It will send a signal that people have an avenue for redress. It says that if you have suffered racial vilification you can be assured of access to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

It is similar to provisions against sexual harassment and domestic violence, although neither of these have penalties under federal law but rely on state criminal codes. I believe that civil remedies such as those provided by the HREOC are appropriate federal measures to address injustices and to fulfil our international treaty obligations. Criminal penalties are not the answer.

I will be proposing an amendment to the title of the bill. The title is wholly inappropriate to the positive motivation that the bill should be trying to promote. A racial hatred bill in the Year of Tolerance to promote racial tolerance is simply a contradiction in terms. I believe that this act should rather be cited as the racial tolerance act. I will be proposing amendments to that effect and to eliminate the three criminal sanctions that have been proposed.

The Greens acknowledge that this is a complex matter and that there are different views in the community. We believe that there is consensus that racism is unacceptable and that racial vilification and racial violence are unacceptable, but this legislation is not the best means of dealing with it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like my colleagues on this side of the House, I rise to oppose the Racial Hatred Bill. There are two grounds on which I have that position: firstly, I believe that this bill represents an improper and undue restriction on freedom of speech in this country; and, secondly, I think this bill has a dubious constitutional foundation in that it appears to rely on the external affairs power. In my view, the matters dealt with in this bill are matters for state parliaments, not the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: If I may deal with the first of my grounds for objection, the very important issue of freedom of speech. Freedom of speech is a fundamental tenet of the philosophy of my party; that is, liberalism. I believe it is a fundamental tenet of democracy itself. In my view—and in the view of my colleagues on this side of the House and of many Australians—this bill is an insidious example of the growing restrictions on freedom of speech, which we are encountering in the name of an insidious philosophy that bears the name of political correctness; that is, the philosophy that says, `We shall control what you say and to whom you may say it.'

It is not atypical of this government that a bill of this kind should be brought forward. This is the government that is increasingly being characterised as authoritarian by many commentators. This is the government that passed an act through this parliament to ban political advertising, an act which was then thrown out by the High Court.

This bill is in the same vein as that particular legislation. It seeks to make racially based threats criminal offences, and I congratulate Senator Chamarette on her eloquent objection to those provisions. But it also makes offensive statements civil offences, and I am disappointed that Senator Chamarette should indicate her support for those. In my view, both of these sections are unacceptable restrictions on the freedom of speech in this country.

There is, of course, no absolute freedom of speech in a democracy. We have laws at state and federal levels that qualify the freedom of speech which, in a democracy, we regard as acceptable restrictions, particularly in relation to defamation—although that restriction has been loosened recently by the High Court as well.

What we are saying to the parliament is that this bill is an undue restriction on the freedom of speech in Australian society. To justify what we regard as an undue restriction, the government would need overwhelming and compelling evidence that such drastic legislation was necessary for the cohesion of Australian society. In my view, the government has not produced any convincing evidence to justify this draconian law.

I think there is universal agreement on both sides of this chamber—throughout Australian society and probably internationally as well—that Australia is one of the most extraordinarily tolerant nations in the world. We all are proud of the absorption of migrants from all over the world that has occurred particularly since World War II. There has been a remarkable absorption of peoples from all over the world by this society. That is why I really do believe that this law is an insult to the tolerance and acceptance which Australian society has exhibited for the last 50 years.

Both sides of politics proclaim the success of our multicultural society. We hear it particularly from the government, but we share in the view that our society has been successful in absorbing people from all over the world. To justify this kind of law, you are really saying that multiculturalism has been an abominable failure and a monumental failure. What you are saying if you put forward a law like this is that something is not working, something is wrong and that our multiculturalism is wrong. But that is simply not the case.

The government often proclaims the view, which we share, that this has been a remarkably successful multicultural society. We do not think it has failed. We do not think Australians need to be punished or insulted by the introduction of such a law. This law is unnecessary and should be rejected by the Senate.

It is already an offence in Australian states and territories to threaten to cause injury to people or to property. The law is there and can be used. This law may also offend the constitutional protection of freedom of political discussion which has recently been enunciated. As the Parliamentary Library's Bills Digest on this bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Racial Hatred Bill is clearly directed at restricting certain forms of speech and is targeted at the subject matter of the speech. It will, accordingly, require a compelling justification to sustain its validity.

It is our view that there is no compelling justification for this law at all. The government has simply not put up that justification. The print media in this country, to their great credit, are overwhelmingly opposed to this law because of its unwarranted restriction on the freedom of speech.

PARA.TAB: We have Labor sympathisers like Phillip Adams and Father Frank Brennan vehemently opposed to the law brought forward by this Labor government. Indeed, I commend Phillip Adams on his excellent article in the Weekend Australian of 27 May. I quote his introduction to that excellent article:
Around the world, people are dying to get it. And we're giving it away. Qualifying it, compromising it, trying to suffocate it in new protocols and legislation. Free speech.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:
The real test of our commitment to the ideal—
of free speech—
is our willingness to extend the right to people we disagree with. To those we don't like.
It has not been put more eloquently than by Phillip Adams.

PARA.TAB: I move to my second ground for objection to this piece of legislation; that is, the question of the head of power under which it is enacted. It is legitimate to ask what authority the Commonwealth parliament has to enact this restriction on the freedom of speech. We presume that the source of constitutional authority is the external affairs power. So again we have a Labor government using the external affairs power to pass laws clearly and unequivocally dealing with purely domestic issues.

The Australians who drafted our constitution and the Australians who voted in support of it would no doubt be horrified to learn that a federal government was using the external affairs power to restrict the freedom of speech. What Australians can and cannot say is, frankly, an internal affair; it is not an external affair and it has nothing to do with the external affairs power.

In my view, this bill and the enactment of it under this head of power simply reinforce the argument that the constitution does need amendment to restrict the external affairs power to the purposes for which it was originally intended. It is wrong to use this head of power to give the federal government the authority to decide what Australians can and cannot say, because that is what this bill purports to do.

Apart from that in-principle issue of the use of the external affairs power to enact legislation like this, there is the specific question about whether this is an act that is valid even under the current High Court's very wide interpretation of the external affairs power. The Parliamentary Library's Bills Digest argues persuasively that there must be some doubt about the constitutional validity of the civil offences created by this bill and, if this bill does pass, no doubt it will be challenged.

I must say in any event as a committed federalist—putting that argument to one side—that it is my firm view that laws such as this should not be the province of the Commonwealth government at all. I adhere firmly to the principle of subsidiarity—which I am pleased to see is growing in its support around the world, most particularly in the European Union—that is, that laws should be made at the lowest possible level of government if we are to sustain democracy and people's commitment to it.

If there is any demonstrated need for laws such as this dealing with racial hatred—and I commend Senator Chamarette for arguing the offensiveness of that in itself; we ought to be talking about racial tolerance—which need this government has not put forward, then it should be a matter for state governments. It is for state governments to determine the need for laws such as this and act accordingly. We do have different societies, different positions, different values and different compositions around Australia, and it is for states to respond accordingly if the need is demonstrated.

Of course, the New South Wales government, as this federal government has said, has decided that that state needed a law dealing with racial vilification, and such a law was enacted in 1989. It is proper for the New South Wales government to come to the view that in that particular state, which has a different composition, different pressures and different status, such a law is necessary.

I am not going to comment on the rights or wrongs of the New South Wales law, but I respect the right of that parliament to enact such a law. I believe that is the appropriate place for decisions to be made on laws such as this and, as I understand it, the ACT, Western Australia and Queensland have also introduced laws dealing with this subject. Again, it is proper for those states to decide accordingly.

The other states in Australia, which are different, have decided not to introduce such laws and, again, it is quite proper for them to conclude that such laws are not necessary in their particular communities. It should be continually noted that all states have laws dealing with threats to cause injury to people or property. Those laws exist, are enforced and applied, and cover many of the situations envisaged by this bill.

In concluding, I join with all my colleagues on this side of the chamber, and with many Australians and many Labor sympathisers, in opposing this bill. I think it is a frightening application of the rules of political correctness; I do think it is an undue and unwarranted restriction on our freedom of speech; and I also believe that it is a very dangerous precedent for restricting other forms of speech dealing with matters other than race. That, I think, is also sobering. I do not believe the government has put forward any compelling evidence to justify the draconian measures included in this bill. I do believe, like Phillip Adams, that this is a genuine threat to the intellectual and political liberties of Australians and that it should be rejected by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —At last we have had a debate on this legislation. At last we have come to what is almost the end of a long road of deliberation on a bill which is important to our community, the Racial Hatred Bill, as it has been important to so many other communities across the world.

PARA.TAB: It is with a degree of sorrow that I have had to listen this morning to some of the speakers from the opposition. We have before us this piece of legislation, this sort of initiative, this sort of measure. The world has come to a decision on the need for a measure such as this through the ICCPR. Western democracies, whether they be the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Canada, or the 20 states of the USA, have introduced legislation like this. This is the global perspective. Looking at the perspective within Australia, there are so many states taking measures here as well.

It has been some 21 years since the Racial Discrimination Act was first introduced into this place. There were people who then opposed this act, which has been working vibrantly since those times. There also was a long process of consultation on a bill which was introduced before the last election—a bill much broader in impact than this one; a bill which received bipartisan support before that election and which was entrenched in Fightback. Despite all this, at the end of the debate on the bill now before us the Senate in this parliament and the opposition on a federal level in this country are the only institutions that are resisting a measure which has both social and economic impact on this country, as it has had on other countries.

I never expected any joy from the Greens and, to the extent that we have got some, we understand where they come from. But it is the opposition that I find very disappointing in this particular measure because they are isolated in the Australian parliamentary community. They are isolated in terms of institutions across the world in their not recognising the need for a measure such as this one. They do not live up to their promise of the past, a promise made by leader after leader after leader. Maybe we will have to have another leader before they change their situation here.

The opposition does not live up to the promises, the expectations of their state parties and state parliaments, and they do not live up to their responsibility to the Australian community. Unfortunately, their position is one without a will to embrace this legislation. It is a position where they now have to resort to dishonesty in terms of a changed position, in terms of the arguments they put forward this morning. It is a position which reflects a lack of appreciation of the communities involved here and a keenness to manipulate them, one against the other, for their sordid little interests. It is a lack of understanding of the issue of race. It is an issue with which they have not been able to come to grips. It is an issue with which their current leader has never been able to come to grips.

Time after time over the last 12 months or so, whether it is Mabo, the land fund or issues that arise from day to day—the rights of Aboriginal footballers such as Nicky Winmar or the rights of the Kathy Freemans of the world—the opposition is the one force in the Australian political system that cannot understand the importance, and not just in a social context but in an economic context in our global environment, that the issue of race has for Australia and within Australia.

Our starting point on this side of the parliament is that we are a racially diverse society. We have within our boarders some 240 different ethnic communities. One in four Australians are of a non-English speaking background. We have a society which has over the last 50 years absorbed 5 1/2 million migrants and done so enormously well. The harmony that we have here is not just something we boast about to ourselves; it is something which the rest of the world recognises, through international forums, through the fact that the United Nations held its global diversity conference in Sydney just a few months ago in recognition of the harmonious situation we have here. But in recognising it we and the rest of the world recognise that it is not perfect here.

People are still living as the butts of racial hatred and racial vilification. There are good reasons for governments to take a stand to ensure that the harmony in our society is developed and that people living in our society feel as if they are an equal part of our society and cannot be subjected to racial hatred. As I said, there are social reasons but there are also good economic reasons. An inclusive society is a successful one. A society which can be fragmented because of the issue of race is one that has problems.

I do not think and the government does not think that Australia can afford not to join with other democracies and take a stand on racial vilification. That is where we differ from the opposition. We recognise there is a need—a need other countries have responded to with legislation like this. The extent of the need has been documented quite frequently, inquiry after inquiry. The human rights commission inquiry found hundreds of cases, not thousands, of people who had been subjected to racial vilification. We recognise that in an environment such as that governments have a responsibility in the interests of the dignity of all individuals to send a message.

Chris Puplick, who was here just a few months ago in a historic sense, commented on this issue in the Canberra Times on 5 November 1994. It is worth placing this paragraph on the record to give people a real understanding of what we are talking about. He said:

Since 1989, New South Wales has had comprehensive racial vilification laws in place. They have worked well. They have provided a sound basis for public education programs; they have helped change workplace and institutional attitudes towards racism; they have assisted numerous individuals to do better in their lives and they have in no way impacted upon civil liberties or the vigorous pursuit and practice of free speech in this state.

SPEECH.PARA: An honest statement by former Liberal Senator Chris Puplick. He recognised the fundamental importance of having a two-pronged response—both education and legislation. He has made that very clear as well.

PARA.TAB: There is a need to send a message to individuals in our society, to tackle the issue that Tim Fischer raised in Adelaide in April this year. When talking about the situation in my home state of South Australia, he was concerned with:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . extreme fanaticism of one kind or another in the Australian community and the subtle movement of certain groupings out of Sydney and Melbourne to Adelaide because of perceived differences in certain State legislation, which is affording them a degree of opportunity and there is some evidence of that around that Adelaide has become the new, sadly, the new networking capital for some of this extremism.

Tim Fischer acknowledged the need for governments to send a message and to be consistent about it. The best way to do that is to have national legislation. But it is the National Party tail—Fischer and Katter—who are dragging the Liberal Party from the barrier on this. They know it, and that is why they do not have the will to face up to this issue in the interests of individual Australians and the national good in general. That is why we have had all this moving around this morning.

PARA.TAB: Going back to Chris Puplick, let me say that he recognises a need for legislation and sanctions to provide the foundation for the education programs. Our response as a government has been to recognise that one has to balance, in this particular area, the rights of the victims with the rights of individuals. We do so by our response to this legislation. Our response is not just a legislative one.

The opposition have come in here and said—and they have said to the community as well—`We are going to give $10 million to overcome racism through education campaigns.' That is actually a cutback. This financial year alone we have announced funding in excess of $10 million across the spectrum of government—whether it is the in the school place or workplace. In my own portfolio, I think the figures we counted this morning were somewhere near $9 million alone. Let us also, as we should, toss in HREOC and the programs that I announced just a few days ago—the need for traditional awareness programs and programs in law schools and wherever. These are all specific measures targeted to overcome racism in our society. We are already spending more than the opposition is promising in a very dishonest way. We are spending it in very targeted programs from the school place to the workplace, in the broader community, through the media, to target the issue of racism.

We have got the programs, the money is there—more than they have promised—but when you look at the educative response, you do not get details from the opposition. Ten million dollars—but over how long? Who knows? No-one has been told. By whom? What programs? What areas? Who will be targeted? We have no idea. They have just dragged a figure out of the air and thought they would buy off the communities with that figure. As a consequence, they have come in here and claimed they would rather educate than take the hard decision. We have provided for $9.193 million this financial year in funding for combating racism through education or community relations strategies; $12.99 million, next year. We are spending $21 million over the current two years, as opposed to a $10 million promise from the opposition, with no time limit on it. They are a sham and should be exposed as such.

In terms of the legislation, we recognise we have to protect individuals' rights to freedom of speech. We also recognise that there are already nine, 10 or 11 areas of speech crimes—crimes which attach to speech, speech which reflects socially unacceptable action such as defamation, criminal law, indecency, obscenity, offensive behaviour, sexual harassment, conspiracy, incitement, contempt of court, pornography or false advertising. They are all speech crimes but they are crimes which society and government have recognised need a legislative response because the behaviour that attaches to them is such that we can do without it and it has a deleterious effect on our community.

Racial vilification stands, I think, very squarely within that basket of speech crimes. We recognise we can deal with it in a balanced way. We recognise that the sorts of actions involved here are such that do require a response from the government. The difference between us and the other side is that the consequences of racial vilification and the consequences of this speech are acceptable to them. That is the dividing line between our side and the Democrats, and the opposition on this particular issue. They come to it with a history of deception; they come to it with a bill, which I do not think I could give a better description of than appears in the press statement issued by the Ethnic Communities Council of New South Wales. Angela Chan is an undaunted advocate on behalf of communities, a person who takes no intimidation from any side of parliament. Her description of the opposition's response was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a meaningless sham. It provides for only one remedy against racist attack, a penalty for actually threatening physical harm, and that, of course, is already against the law.

What Angela does not say is that the opposition, in their depiction and framing of it, have produced a bill which is unworkable because of requirements for tests of reasonableness and all sorts of aspects they have tossed into it. Because of the levels of proof required on so many levels—the subjectivity tests, the sole reason requirement—their bill is unprosecutable. It is also different from the New South Wales legislation, legislation which they promised. It is jumbled in wording and is such that it quite clearly warrants the description by the New South Wales Ethnic Communities Council.

PARA.TAB: In terms of our position—this is a pretty important starting point in assessing the government's legislation, contrary to the bland assertions in an endeavour to deceive on the other side—the best description once again comes from New South Wales anti-discrimination commission president, Chris Puplick. He said that he did not believe that either the New South Wales legislation or the federal legislation restricted free speech, that generally the New South Wales laws were more broad ranging and that the federal laws would target specific acts with stiffer penalties. We are talking here about a more measured response than the Greiner measure of New South Wales. If the opposition is too gutless to embrace a measure which Nick Greiner embraced in the broader way then I can understand why he would make comments about the gutlessness of the opposition responses to policy issues.

This is another instance where the opposition, confronted with a national issue in this place, have not had the guts, nor the talent, nor the policy framework with which to respond to it. They do not understand the importance of race. They do not understand society. They do not understand the importance of issues like this. As a consequence, they have dragged out this debate whilst they have been dragged backwards by the National Party. Fisher and Katter have made their decision on this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—You know full well that it is not rubbish, Senator Panizza. Look at our measures. They are tight. They are concise. They go to making threats to cause physical harm and property harm. Incitement is an important aspect of it. Objective standards in respect of such an offence are implanted in our legislation. We do have the civil remedies, remedies which in New South Wales have proven to be most important in terms of the capacity of the commission there to act in a way which can educate and conciliate.

PARA.TAB: So our starting point is that, like the rest of the world, we believe that there is a need for this legislation. We recognise the positiveness of our community but we also recognise that we have to work as a society, government and community together, to overcome racism in this society. We have to do that through education and conciliation as well as criminal sanctions. If you are not serious enough to send a criminal sanction message in this legislation, then the fact that you are not sending that message will be taken by racists in our community as somewhat of a yellow light for their behaviour. Coming from South Australia, I know that pretty well from the sorts of groups we have acting in that state.

We talk about this as a social issue, but do not underestimate the importance of the Australian Parliament sending a message, not just to Australia but to the rest of the world, that we believe that racial vilification is not on. We work in a global environment. We trade with the rest of the world. Our interaction with our region and the rest of the world is not on a financial basis alone. Our interests are developing and growing. They are foreign security, they are social, they are cultural. Our links are very strong. You cannot say to the rest of the world, `We do not mind taking the money but we have something about the issue of race that we are not all that comfortable about.' To be consistent and fair to our future as a nation economically and socially, we have no alternative but to support measured legislation like this. It is a real pity that the opposition has not understood that they also have a responsibility to Australia's economic and social interests.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Clause 1

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1.Clause 1, page 1, line 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

SPEECH.PARA: "1. This Act may be cited as the Racial Tolerance Act 1995.".

The amendment that the Greens are putting up at this point is to change the title from the Racial Hatred Bill to the Racial Tolerance Act 1995. I have already mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage that I believe that to have a Racial Hatred Bill whose avowed motivation is to improve and encourage racial harmony within the community is a contradiction in terms. Especially in the Year of Tolerance, we ought to be looking at how we can promote that in the best possible way. I ask that the committee support the amendment that has been circulated previously in the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government does not support the amendment of the Greens. We do not see it as having any consequence other than diluting the message that we want to very clearly send, that is, the title of this legislation concerns racial vilification and behaviour that should not be tolerated. I think any degree of amendment like the Greens are suggesting would be of no real assistance in terms of sending a very strong message.

—The Australian Democrats find the amendment somewhat strange in view of the intention of the Greens by subsequent amendments to emasculate the bill. I would have to say that, while it has a nice touchy-feely tenor about it, it really does not contribute to the strong message that needs to be sent, I believe, that we care about the victims rather than the perpetrators of racial hatred.

—The coalition does not support the Greens' amendment in this respect. I understand that, for whatever reason or by whichever means we are trying to achieve something, we are all trying to achieve a greater level of tolerance. Nonetheless, the fact is that this bill is dealing with incitement to hatred and we think, therefore, the title is appropriate. If the government had taken up our very wise suggestion of a $10 million education campaign, you might have had a better chance, Senator Chamarette, because we think an education campaign will engender tolerance. Nonetheless, for those reasons we do not support you.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I add another point here. I do not know whether Senator Vanstone was actually in this place when I was making the point in terms of education. Let us acknowledge that the government does have a very broad-ranging education program, through agencies such as my department, through the Prime Minister's department, through HREOC, through ATSIC and through other avenues, for combating racism. They are diverse, multipronged levels of programs targeting different parts of our society. Let us put on the record once again that this year, 1994-95, we spent $9.193 million. That was in the last financial year. This financial year we are spending $12.99 million to combat racism. A promise of $10 million is a cutback.
—Additional.

—You have not said `additional'. Your promise is not additional. You cannot make policy on the run like that. Your promise is to spend $10 million to combat racism. We are spending $12.99 million. I would like to know where the $3 million cutback is going to come from.

—I have two comments to make. In passing, I will respond to Senator Spindler's comment. He said that the flagged amendments, which were to remove the criminal offences created by this bill, emasculated the bill and that this was proof that the Democrats somehow cared more about the victims than the Greens if we removed the criminal sanctions. I would like to clarify for Senator Spindler that the real access for victims in this situation is via the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. They are the parts that we are proposing to retain and support.

PARA.TAB: It is quite one thing to argue that you care about the victims and that you somehow want to punish other people as a way of caring about victims of oppression. There is a flaw in that logic. There is no question that there may well be some victims of oppression who call for harsh justice to be applied to their oppressors. However, whether that demonstrates more care for their concerns, when you cannot deal with the problem in a proactive and preventive way, is a difficulty. I believe that it is in the civil remedies that any real address of the problems of victims is seen.

As the whole matter of education was raised, I want to ask the minister a question about it. There is very little mention in this bill of education. I searched for it and eventually found it in the explanatory memorandum. I was discouraged to see that the emphasis was primarily on educating people about this legislation, if it were to be passed. Having accepted that the numbers will preclude any change in the name of the bill from the Racial Hatred Bill to the Racial Tolerance Bill, the absence of any educative measure in it or the absence of any real concern that we show tolerance and respect for a diversity of views mean that it would not be appropriate to have the bill's name changed either, as Senator Vanstone has said.

I regret that the spirit of the bill, if this is what it is, is not capable of being reflected in the title more accurately. It looks as though we are promoting racial hatred by calling it the Racial Hatred Bill. Perhaps we could mention opposition to racial hatred. The point I am making—I do not want the minister to forget my question about education—is that the positive underlying motivation, if there is one, is not being reflected in the title.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill is an amendment to the Racial Discrimination Act. As a consequence, the activities that are being targeted will not just be the subject of promotion in terms of the aspects of this legislation that are important. The function will be given to HREOC. HREOC already has a number of programs, as part of an overall government response in this area, which target racism in schools. They are reinforced by various programs run by educational authorities. It also provides resources to help employers deal with racism in the workplace.

PARA.TAB: As well as the ongoing responsibility of HREOC to educate and raise awareness in terms of the issue of racism and to combat it through diverse programs, we also have a commitment to conducting a public education program to promote this legislation. The promotion of this legislation and the aims and objectives of it is also an important part of helping to combat racism. We do not miss your point. In respect of the departments I mentioned earlier, most of our programs are about combating racism and raising awareness to overcome it through education. That involves $12.99 million in this financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points in response to what Senator Chamarette said. I know that it is possible to lodge complaints with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, but the importance attached to here is the clarity and strength of the message to the community and possible perpetrators. Hopefully, there will be a deterrent effect when sanctions are on the books. It is a statement by this parliament that we as a nation make. We back it with sanctions which, as I said, are likely to have a deterrent effect.

PARA.TAB: I also have a question about education. The minister stated a couple of times that there are education programs. To what extent do these programs simply consist of pamphlets, posters and other written material that is distributed? To what extent are there more active programs? To what extent do we have an actual strategy which addresses how we will combat racism? To what extent is this particular message actually incorporated in schools' curricula and how is it handled in the education system?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thanks very much for that question, Senator Spindler. I think the thrust of your question is spot on—you have to combat it in an interactive way. Putting pamphlets out is one way, but probably the best value of putting pamphlets out is to alert victims to their rights. But you really need to take the education process a couple of steps back and work in communities, the school place, the workplace and so on.

PARA.TAB: For instance, we have a community relations agenda. The major purpose of the grants under that agenda is to do what you are talking about—work on a community level, whether it is in a school place or interact with new technology. A great degree of innovativeness has been shown by people who have applied for grants under the CRA to involve both new technology and communities, as I said, from the school place to the workplace and the general community. So that has to be, I think, much of the thrust of this.

It is a detailed process, a long one and an exhaustive one. The simple response will be for departments to say, `Let's put out a pamphlet', but that does not have the effect and we recognise that it does not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a point of clarification for the minister in respect of that $10 million education campaign which you seek to portray as less than your existing funding—and you want to see where the cuts are coming from. I repeat what you have already been told once: it is a commitment to additional funding. You can shake your head, minister, as much as you like. Maybe the word `additional' has not been put before it and maybe you feel that would have made it clearer, but it was always clear in our mind that it is a commitment to additional funding. If you didn't know it then, you do now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On this particular issue, Senator Vanstone, I don't accept your expression of policy. Your party has consistently said that you will spend $10 million. Now you are saying you will spend an additional $10 million, without having gone back to the leadership, without having gone back to your shadow Treasurer, to determine whether that is the case or not.

PARA.TAB: Your performance on this issue has been one of shifting sands time and time again, day in day out. You can't be trusted on it. Unless we get a commitment from your leadership involving your shadow Treasurer and finance spokesman, then we won't believe that that is the case. Up until now everyone has been told that you will spend $10 million—nothing new about it, nothing new at all. So don't make policy on the run in an attempt to deceive again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you should withdraw the comment that I am attempting to deceive the parliament now by making a statement that is untrue. I am making a statement that is true. Whether you believe it or not is entirely up to you.
—You should withdraw that, Senator Bolkus.
—Sorry?
—I ask you to withdraw that.
—Why?
—Because it is an attack on the Senator.
—I will just ask for clarification. Why should I be asked to withdraw an assertion that there is an attempt to deceive? There is nothing unparliamentary about that.
—Because it is an improper motive imputed to Senator Vanstone.
—You're being a bit rich.
—Maybe but I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw.
—I am glad that the minister has withdrawn. I think it was quite a scurrilous statement. He knew that it was a falsehood.

—On a point of order: Senator Short is imputing a motive to me. I honestly believed, on the record, that Senator Vanstone was creating policy. That was an honest belief. There was no motive of mischief or scurrilousness. I ask that that imputation of motive also be withdrawn.

—On the point of order: that may have been the case, Madam Chair, when the minister first raised it—and his ignorance in that respect is entirely his fault and not mine. But having had it pointed out to him, that it was a mistake, he then proceeded to get up and assert that he knew better than I, better than Senator Short and others, what the coalition's policy was. He got up and asserted that, having been told the truth, having had the opportunity to inform his mind—and that was scurrilous; I quite agree with Senator Short's assertion.

—On the point of order again: my motivation was based on my understanding of Liberal Party policy. In a press statement of 7 March 1995 there was an explicit commitment to a $10 million multi-pronged education campaign. There was no reference to the word `additional'. It was with that background, and with the knowledge that there is no promise of additional funds, that I made that assertion. What Senator Vanstone has done is confirm my appreciation that the complaint is about my motivation being scurrilous or mischievous. It was not. It was based on a clear understanding of the Liberal Party's commitment in this area—a commitment that we had before today.
—From my understanding of the meaning of the word `scurrilous', I would ask you, Senator Short, to withdraw and phrase it differently.

—I will not press it, except to say that it was a quite outrageous statement. I say to the minister that Senator Vanstone was absolutely right in what she said. I represent in this chamber the shadow Treasurer and the shadow Minister for Finance and I give an unequivocal commitment that the coalition's decision in relation to the $10 million is that it is additional expenditure. There is not a shadow of doubt, and there never has been, in the coalition's mind and in the minds of the many ethnic communities with which we have consulted on this matter that it was anything other than that.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 2 to 4—by leave—taken together.<

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that these clauses are extremely important. I have already addressed some of the concerns about having criminal sanctions in a bill that purports to promote racial harmony and deal with racial vilification in a positive way. I think there are many questions relating to the implications of these three clauses that need to be asked.

PARA.TAB: I am opposed to clauses 2 to 4. I ask the minister what his understanding is of the clash between the state offences that are already covered under the offences of threat of damage to property or threat of harm to persons and this legislation. My understanding is that there are two possible problems. One is that the penalties outlined in these clauses would be lesser than those available in all the states. If these laws were to operate in such a way that racist violence carried a lesser penalty than non-racist violence, I think it would present a significant problem which the federal government has created.

The second problem relates to the interaction between state and federal laws. I would like the minister to explain whether these federal laws will operate in addition to the state laws? Will they operate independently of state laws? How will those two laws interact?

Just to spell out the example for that: let us assume that somebody has committed an offence of threatening somebody and there is a choice of prosecution under federal laws because there is a racist component. If the case is not able to be proved and, therefore, that offence lapses, will that person then be charged under the state laws that do not have a racist component which may or may not be substantiated? It is that interactive effect I am interested in.

The third point is, who will enforce it? Are the state police forces being asked to enforce not only the state penalties but also the federal laws? How will that operate in terms of training and education for police forces? What will be the position of individual state police forces in respect of the competing laws?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The starting point of my response is to alert you to new section 61 in clause 4, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Part is not intended to exclude or limit the concurrent operation of any law of a State or Territory.

Also, new section 18F on the last page of the bill states that state and territory laws will not be affected. They will have concurrent operation. Administration will be through state police forces. Under the double jeopardy law, we can give an assurance that people will not be pinned twice for the same conduct.

PARA.TAB: In terms of awareness programs and whatever with state police forces, we do actually have a mechanism in place nationally through a body which is in the business of working with police to raise cultural awareness. That body is one that I have had some contact with. It is a body which does perform some work in this area.

If there is anything further expected in terms of awareness courses with state agencies, I will let you know, Senator Chamarette. But it will be implemented in the normal course of operations by state agencies, as happens quite often with drug laws and like where there are both criminal and state offences involved which could attach to a particular form of conduct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for clarifying that, though what it will mean in practical terms might be a little more difficult to assess. I would like the minister's response to how this particular federal law conflicts with state principles that I know operate in Western Australia—that is, imprisonment is a penalty of last resort and not to be used as a penalty of first resort? Will that put state jurisdictions in some kind of doubt as to how they should deal with those offences?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of criminal offences federally and those administered by the state judicial system, my understanding is that it is the considerations brought to the task under the relevant legislation which determine what the judicial officer's decision will be. I think you will find a degree of synchronisation between both state and federal objectives when it comes to sentencing—and that, of course, is to use the penalty of imprisonment as a last resort.

PARA.TAB: I think that is something that has been driving at federal sentencing policy. In the instances you referred to, and because of your reference to it, I presume that is what drives state sentencing policy in this particular area in your state. I am only going by your words so if you want to change that, please do. We do not see imprisonment as being the first resort. It is very much part of a process, and the judicial officer will have discretion to look at alternatives and hopefully use them as a preference.
Question put:
That clauses 2 to 4 be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Clauses negatived.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH AUTHORITIES (AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY PAY-ROLL TAX) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 June, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the coalition, I rise to speak on the Commonwealth Authorities (Australian Capital Territory Pay-roll Tax) Bill. The legislation is supported by the coalition. Essentially, the bill is intended to rectify an oversight that occurred at the time self-government was proclaimed for the Australian Capital Territory.

PARA.TAB: It is somewhat surprising that it has taken nearly eight years to identify this oversight and to take action to resolve the situation, particularly given that taxation revenue was at issue. The bill applies only to those Commonwealth authorities who, immediately before the commencement of the ACT payroll tax regime, were registered as employers or had an application for registration pending under the payroll tax regime of the Commonwealth or of a state or territory. It will have no application to other Commonwealth authorities.

The bill will create a payroll tax liability for these authorities which, as I have already stated, were technically not subject to ACT payroll tax liability because of general exempting provisions in an act or under regulation. These provisions will place the payroll tax treatment of certain Commonwealth authorities operating in the ACT on a similar footing to those Commonwealth authorities operating in the states or in the Northern Territory.
Clause 6 of the bill is designed to protect various collections of payroll tax by the ACT government. As stated in the explanatory memorandum and supplementary memorandum:

SPEECH.PARA: Those Commonwealth authorities that have paid ACT pay-roll tax before Royal Assent to the Bill will not be able to recover the payments.

The clause is necessary to protect the revenue of the ACT. Were this clause not to be included in the legislation, a Commonwealth authority which had paid ACT payroll tax under the mistaken belief that it had a legal objection would have been able to have an action to recover the tax erroneously paid. The ACT revenue base would have been detrimentally affected and the ACT government would most likely have sought recompense from the Commonwealth. Clause 6 will make such an administrative roundabout unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased that the government has picked up the coalition's concerns in respect of the wording of clause 6, and the coalition will be supporting the government's proposed amendment. This amendment will make clear that, where a payment has been made by a relevant Commonwealth authority, the fact that the payment was not previously required by law is not relevant.
