With the redrafted clause 6, the coalition supports the passage of this bill and supports the provisions in the bill which prevent the Commonwealth authorities from claiming back from the ACT government the amounts paid in payroll tax from 1 August 1987 to date. The bill is clearly long overdue, and the coalition is pleased to see its passage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I want to table the supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment to be moved to this bill, which I understand is acceptable to the opposition. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.
Amendment (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
Clause 6, page 3, lines 15 to 18 (inclusive), omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Payments made before commencement of this Act

PARA.TAB: "6. If a Commonwealth authority made any payments before the commencement of this Act on the basis that the payments were payable under the pay-roll tax law of the Australian Capital Territory, the Commonwealth authority cannot recover those payments.".
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Schacht) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 1) 1995SOCIAL SECURITY (NON-BUDGET MEASURES) LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate on Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 resumed from 21 June, and debate on Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 resumed from 8 March, on motions by Senator Cook and Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I was not here when the legislation was first called on is that this government still has not given me a copy of the guidelines for one of the schedules and I was up in my office waiting for them to come through. They were promised to me and I was sitting there waiting, so I do have a legitimate excuse for not having been here. Here we are debating this bill at a lunch time and I am still waiting in my office for the guidelines for a bill that has come before the house. I think the government could have got their act together and got those guidelines to me.

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 will make amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 and associated pieces of legislation. Overall, the coalition is supportive of these amendments. However, there are basically four areas which have raised concern. They are: firstly, schedule 3 and, in particular, the amendment to the amendment bill relating to the Italian international social security agreement; secondly, schedule 4, which relates to the clarification of the qualification requirements for the disabilities support pension and the disability wage supplement; thirdly, schedule 14 on the issue of the native title rights and interests which are not to be taken into account when applying the asset test in the act; and, fourthly, schedule 16 and the issue of split compensation settlements and the application of provisions to claimants and assessment of periodic and lump sums.

In relation to these areas the coalition has had representations from a number of groups, including the Welfare Rights Centre and the Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition. The Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee has also considered these amendments and the representations further, as well as giving the department the opportunity to justify the amendments being proposed.

With respect to schedule 3, the amendment to the bill relates to Australia's social security agreement with Italy. We will be supporting this amendment, which is basically a technical one posing no real changes. This amendment will clear up the current situation which has arisen out of the new agreement between the Australian and the Italian governments not having been ratified in Italy, due to the delays in the Italian legislative process. This has resulted in the old agreement remaining in force. However, it is no longer a scheduled international social security agreement under section 1208 of the principal act. Therefore, because the old agreement has been repealed and the new agreement has not entered into force, social security payments made on the basis of the agreement and out of consolidated revenue have not been validly made. The amendment will correct this situation.

Schedule 4 proposes that the rules be altered to clarify the qualification requirements in relation to the disability support pension. This proposed narrowing of eligibility raises some cause for concern, particularly in regard to a lack of energy or motivation and the extent to which this factor should be related to a physical, intellectual or psychiatric impairment of 20 per cent or more. The concern raised in the committee hearings is the possibility that people who have a lack of energy or motivation as the natural consequence of a long-term illness or pain could be excluded from payment and access to the disability reform package program.

The department dealt with this by saying that each case would be assessed individually and that people who generally had a lack of motivation as a result of an illness or disability would not be excluded from payment. The department has also pointed out that, overall, this is intended to be legislation to benefit recipients and that, if there is an ambiguity in the act with no contrary intention, then it will generally be interpreted in favour of the client.

The other cause for concern was raised in relation to people with head injuries and psychiatric problems. With the tightening up of the act, it was argued, this could create some problems in assessing these sorts of cases where the Commonwealth medical officers deemed valid cases not to be entitled to the pensions. In discussions with the department and the minister's office, it was agreed about three days ago that guidelines would be drawn up to give direction or some indicative guidelines to the CMOs. That was discussed approximately three days ago, the shadow minister received the draft yesterday and had some comments to make, and the corrected draft was to be faxed back to him or to my office. That is what I was waiting for in my office, to actually have a look at those guidelines before we got onto the debate. Regrettably, I have not had time to look at them, but what is intended is that these guidelines will be inserted into the AGHS guidelines for CMOs, directing them to refer the matter to an appropriate specialist in certain circumstances. I seek leave to table and to have incorporated in Hansard those guidelines.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: "DSS requires AGHS to seek a report from a psychiatrist or psychologist where:-
the psychiatric/psychological condition/acquired brain injury is the claimant's primary medical condition; and
there is an unclear psychiatric/psychological/neurological diagnosis; and/or
the person has not had a previous psychiatric/psychological/neurological assessment or received treatment from such a specialist or is unable to obtain a report from their treating specialist.
DSS may waive this requirement where exceptional circumstances exist, such as remoteness".

TALK.START.PARA: —The schedule 14 amendment has also generated questions regarding the making of native title rights and interests exempt from the provisions of the assets test. It is proposed to treat native title interests in a similar way to other exempt assets, such as life interests. However, it has been argued the amendments might give someone an advantage, because of their race or culture, over some other person in a similar situation. I guess the basic question was: why separate the native title from everything else? The department responded by saying that, unlike other similar life interests, native title interests in an asset are not realisable as a source of funds to provide an individual or individuals with support, as there could never be any question of selling the property. This is because native title interests are community based in nature. It has also been pointed out that any income derived from a native title right or interest would be assessable under the income test.

PARA.TAB: In response to other concerns, the department also says that land obtained under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 will not be excluded from assets tests. This is also the case for land obtained under the land acquisition fund.

The third area of concern for the coalition is in relation to schedule 16. Schedule 16 comprises four distinct initiatives, two of which are at issue: compensation and split settlements and the application of provisions to claimants as well as recipients. Compensation is where two or more lump sum payments made in respect of one disease, injury or condition sustained in one event are treated as one lump sum compensation payment for the purposes of the compensation recovery provisions. There is a 50 per cent rule applied to this.

An amendment to these compensation provisions in the act was also sought by the government in 1993. However, as was clarified in the legislation committee on 23 June, the new amendments are different from the one sought two years ago. Even though they are different, the coalition is still concerned that this could undermine compensation payments in regard to non-economic elements.

The Welfare Rights Centre and other groups have spoken out strongly against this amendment, saying that it undermines legal settlements reached between parties recognising the injuries and loss suffered by a client—and which are not related to a person's lost earnings—and that they will be required to use this money to support themselves rather than using it for basic infrastructure costs associated with their disability or injury.

A concern was also expressed that this amendment aimed at preventing double-dipping and people ripping off the system will affect a much larger group of people than was initially intended and that it could affect people who are genuinely entitled to a full payment. In response to this, in an amendment to a document called Guide to the administration of the Social Security Act part J: disregarding payments of compensation, the department said:

SPEECH.PARA: In some cases, the application of the 50 per cent rule to calculate the preclusion period may lead to a result that is harsh or unjust.

The department then went on to say that, if the economic loss component of a lump sum is considerably less than 50 per cent, this is a factor to consider in deciding whether special circumstances exist. The department provided the coalition with a copy of the letter stating that the new guideline will be inserted in the guide in addition to the existing guidelines relating to disregarding payments of compensation.

PARA.TAB: The second issue of concern to the coalition in relation to schedule 16 is the application of compensation provisions to claimants as well as recipients. Under the compensation preclusion provisions of the act, a person will not receive income support while they have the benefit of a compensation payment for loss of income. Currently, a decision must be made first as to whether a person is qualified for the payment even if it is obvious by the person's circumstances that the person will be precluded from the payment because of the compensation preclusion provisions. The amendment has the effect that the compensation preclusion provisions may be applied to a person first and they may be excluded from a payment without a decision made as to their qualification.

This amendment is of concern to the Welfare Rights Centre. The centre says that there have been cases when a person has applied for payment and their qualification has not been determined but where they have been refused on the basis of the preclusion rules. The person has then appealed to the SSAT and the AAT and it has been found that the decision to refuse payment was incorrect, but, as no assessment as to qualification has been made, the Department of Social Security continues to assess qualification.

To ameliorate this situation, the coalition, on behalf of the Welfare Rights Centre, obtained an agreement in writing from the minister. The minister agreed that the following amendments would be made: any client who remains affected by the compensation preclusion provisions after a review will be informed in writing of their right to have their qualification assessed before any SSAT appeal is heard; and any appeal to the SSAT should simultaneously deal with both the payment and eligibility factors.

As the bill was delayed until the spring session, the government has now incorporated this amendment into the bill. The amendment provides that, if a person's claim for a pension fails because of the operation of the compensation preclusion provisions, if that person applies to the SSAT for review of the compensation preclusion decision and if the person requests the secretary to assess his or her qualification for payment, then the secretary must make the qualification assessment.

This is acceptable; however, it does not provide for the person to be advised of their right to have their qualification assessed if they are appealing and in the committee stage of the bill I will be pursuing what undertakings the minister will make as to the way in which clients will be advised.

I have pointed out the areas of concern the coalition has about the bill. It is the coalition's view, however, that the department has answered those concerns, particularly with the amendments in relation to split settlements, outlining the discretion available in making decisions relating to this. The coalition will be supporting the amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 and the government's amendments to the amendment bill. However, we will be monitoring the effect of these amendments and, if the department's assurances are not found to be correct, the coalition will be demanding that the government act to address any shortcomings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. Looking first at the non-budget measures bill, the Democrats acknowledge that there are a number of very welcome measures being introduced through the bill. Whilst many of these measures incur a negligible cost to the government, the benefits to the people involved will be significant. For example, the bill provides that mature-age allowance recipients can continue to claim Commonwealth fringe benefits for six months after they commence employment, that disability support pensioners can retain their fringe benefits for 12 months after they lose their pension because of income and it provides employment and education entry payments to carer pensioners.

PARA.TAB: On top of this, the bill also provides for the extension of the mobility allowance to handicapped people who are in receipt of either a newstart, jobsearch or youth training allowance. Finally, the bill provides that the ordinary one-week waiting period for people claiming sickness allowance can be waived where the person is in a position of financial hardship.

The financial impact of each of these measures will be negligible but the benefits to the people involved will be substantial. The Democrats are pleased to see these amendments and will certainly be supporting them.

I would like to turn to the amendments in the bill which relate to the position of people on a carer pension when they travel overseas. The amendments the government is putting forward will allow a carer pensioner to accompany the person they care for overseas for up to three months in any one calendar year and continue to receive their pension.

In the majority of cases, carer pensioners are looking after a person on either a disability support pension or an age pension. Both these pensions continue payments for up to 12 months while the recipient is overseas and, in some cases, for an even longer period. So the practical effect of the government's proposal will be that, if a carer remains overseas for more than three months, then they will lose their pension. At the same time, however, the person they are caring for can continue to receive their pension for a further nine months. This seems to be a ridiculous anomaly.

Alternatively, if the carer wants to keep on receiving their pension, the disability support or age pensioner will have to return with them from overseas within the three-month time limit. This problem has been increased by the phasing out of the wife pension this year as it is expected that about 25 per cent of wife pensioners will transfer over to a carer pension.

I do acknowledge that providing three months portability for carer pensioners is a step in the right direction. However, the Democrats believe that portability for 12 months would be more appropriate, and, surely, I do not have to argue the sense of that proposal.

At the Senate inquiry when we were discussing the possibility of the amendment the department said, in answer to a question, that there would be a very small number involved, so the cost would be very small. I signal now that I will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to provide that a carer pension can continue to be paid for up to 12 months while they are overseas with the person they care for.

I turn now to what was one of the more contentious measures in this bill, and that is the section relating to the qualification criteria for the sole parent pension. Under the current legislation, to qualify for a sole parent pension, a person must be living separately and apart from their partner. The government apparently believes that under a strict interpretation this could allow people to receive the pension when their partner was away from home only temporarily. The original explanatory memorandum to the bill gave as examples people who were `on holidays, work or study commitments or during short-term domestic disputes'.

The Democrats were disappointed that the government chose to include domestic disputes within these amendments. In particular, we were concerned about the possible impact that this proposed change could have had on women seeking to leave violent domestic situations. We also believe that it would have been unreasonable to expect the Department of Social Security to be able to determine which separations following a domestic dispute were of a short-term nature and which were not. Further, having counselled many women who have been the victims of domestic violence, I know that it is a sad fact of life that many women remain in violent households because they fear they will have no financial support if they leave. The Democrats were gravely concerned that the proposed changes would have only increased that doubt.

In line with our deep concern over this issue, in question time on 1 March this year, I asked Senator Crowley whether or not the government was conscious of the effect the proposed changes could have on women seeking to leave domestic violence. In response to my representation to her, Senator Crowley said that she would seek further clarification of the government's position either in the explanatory memorandum or during the debate on the legislation. I am pleased to see that, in line with the commitment given in response to my question, the government has now removed the words `during short-term domestic disputes' from the explanatory memorandum.
The government has also added a clause to the memorandum which I would like to read into Hansard. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no intention in the amendments to adversely affect people separating in circumstances that involve domestic violence. The amendments will not change the current admission procedures for sole parent pension that deal with situations involving, or potentially involving, domestic violence.
I certainly welcome the addition of this clause in the memorandum and I thank the government for recognising the concerns and acting appropriately and swiftly on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995. I want only to speak very briefly to this legislation as I believe my colleague Senator Lees will expand a little more. I want to concentrate my remarks on the amendments made by schedule 16 of the bill. These amendments deal with the way in which the Department of Social Security treats compensation payments. At the moment, for ease of administration, the Social Security Act assumes that, where any loss of income component can be identified in a compensation payment, 50 per cent of that payment has been made for loss of income. The department then divides this amount by average weekly earnings to calculate the number of weeks a person is to be precluded from social security support.

While I recognise the administrative benefits of this 50 per cent rule, I still believe that the department should be able to look more closely at individual compensation payments. Even if it is the case that the department loses as much as it gains by the application of this rule, the effect on an individual who may only have received, say, 25 per cent of his or her compensation payment for economic loss could be devastating. The Democrats have always acknowledged the problem of compensation payment construction designed to disguise the true nature of a payment and thereby cost-shift onto the Commonwealth.

The bill before us today seeks to allow DSS, when calculating any preclusion period by means of the 50 per cent rule, to combine two or more lump sum compensation payments which are made for the one compensatable event. The aim of this amendment is to reduce the scope for any sort of artificial payment structuring. The Democrats recognise that this proposal is different from the proposal put forward by the government last year. Our position has always been, however, that we could not support a proposal to address the problem of payment construction which would disadvantage any compensation recipients—people who, it must be remembered, have been the victims of an industrial or motor accident. As such we will not be supporting schedule 16 of this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will only be speaking about one particular section of one of these bills, schedule 4 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1), looking in particular at the modification of the qualification criteria for the disability support pension and the disability wages supplement. I wish to stress here that the Democrats will be continuing their opposition to these changes and will be opposing them in the committee stage. I do acknowledge the work that has been going on behind the scenes to at least get some guidelines. However, on reading the draft that we have had tabled before us today I still see huge problems for the most disadvantaged group of people in our community.

PARA.TAB: I believe, and the Democrats believe, that it is time to draw the line. We have tightened eligibility again and again to the point where these changes will mean that people with significant disabilities are going to miss out on the option of a disability support pension. I am not alone in this. The Democrats and, indeed, the Senate committee have been contacted by a wide range of organisations representing people with disabilities—the Head Injury Council of Australia, the Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition, the National Federation of Blind Citizens, the Uniting Church, the Welfare Rights Centre and a number of community legal centres. They all said the same thing, that these changes are likely to severely disadvantage a group of already disadvantaged people. So we need to look here at the continuing battle between the major parties as to who is really looking after the battlers.

Here we have a concrete example of what they do in legislation to a group of battlers and we really have to ask, `How much more difficult can we make it for these people?' Time and time again we sit through debates on social security in this place, and time and time again we see the rules for income support tightened and tightened. And we then wonder why our charities are so overburdened with people who cannot make ends meet.

One of the most disappointing factors in all of this is that it is going to go largely unnoticed. It is not a high profile community issue. Indeed, it is probably going to make scarcely a ripple in any news broadcast anywhere in Australia because it is a very small number of people that we are talking about and it is a group of people that do not have a lot of power and do not have ready access to the media to stand up and to really make a noise about what is happening to them.

I would argue that this is a very real issue about fairness and equity and it is something that the government fairly hastily brought before us as a result of very fair decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Both the government and the coalition know that these decisions are rarely in the public arena and they can get away with changing these rules without any notice whatsoever.

What effectively is being done here is that the changes modify the meaning of the term `continuing inability to work', which is one of the qualification criteria for receiving the DSP. The amendments provide, firstly, that an applicant is not eligible for a disability support pension if their impairment is not by itself sufficient to prevent them from doing any work and, secondly, that an applicant's inability to work or retrain must result directly from the impairment and any consequential results of the impairment will not be considered.

These amendments have to be placed in context. When the disability support pension was introduced in 1991, as the replacement for the invalid pension, the Democrats and a number of groups representing people with disabilities expressed grave concerns about the government's plan to minimise the relevance of non-medical factors in assessing a person's continuing inability to work. I believed then and, indeed, I still believe that it is wrong to exclude non-medical, socioeconomic factors from decisions, when looking at access to the DSP. I think those concerns have been vindicated by the practical operation of the DSP assessment processes.

Although it is very difficult to ascertain exactly what is going on, it does appear that the department and the Commonwealth medical officers regularly disregard psychological and other factors in assessing whether or not a person meets that minimum 20 per cent impairment level. This has made it difficult for people with a psychological condition, or some other non-medical, socioeconomic handicap, on top of their disability, to get the DSP.

The attitude of the CMOs and the DSS has been criticised by the AAT and the SSAT. The tribunals have shown some degree of flexibility in dealing with the issue of whether particular consequences of an applicant's impairment, such as poor motivation or antisocial behaviour, can be taken into account when there is no medical evidence suggesting an underlying psychiatric condition.

The government says that it wants to bring consistency into its policy on the DSP and these amendments are clearly a direct response to decisions made by the tribunals. But these amendments want to exclude any recognition of skill levels. It is technically possible under these amendments to exclude virtually any person with an impairment from the DSP, unless that person has a clear and almost total inability to function.

The consequences of these amendments is that people with disabilities are going to be channelled into JSA and newstart. The government can dress that up in any language it likes but, at the end of the day, that means it is cheaper for government. It will have to pay out less money to people with disabilities, not just because of the level of payments but also because a lot of people in this category are not going to be able to fulfil the requirements to keep jumping through the hoops and to stay on the treadmill that continues their income support. I state again that it is going to further disadvantage a group of people who are already significantly disadvantaged.

The disability reform package evaluation carried out this year found that DSP recipients received more intensive training assistance more quickly than people with disabilities on JSA and newstart. As the Sydney Welfare Rights Centre pointed out in its submission to the Senate's community affairs committee, narrowing the qualification requirements of DSP might reduce the number of people receiving DSP but it does not reduce the number of people who need long-term income support payments. All it does is shift a group of people off DSP, and onto the unemployment queue on a long-term basis where they will lose priority in accessing appropriate labour market programs and will have to compete for the general labour market programs. And, what is more, they will be forced to comply with JSA and newstart requirements.

Welfare rights and disability organisations argue that there are many people who just do not quite make that 20 per cent medical impairment which, when combined with other factors consequential upon their impairment, makes them unemployable. It makes little sense to exclude these people and these factors from the assessment process and then basically channel them off into unemployment benefits and, I would argue, for many of them, onto the charity system in the longer term. JSA and newstart now carry penalties for breaches of certain requirements. It is also placing these people, particularly those who are likely to have behavioural difficulties, at risk of losing their income support altogether.

Organisations representing people with a psychiatric disability are particularly concerned, as the Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition pointed out. I acknowledge the work that has gone on behind the scenes for some guidelines for the Commonwealth medical officers, but I still believe that there will be a significant number of people that these do not pick up. It seems to the Democrats that this exercise is really nothing more than a cost cutting and cost shifting exercise, at the expense of people with disabilities.

The government appears to believe it has a problem with a number of decisions—I stress, a very small number—of the AAT and the SSAT to overturn decisions made by the department and therefore give people access to the DSP. However, the problem does not appear to be a large one. It is certainly the case now that the solution to this so-called problem really does lie in better assessment processes and not in the legislation we have before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill will give effect to a number of non-budget measures. It seeks to amend the Social Security Act 1991, the National Health Act 1953, the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990 and the Social Security (Budget and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Act 1993.

PARA.TAB: What we have in the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill is yet another motley collection of disparate provisions which are certain to reinforce the perception of social security legislation as cumbersome, complex and, to many, incomprehensible. The bill, particularly clause 14, as it currently stands relating to the sole parent pension, will set the cause of plain English back a millennium.

To understand the complex nature of the bill, I want to run through some of the areas of social security that will be affected by these amendments: carer's pension; disability support pension; mobility allowance; partner allowance; family payment; sickness allowance; attendance requirements for JSA and NSA; training supplement; activity agreements; disclosure of social security information; the power to collect information; decisions by the minister being subject to internal review or review by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal; debt creation provisions of the Social Security Act; the National Health Act; issues relating to health care card concessions; data-matching program; and the telephone allowance, et cetera. It concerns me that we are at the point where we are debating these two bills cognately, when even in one bill there are a whole lot of issues relating to changes to social security.

The coalition will not be opposing the vast majority of these measures. However, we do have some residual concerns in a number of areas. We will be moving an amendment to remedy one of those areas and we will maintain opposition to a number of others which we do not consider to be in the best interests of social security clients.

We will move an amendment to ensure that certain of the secretary's decision-making powers are subject to an appropriate level of parliamentary scrutiny. The effect of these amendments will be to subject the secretary's decision-making powers under division 20A to waive particular classes of debt to disallowance. This was an issue that was commented on by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and I would have thought that the department and the minister would have taken this issue up. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee is a multi-party committee which assiduously looks at legislation to ensure that it does not infringe the rights of individuals or take away the rights of the parliament. The committee made a comment and, for some reason, the government has chosen to ignore it.

The coalition opposes clauses 23 to 26, 38 and 39 and division 18 of the bill. Clauses 23 to 26 would render decisions of the employment secretary not to approve a particular person's participation in a vocational training course or labour market program for the purposes of training supplement payment non-reviewable. The coalition does not believe that this particular extension of the range of non-reviewable decisions under the act is in the best interest of social security clients.

The coalition also will be opposing division 18 of the bill. It contains a range of provisions which purport to clarify the concept of payability under the Social Security Act 1991. The law, as it currently stands, requires a positive determination by the department before payability of benefits ceases. These provisions would change that and have the effect, amongst other things, of raising debts against clients who have complied with all their obligations under the act. Clients will be forced to bear an unreasonable onus which should properly be borne by the department: the onus to process information in a timely fashion and not allow clients to be prejudiced by any laxity within the department.

Overall, the bulk of this bill may fairly be seen as neither controversial nor involving significant financial impacts. The concerns that we seek to address, whilst few in number, are by no means trivial. Accordingly, our intention to move amendments in some cases and to oppose provisions in others is grounded in the coalition's commitment to ensure that the social security legislation is both accessible, comprehensible and subject to the appropriate level of public scrutiny.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans. I refer to the government's willingness to table advice from the Solicitor-General only two days ago confined to the issue of the validity of the mechanisms proposed for making legal aid payments available to Dr Lawrence. Prior to the cabinet decision to provide such legal aid, did the government seek any advice from the Solicitor-General as to whether it was legal or proper to do so? If not, why not? And will the government identify and table any other legal advice on this matter obtained prior to and not after the event?

—Mr President, it is not the practice of any government to make publicly available any legal advice received from its advisers, whether it is the Solicitor-General or anybody else, in the course of the normal decision-making process of government. That is a practice that has been observed. It has been so long since you have been in office you have no doubt forgotten, but it is a practice that has been observed by every government from time immemorial. It is part of the norma confidentiality of cabinet process and governmental process.

PARA.TAB: The particular advice that was tabled by me yesterday was prepared specifically, as was stated in the accompanying statement, for the purpose of explaining publicly what the legal basis on which the government acted was. The original cabinet decision was one to provide for a one-line appropriation, preceded by payment out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance, and that had been the subject of discussion, as you would expect, between legal advisers in AGs and the Department of Finance as to the appropriate basis for the payment, among a number of options and alternatives which do exist, including, for example, 34A of the Audit Act. The view was taken that a one-line appropriation was the way to go, and that that would be specifically transparent and open to parliamentary scrutiny.

At that stage, particular consideration had not been given to the possible impact of section 48 of the constitution and issues that were subsequently raised in public debate a few weeks later. When that issue was raised in the public debate, some closer legal attention was given to whether in fact there was a problem with a one-line appropriation. It was thought by the Solicitor-General, whose advice was then sought—and only then, just a few days ago—that there might be a problem if the matter was just left in terms of reliance on a one-line appropriation next April or May, with money being paid out of the advance now, because of the case of Brown v. West which seemed to be saying that any particular payments made to members of parliament or ministers needed to have some firmer statutory basis for them. His advice to us was essentially that there would be no problem at all about the one-line appropriation itself supporting the payment, but there might be a question mark raised, litigated, as to whether it could be payable under the Advance to the Minister for Finance—just based on that and that alone.

However, his further advice was that the Parliamentary Entitlements Act 1990, which does contain explicit legislative provision enabling that class of payment to be made, and it gives lawful authority for it, namely, so far as it relates to the carrying on of the functions of a minister, then that particular—

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't empower anything.

—No, not by itself, but in conjunction with, subsequently of course, the one-line appropriation in order to cover the particular dollar sum. Rather than just being a matter that had to wait for its entire legal authority for the parliamentary appropriation, with 4(4)(b) in place as a result of that case, it was possible to see the nexus or the relationship between the two things. The Solicitor-General advised in those terms, and that is the basis on which the government was confirmed in its original decision to make the payment out of the advance and to follow it with a one-line appropriation, as you would expect, next April but relying in the meantime on the umbrella authority of 4(4)(b) to make the point. That is the basis on which the Solicitor-General advised us orally a few days ago, confirming the original decision that had been taken by the cabinet to go down that particular route. It is that that is spelt out in the paper that you have seen and which we, in the interests of transparency, put in the public domain.

PARA.TAB: I have seen some speculation that Dr Lawrence has to stay a minister in order to justify payment being made. That is nonsense. There are alternative routes available. You can go down the one-off route of 34A of the Audit Act, an act of grace payment, which was utilised, for example, to support Alan Griffiths's funding of his legal defence when he became a backbencher after he resigned from the ministry. There is no particular problem about that. Again, you need a one-line appropriation. But the government has been absolutely frank, absolutely transparent. To the extent that we have to pay for this—and we still believe it ought to be a matter for the Western Australian government—we will do so, and wie have a very sound legal basis on which to do so. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Minister, will you clarify whether any legal advice was sought from the Solicitor-General or any other party prior to the decision being made to fund Dr Lawrence as to the legality and propriety of that funding? Will you tell us from whom the advice was sought? Will you also explain why the Solicitor-General's support for the legality and propriety of this payment is so limp in that in the advice—if you care to read it—he makes reference to payments that `may be justified'. I do not think he ever comes out and says `can clearly be justified'. Why is the advice so limp?

—It is a pretty limp old bit of poking and probing that we just had there. I have answered the first part of the supplementary question already. I said the Solicitor-General only came into this a few days ago when his advice was specifically sought on the implications of section 48 of the constitution, Brown v. West.
—Did you get any other advice before?

—I also said—you were not listening because you were preparing this breathtaking supplementary—that there had been some exchange of discussion between AGs and Finance personnel in the run-up to the original cabinet discussion in order to discuss the different options that were available. I do not know what might be in paper as a result of those exchanges. What I do know is that the government does not propose now or ever to table legal advice that might exist in this particular forum.
—Did you get it is the question.

—We acted on the basis of the advice of the officials that that was a perfectly legally appropriate way to go. Subsequently a question was raised, `Yes, there is no problem about the money being paid eventually but it might be a bit unreasonable if the lawyers have to wait till next April or May. Can't they be paid out of the Advance to the Minister for Finance?' Maybe not. There was a question raised under Brown v. West. However, 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act makes it clear that you can—very straightforward, very clear. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. One of the important factors contributing to Australia's economic development and international competitiveness is our industrial relations system. The number of working days lost per thousand employees in the year to May 1995 was the lowest figure for any year to May since the ABS began publishing these statistics in 1982. This is obviously very important for all Australians, whether they be workers or employers. What are the national implications flowing from the Western Australian government's controversial second wave of industrial relations changes?

—Australia enjoys a new respect in the world, and it enjoys that respect because of the restructuring of the Australian economy and because we in Australia have managed to heal the industrial relations rift that existed in this country over many decades under conservative governments. We have ended the old period of confrontation. We have introduced a new period of cooperation in the workplace and, as we have heard, Australia has the lowest level of industrial disputation now since the records of industrial disputes commenced being kept. That is an enviable record recognised around the world, and Australia gets marks for bringing off that major reform without any disputation at all.

PARA.TAB: That record is now being threatened. It is being threatened not only by the legislation that the Western Australian government has carried, but by the so-called second wave of industrial relations legislation threatened by the Western Australian government. It is properly characterised as extreme and ideological legislation. It has been condemned by the Confederation of WA Industry, which described it as provocative and unworkable. It has been condemned by mining industry companies—a major lifeblood of the industry sector in Western Australia. It has been condemned by the editorial writers of the conservative West Australian newspaper, who described it as vindictive and unacceptable to the Western Australian community. These are not Labor stooges; these are conservative voices in Western Australia who normally oppose a Labor government, but all of them have condemned this legislation as extreme and ideological.

The leader of the federal opposition, Mr John Howard, has described this legislation as a model for his own industrial legislation changes. He has described it as his model. It is important to get on the record the circumstances of that. The legislation was announced by Mr Keirath, the Western Australian industrial relations minister, on 26 May and the draconian nature of it was then spelt out. It was debated during June and July. On 28 July, Mr John Howard said the WA model is a model for the federal industrial relations legislation—and that was only three weeks ago. On 17 August the West Australian reported that Mr Keirath rejected the idea that he was withdrawing his second wave legislation because of federal pressure, but then went on to say he had discussed this with Mr Howard and—I quote the West Australian—`Mr Howard wholeheartedly supported it'.

That has since been denied—or attempted to be denied—by Mr Howard; but we know that prior to the last election, Mr Howard did not reveal the details of his proposed industrial relations changes at that time. We asked him to produce the bill. He declined to do so. He said he would have it available the week after the election. It is now several years after the election. He still has not produced his bill. Who is lying here? Is the liar Mr Keirath, or is the liar Mr Howard?

There is absolutely no doubt, given the conspiracy here on the Liberal side of politics, that the facts are now revealed. The draconian, ideological and vindictive industrial legislation planned in Western Australia is owned by the federal opposition and is the model for their industrial relations changes. That disturbs business in this country; that disturbs our trading partners; that threatens to break the harmony in the workplace that we have nurtured over so many years, and turn back the clock on the major reforms that we have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the importance of this matter, it is quite appropriate to ask the minister to explain further the implications for the Australian economy if this legislation were to operate nationally.

—The implications can best be explained by going to what is said by employers and experienced commentators in Western Australia. They have said that in the old dark days of industrial relations confrontation under the Liberals, the Western Australian iron ore industry, for example, was dispute prone and Australia got lower prices for its iron ore commodities because it was regarded as an unreliable supplier.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. If I recall correctly, you made certain comments yesterday in relation to an opposition question, that it was hypothetical. I was wondering whether you, Mr President, would be indicating your view as to whether that supplementary was also hypothetical; because we on this side would like to see the same standard applied to both sides of the house.
—You might also remember that yesterday I allowed the question. I allow this question, too. I listened to it carefully.
—I am a bit cynical about this, Mr President—
—Order! I have made my ruling. Sit down.

—We had lower prices for our mineral commodities because the Liberal Party's industrial relations changes created disputation and made Australia's international reputation one of an unreliable supplier. We are addressing the current account difficulties of this economy. This legislation goes right to the heart of turning back our ability as a country to grow our trade if once again it plunges us back into the dark ages of industrial disputation. That is the most significant implication of this sort of legislation—turn back the clock and bring back the Dickensian confrontational politics of industrial relations under conservative governments.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to his repeated claims that the Marks royal commission is a political exercise designed to damage Dr Lawrence. How does your view of the royal commission reflect on the integrity of Commissioner Marks and the sworn testimony given by half of her cabinet colleagues, which includes the current Labor leader and Dr Lawrence's former deputy premier and four of her former senior staffers? Is it not a fact that Dr Lawrence is being damaged by her own political side and not her political opponents? Do you accept that in seeking to diminish sworn testimony you are sending a message to the community that the parliamentary standards have fallen so low under the Keating government that words like `integrity' and `propriety' no longer have meaning?

—I do not resile for one moment from what I have been saying about the nature of the Western Australian royal commission. It is unequivocally and unashamedly a political exercise designed to discredit one person, Carmen Lawrence, simply because of her profile. Any issues about the appropriateness of the petition being lodged were well and truly dealt with in the two previous years by the Western Australian parliament's own processes. There was no issue left to resolve. The matter in issue was not the cause of Penny Easton's death, although that is something which still seems to be very much in the minds of the opposition as something they want to associate with Carmen Lawrence.The opposition ought to be very ashamed of itself indeed for what we have heard in the last 24 hours—from former Senator Bishop, for example.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Before Senator Evans goes off on a totally unrelated frolic, the question that he is being asked is: what has the motivation for the establishment of the royal commission got to do with the evidence that has been presented before it? In other words, does Senator Evans seriously suggest that your questioning of the motivation of the royal commission in any way impugns the integrity of the commissioner or in any way reflects adversely on those who have given sworn evidence before the commission? That is the question. That is what is relevant. It has got nothing do with whatever else he might want to talk about.
—Order! You have made your point. Your understanding of the question is quite different from mine. There is no point of order.

—People involved in this exercise, both in Western Australia and on the other side of this parliament, are unashamed and naked in their ambitions to use this commission for one purpose and one purpose alone. Unashamedly, nakedly, we have had at least three opposition members in the last 24 hours trying to draw a deliberate nexus between what Carmen Lawrence may or may not have done in the death of Penny Easton. We have had Bronwyn Bishop talking about the mother of Penny Easton, who died as a result of that petition. You have Wilson Tuckey talking about the petition that caused a woman to suicide. You have Michael Wooldridge talking about the tabling of the petition being the trigger that caused Penny Easton to suicide. This is being said over and over and over again by those on your side of politics who are engaged in nothing less than one of the sleaziest exercises I have ever seen in the 17 years I have been in this parliament. You ought to be ashamed of yourselves.

PARA.TAB: I cast no public aspersions on Mr Marks for taking up this particular job. That is a matter for his own conscience and he can live with that. As to the circumstances of the evidence that so far has been proceeding before that commission, I repeat as I said yesterday that when what is in issue is people's recollections of a sequence of events, what they knew and when, and when there is no contemporaneous documentary evidence supporting any particular point of view, it is utterly inappropriate to leap to conclusions about the quality or significance of that evidence simply on the basis of the strength of conviction with which a particular recollection is held. That is something we all know is true about human nature. We all know it is true about the human psyche, that there is that inability to be precise in your recollection.

What we have heard so far tells us nothing about the truth of the matter. What is in issue at the end of the day—and it cannot be said too often—is a royal commission designed for one purpose only, a purely political purpose. It is not designed to identify a possible criminal action. It is not designed to attribute responsibility criminally. It is not designed to work over an exercise in maladministration. It is not designed to inquire into financial impropriety or abuse of power. It is not designed to inquire into a national security issue. It is designed for one purpose only—to discredit a political opponent who, you know, is doing you damage because of the measure of acceptance and respect with which she is regarded in the entire Australian community; and she will not be dragged down by this sleazy and squalid exercise which you have unashamedly engaged in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, under standing order 193(3), I ask that the Leader of the Government withdraw that sneering imputation with regard to the commissioner that it was a matter for his conscience whether he took the job, because that is a grave breach of standing orders.
—There are two things about that. I did not take that as a sneer. But number two, the commissioner is not protected by that standing order.
—He is, because he is a judicial officer.
—I have just indicated that he is not. If you want to take it up later—
—I would like you to read 193(3) also.
—Mr President—
—I have just ruled on that.
—Mr President—
—I have already ruled on that point of order.
—Can I put it to you—
—Do you want to take another point of order?
—Yes, I do. Are you saying that you do not really mind whether or not Senator Evans has reflected adversely on the integrity of the commissioner?
—That is not what I said.

—Or is it simply that he is not a member of parliament and Senator Evans can say what he likes? I do not think Senator Evans would like to be left with that imputation. If you say, Senator Evans, that it is a matter for someone's conscience, you are saying, `You ought to think again about your position.' In other words, you are reflecting very deliberately on the integrity of Commissioner Marks. If you want to leave it there, that's fine. We know where you stand.
—I made it clear the first time and I do not wish to repeat it. I call Senator McGauran.

—Minister, given your efforts to diminish sworn testimony before the commission and to brand the commission as a political exercise only to damage Dr Lawrence, will you agree that the original motive for the tabling of the petition was a pure political exercise by Dr Lawrence to damage Richard Court?

—Whether or not there was any impropriety involved in the lodging of the petition is something that was the subject of consideration and report by a committee within the Western Australian parliament. I have nothing to add to that particular process. Lots of things are done in parliaments which might be a little bit colourable or a little bit inappropriate, but it is not Dr Lawrence's petition; it is Mr Halden's petition. The matter in issue was who knew what about it and when. That is exactly the matter that is in issue, and I am not going to draw any adverse inferences at all about people's responsibility or credibility or respectability based on the flimsy material that is available in this respect at the moment.

—My question is directed to Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade. Building vehicles has great significance in Australia and is of particular importance to my home state of Victoria and to South Australia. The best health of the industry is the aim of management and workers in it, as demonstrated by the concern shown for it by such unions as the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union. Given this, what is the government doing to ensure that Australian—
—Wally Curran.

—Wally Curran is not in the manufacturing workers union. He is in the meat employees union, and he leads that union with outstanding skill, integrity and drive. He is one of the greatest unionists this country has seen. To return to the question: what is the government doing to ensure that Australian automotive exports to Japan will not suffer, and indeed will gain, from the auto agreement recently reached between the United States and Japan?
—On behalf of Senator Cooney, I would like to thank Senator Kemp for guaranteeing him a few more votes in his preselection!

PARA.TAB: The government is extremely conscious of the potential impact that the United States-Japan auto agreement might have had on automotive exports. It was specifically to protect the export interests of these industries, and the very important level of employment in the automotive sector that Senator Cook spoke about so positively yesterday in terms of the major investment decisions that are being made, that he and I decided to establish a special task force to monitor the effects of the US-Japan auto agreement, a group comprising manufacturers, components industries and the union movement, co-chaired by Senator Cook and myself, to ensure that Australian exports benefit from the market openings that Japan is committed to and to ensure that there are no discriminatory deals that cut Australia out.

It is designed to send a very clear message to both the United States and Japan that we will be vigilant to ensure there are no such deals. Both Senator Cook and I have received assurances at ministerial level in Japan and the United States that the agreement will be implemented in a non-discriminatory manner, and those assurances are very welcome. We are further aided by the fact that we made the decision to participate as the third party in the dispute in the WTO and that has helped our position in obtaining those assurances.

But we are not merely going to sit back and allow other governments to look after the interests of our industry and our workers. In addition to the task force, we are setting out to establish a channel for discussion with the Japanese and the United States on the effects of the auto agreement on Australia. Therefore, we intend to discuss with the Japanese Minister for International Trade and Industry, Mr Hashimoto, tomorrow during his visit for the AJMC—the Australia-Japan ministerial consultations—an initiative for Australia and Japan to meet each year after the annu6al consultations between the United States and Japan on the implementation of the agreement. So that we will equally have the opportunity to ensure that Australia's interests are protected and that through the task force which is monitoring the trends in exports we will have an avenue to put that information directly to the Japanese industry and the Japanese government. Japan is fully aware of the direct commercial stake Australia has in the implementation of the auto agreement and I am quite optimistic we will get agreement on the establishment of such discussions during the course of tomorrow's meeting.

A similar proposal has been put to the United States trade representative seeking what is, in effect, a parallel although not identical arrangement. In it, he has responded favourably and it is a matter that I will be pursuing in detail shortly.

But what I am putting today in response to Senator Cooney's question is the important interests of Australian industry and Australian workers in building on the great strength of our exports of automobiles, and in this instance particularly automobile parts which is where our strength is in Japan. We are trying to put in place a comprehensive framework to ensure the globalisation and the export plans of the Australian automobile industry are not derailed by the US-Japan auto agreement, but rather that these plans build on the opportunities provided by this agreement.

The framework we have established should help assure the future of Australian workers, particularly in Victoria and South Australia, as Senator Cooney said, because that is where much of the industry is located. It is yet another example of effective, active trade policy and of the team Australia approach—government, industry and unions working together to protect and advance our export interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is it a fact that in the late 1970s the Australian Environment Council passed a resolution that Australian companies operating overseas would be required to observe environmental protection conditions at least as stringent as if the same company were conducting its operations in Australia? What is the present government's attitude to this resolution, whether or not you have been able to confirm this resolution which I believe was passed in 1978? Has it insisted on this condition being met in the case of the involvement of BHP in the Ok Tedi Mine in Papua New Guinea? If it has not, will it now insist on this condition being met and, if not, why will it not so insist?

—I have been advised, Senator, that there is no such Australian Environment Council resolution going to the operations of private companies overseas. I can say to you though, Senator Coulter, that I am aware of a resolution in 1992 that government agencies apply the same environmental assessment procedures to overseas projects as are applied in Australia. In fact, decisions relating to overseas activities are subject to the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

PARA.TAB: I can also say that the government is certainly concerned to see that Australian companies operating overseas follow the same principles of ecologically sustainable development and best environmental practice that we look for in Australia. As Senator Gareth Evans said in answer to an earlier question this week in question time, the Australian government does not have the power to determine or implement standards in the jurisdictions of other national governments. This is properly the responsibility of the government concerned.

Australian standards are developed for Australian conditions. They are not necessarily appropriate to conditions in other countries. There are cases where insisting on Australian standards would see a negative result for the environment. For example, there are projects in other less developed countries supported by Australian aid funding that clearly result in a marked local improvement in environmental outcomes but which would not go ahead if it were necessary to reach the standards that Australia enjoys.

I think it is appropriate that the government make clear its expectation of companies that are operating abroad. I have asked my department to work closely with industry and community organisations to develop suitable guidelines. Work on such guidelines for the mining industry is already under way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What involvement did General Baker have in the proposal, appointment and subsequent withdrawal of General Mantiri as the Indonesian ambassador to Australia? Does the minister consider that it is entirely appropriate for senior members of Australia's military to be involved in the negotiations and appointments of diplomats, particularly when there are significant sensitivities involved? What is set in place to prevent the overriding of broader foreign affairs and human rights concerns by a desire on the part of the military and defence industry to gain access to Indonesia's defence market? Finally, in that regard, what is the purpose of the forthcoming visit to Western Australia by two of the most senior figures in the Indonesian military, General Tanjung and Defence Minister Sudradjat?

—Although misconceptions seem to persist on this subject, General Baker has already explained on the public record, as has Senator Ray, the nature of the contact that he had with General Mantiri when the question of the new ambassador to Australia was still a live issue. That involvement was one of simply contacting General Mantiri, whom General Baker knew well, to express the view to him, which was entirely consistent with the position that had been taken by me and the government as a whole, that maybe things would be very difficult for him if he were to come to Australia, given the feeling that existed on the East Timor issue here and given the way in which General Mantiri's name had been publicly associated with that issue.

PARA.TAB: That was the nub and the substance of the conversation. It was not one that was designed to encourage General Mantiri to come to Australia. On the contrary, it was designed, from one professional colleague to another and from one friend to another, to make clear that General Mantiri would probably experience very great difficulty if he did come to Australia and that that would not be helpful to the overall relationship. That is the nub and the substance of it.

The other question that you raise concerns the visit of the other two senior Indonesian military personnel to Australia. That is obviously a visit that is part and parcel of our continuing very close defence cooperation and relationship with Indonesia in the aftermath of the K95 exercise which has been proceeding. It is a visit by senior personnel that we welcome. It is very important that Australia have a multidimensional relationship with Indonesia which stretches across the whole range of political, economic and military contacts as well as many other categories of person to person contact, such as culturally, through tourism, educational exchange and so on.

This is a relationship that we enormously value—the relationship with Indonesia. It has had many new dimensions added to it and has had many more layers of substance added to it over the last few years. That is a trend we entirely welcome and have been assiduously working towards. The military dimension of it is just one other such dimension.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two questions that were not quite answered. Firstly, are you, Minister, disputing the interpretation by Four Corners that it was an encouragement of General Mantiri? Are you saying that that interpretation is wrong, that he did not say, `Yes, you will still be welcome in Australia?' Secondly, you did not answer the question about what they are doing in Western Australia.

—Among other things, they will be meeting Senator Ray and other senior military personnel. Western Australia—although Richard Court has not caught up with it yet—is where a large amount of our defence force is currently based these days. I have not seen the Four Corners program this week to which you refer. I had not been aware that, as you say, there had been some reference in it to General Baker having encouraged General Mantiri. Certainly encouragement to come to Australia was not the purpose of the call nor its content, as I understand it. To that extent there seems to have been some misunderstanding.
—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—You look like Napoleon.

—At least my hands are above the table, unlike yours, Senator Faulkner. Given that former Labor number cruncher and senior minister Graham Richardson, in his book Whatever it takes, admitted that lying was part of his political armoury, does the government acknowledge that lying is also part of its political armoury? What standard does the Prime Minister apply to Labor ministers? Is telling the truth a prerequisite for holding ministerial office under Labor or is telling a lie sanctioned if it delivers the leadership to Paul Keating or an election to Labor or attempts to save a ministerial scalp?
—This is a government that is very strongly committed to honesty and probity of government. That is the way we have acted. That is the way we will continue to act.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. In answer to a question asked by me in February of this year you informed the Senate that the Commonwealth and all state governments were working towards the development of a mandatory code of practice for health and hygiene in all slaughtering and meat processing establishments in Australia. Can you inform the Senate of the progress that has been made on this vital public health issue since that time?

—This is an extremely important issue. I thank Senator Burns for the question. I am pleased to advise the Senate that there has in fact been substantial progress made on this front. Following the food poisoning outbreak in South Australia I sought the agreement of all state primary industry ministers to a thorough review of the existing codes of practice in the meat industry. I wanted to see those voluntary codes made mandatory to ensure that uniform standards applied in all states. It is state governments that are responsible for those domestic establishments.

PARA.TAB: The February meeting of ARMCANZ ministers agreed and a concerted industry and government review process was set in train. I give credit to the enormous amount of work that was done on this major job by the state government and federal government bureaucracies. It is a good piece of work.

The work included the completion of substantial revisions to a number of industry codes of practice by a working group chaired by Mr John Crosby of the New South Wales Meat Industry Authority. This important task was completed within a tight time frame and, as I have just said, the working group is to be commended for its efforts. The new Meat Industry Council played an important part in galvanising the commitment of the industry to this approach. Ministers had the benefit of detailed advice from the MIC which fully supported the proposed approach to meat safety issues.

At the meeting of ARMCANZ ministers which I chaired in Perth last week, agreement was reached on an extensive package of measures which will ensure uniformly high safety standards for meat across Australia. Legislation to support minimum mandatory standards for all slaughtering, meat transport and meat processing establishments will be introduced by all governments by December this year or as soon as legislatively possible thereafter.

To further improve the system and keep it at the forefront of developments in the area of meat safety, hazard analysis and critical control point principles will be introduced across all meat establishments in Australia by December 1996. Further work in the area of chemical residue management, animal identification systems and refinement of development of game and fish codes is to be fully undertaken as part of the overall process of ensuring fully contemporary food safety standards in Australia.

These outcomes are timely and significant. They demonstrate not only this government's commitment to food safety and consumer protection but also our capacity to work with industry to address and resolve the really important issues.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Minister, do you believe Carmen Lawrence's account of events preceding the lodging of the petition in Western Australia or do you suspend judgment until after she has had her day before the commission? If the former is the case, why do you believe her account as opposed to the recollection of so many of her colleagues?

—Carmen Lawrence is a person and a minister of absolute rock solid integrity and honesty with a reputation that is beyond comparison in the Australian public in terms of her years of public life to date. I have absolutely no reason whatsoever to doubt that that is her recollection as she had it at the time when she was first asked about this five days after the event and that that is her recollection now.

PARA.TAB: The fact that other people's recollections appear to be different, as I have said constantly over the last few days, is not in itself conclusive of anything. It is not conclusive that those recollections have been sworn to on oath. It is not conclusive that those recollections of other ministers which are different have been manifestly strongly or intensely held.

People's recollections are notoriously fallible on matters of this particular kind where what is in issue is not whether something happened but rather when it happened and what someone's state of knowledge about it was at a particular time. Notoriously we tend to get chronologies out of sequence, to get things mixed up. Particularly when people are giving evidence on these matters up to three years after the event, in many cases for the first time committing themselves on the record to a particular recollection, it is not surprising that those recollections might on occasion be very fallible indeed. So let us not make any assumptions about this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then if you accept her version on the basis of your belief in her integrity, what does that say about your belief in the integrity of so many of her colleagues who fundamentally see it very differently?

—The difference between Dr Lawrence and the others is she put her recollection on the record five days after the event. The others who are now speaking on the record, in many cases for the first time, are doing it up to three years after the event. If it comes to a choice between the two of them, as a prima facie matter it is perfectly reasonable to believe that a recollection first stated on the record five days after the event and absolutely consistently maintained thereafter is to be taken absolutely seriously, and I do.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Can the minister inform the Senate of progress with the groundbreaking accreditation of child-care centres in long day care centres?

—I am very pleased to have been asked this question by Senator Neal and to be able to tell the Senate just how well the accreditation system for child care has progressed. I would also like to tell the Senate that over the recess I held a number of consultations, or participated in consultations, with the National Parents Child Care Council, chaired by Christine Woodrow, to hear from parents. The highest concern that parents have for child care is that it provide good quality care.

PARA.TAB: In the light of that, it is very encouraging to be able to report that 99.9 per cent of child-care centres around Australia have registered. They are now part of the quality improvement and accreditation system, part of this government's world first national accreditation system. Of the 3,580 long day care child-care centres in Australia, only a few have chosen not to participate at this stage.

In South Australia, Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory all centres have registered. I am particularly appreciative of those reports. The National Childcare Accreditation Council is waiting for seven centres in New South Wales, five in Victoria and one in Western Australia to register.

When parents are asked what is their principal concern about child care—now that we do have such a significant number of places and the child-care assistance to keep it affordable for parents—the most important concern is quality. Parents want the assurance that they are leaving their children where they will have a secure, safe and interesting day.

The other thing that the Senate may not be aware of is the independent evaluation done by Coopers & Lyerbrand at the end of the last session. It was an evaluation of the accreditation process to this time. Coopers & Lyerbrand—
Opposition senators—Lybrand.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did I say?
—`Liar-brand'; but it is on your mind.

—What an absolutely gripping contribution to wisdom! Coopers & Lybrand proved the opposition wrong. That evaluation showed that the participating centres have been able to show that there is an improvement in the quality provided through the centres and, secondly, that the cost—and this should be particularly interesting to Senator Boswell; I hope his colleagues tell him—assessed by Coopers & Lybrand is less than $2 per place per week. So rest easy, troops over there, all of you who beat it up to $60. It is less than $2 a week and, if anything, likely to decline. This included the setup costs for accreditation. The Coopers & Lybrand independent evaluation is very good news. It makes clear that cost is not a concern. The response has led to increased quality and reports of satisfaction from the people participating in it.

PARA.TAB: There is further good news. Of those centres that are registered, only 29 have not lodged their self-assessment forms. A few weeks ago I wrote to something like 63 or 64 centres which at that stage were registered but had not put in their self-assessment forms. That figure has now fallen to only 29 centres. It is not a major concern that those centres are registered but are waiting to complete the form before 31 August. We have obtained their interest and commitment to the accreditation process. I urge the 13 or so centres still outstanding to take very seriously the opportunity and obligation they have to conform with what is now a matter of law.

It is important that people realise that it is a matter of law and that centres are not assisted by any opposition spokesperson urging antagonism to accreditation or encouragement not to participate. It is important that centres know that it is a matter of law. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Faulkner, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to your answer to Senator Carr yesterday regarding the offer by World Geoscience to survey Mururoa Atoll for radioactive leakage. You appear to have been poorly advised in the answer you gave. I am advised that the company is prepared to cover all costs of the survey. Further, the survey would provide a baseline of what radioactivity is in the area and indicate whether there had been any surface leakage from the tests. Will you now reconsider your position, initiate discussions with the company, and approach the French to seek the required approval?
