—No, I will not. One of the reasons is that the French have already said that they will not allow such an overflight to take place. But let me say to Senator Kemp that in its original communication with my office the company concerned did offer its services free of charge. However, in a subsequent telephone conversation between my staff and the company, Mr John Bell of the company did clarify that `free of charge' related to the use of their technology, not the charter of a plane or helicopter.

PARA.TAB: Let me also point out that we have from 20 eminent scientists a very clear indication indeed that the likelihood of radioactive contamination to the marine environment will be for a period of time into the future. In the best case scenario the contamination is likely to be in some hundreds of years, as I have said on a number of occasions; in the worst case scenario, maybe 10, 20 or 50 years. We also know that there has been structural damage to the atoll itself; we know there has been contamination of the lagoon; we know there has been subsidence; and we know there have been landslides. I want to make very clear that in no way is there any suggestion that the nature of the contamination will not be long term, and that it will have the sorts of impacts that have been outlined in the scientific report.

I make the point that we do not want to have a situation where anyone could suggest that one or two flyovers by a survey plane of Mururoa Atoll will in any way compensate for proper access to all the data that the French government holds; for proper access to the survey material that the French government holds; or for proper access to either Mururoa Atoll, and there have been only three scientific missions to that atoll, or Fangataufa Atoll—and there has never been a scientific mission there.

What the Australian scientists have said very clearly and very publicly to the Australian community is that we need that level of access, and we need it before the tests take place—not after, as the French government has said. We do not accept the principle that you can have an environmental impact assessment after the environmentally significant event has taken place. I would hope even someone with as little understanding and knowledge of environmental principles—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or interest.

—or interest as Senator Kemp would at least understand that situation. In no way is this government going to back away from its commitment to a thorough, rigorous and long-term monitoring program and proper scientific assessment. I think Senator Kemp's efforts, and those of Mr Downer, in relation to this particular matter do nothing but undermine this government's and the Australian people's strong commitment on that matter.

—My question is directed to Senator Schacht, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. My question relates to the launches of the Customs Watch Program which have taken place throughout Australia. I am particularly interested in the program because of the length of the coastline in the state which I represent and also because of the vulnerability of the Torres Strait area, also within Queensland. Would the minister be able to advise what this program is designed to achieve and what has been the public reaction to the Australia-wide launches?

—I thank Senator Colston, a senator from Queensland, for asking the question. The impact of this new program called Customs Watch is, quite rightly, of great and particular interest in the northern areas of the coastline of Queensland. Customs Watch is a community participation program whereby we encourage members of the public to report to customs officials suspicious or unusual activities or circumstances which may look like they are involved in illegal drug importation into Australia.

PARA.TAB: Although we have greatly expanded the resources available in the new contract with Coastwatch, with a coastline the length of Australia and with our sparsely populated remote areas it is still quite possible, of course, for people with a determined plan to illegally bring drugs into the country. Therefore, with local communities in these areas being involved, we want to encourage them to keep their eyes open and report any sorts of suspicious circumstances. Such things as something buried on a beach, fuel hidden in remote areas or ships at sea signalling to somebody on the coast—it does not necessarily mean that they are illegal activities—are things that customs officials may wish to investigate. We have launched Customs Watch at various community areas around Australia, in particular—
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. This is of interest to some people here; let us hear it.

—I thank you, Mr President, and it is of interest particularly to the communities involved. The response has been very strong, particularly in areas in northern Queensland. We have had a launch in Cairns and the response has been very strong. We have established a toll-free number, a hotline number, right across Australia for people to ring if they see or believe there is suspicious activity. The number is 1800 06 1800.
—What was that?
—An easy number to remember, Senator Bolkus: 1800—about the last year the Liberal Party had an original idea in Australia. It is a program of community support.
—It doesn't suit you, Chris.

—Senator Kemp, I would hope that you would encourage people to participate in this program. There actually has been support from some members opposite, and I happen to have noticed that even Senator Ian Macdonald has shown some interest in the launch of this program, and my customs officers have advised him accordingly.

PARA.TAB: I just want finally to acknowledge that organisations such as four-wheel drive clubs and sailing clubs, crews of fishing vessels, pilots of light aeroplanes and appropriate industry and community groups using those sorts of vehicles and equipment have already indicated strong support. That has been a very encouraging development and means that we can get a very good and improved coverage in the surveillance to stop illegal drugs coming into this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the minister confirm that the recent Qantas float raised only $1.45 billion, that the proposed $180 million sale of AIDC has been abandoned, that ANL will get a maximum of around only $16 million and possibly as little as $5 million after deducting almost $1 million for fees to Messrs Wran and Turnbull, and that the sale of any airports in this financial year is now highly improbable? Does this not mean that, even if 60 per cent of the remaining Commonwealth Bank stake is sold this financial year, there will still be a $1.4 billion asset sales shortfall from the budget forecast of $5.3 billion and a resulting budget deficit, thereby blowing your mythical surplus out of the water?
—To the first question, no. To the second question, no.

—Given the fact that a Commonwealth Bank sale of something like 60 per cent at a minimum will still leave you with a deficit of more than a billion dollars, will you give an assurance that the sale of the first tranche of the remaining Commonwealth Bank shareholding will be completed this financial year? Does not the government's decision last week to increase its borrowings this financial year from around $6 billion to $8.5 billion simply confirm that the government does not expect to achieve its asset sales program and, if it does not mean that, then what does it mean?
—Senator Short knows full well—
—No, he doesn't.

—Well, he ought to know full well, because he is an ex-Treasury official, although he does a lot to disguise that fact in the questions that he asks in here, that any government, whether it is ours or any other government, will not itemise the particular amount that they will recover from an asset sale. This question is about trying to establish whether or not the global figure we have included in our budget can be met.

PARA.TAB: We believe that there is a significant return from the asset sales that we will undertake. We will undertake those as we have announced. If there is any change to that, we will announce those changes. But at the moment I am not going to comment on any of the particular details of any of the sales you have referred to. In the case of the Commonwealth Bank, we have announced our position on that—you know that—and we do not resile from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Crowley, the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. I refer the minister to the fact that the Medicare agreement requires state governments to put any savings made from the closure of mental health institutions or other rationalisation of mental health services back into the mental health budget, and also to a further requirement that states provide casualty services in public hospitals. I ask: is the minister aware that the Victorian government is ignoring both of these requirements? Is she aware that the Victorian government has made so-called savings of at least $14 1/2 million in the mental health budget? Is she also aware that just recently, on 30 June, they closed the Rosebud Hospital's casualty department? I ask: in the light of these actions, what does the minister intend to do about these blatant breaches of the Medicare agreement by the state government of Victoria?

—Senator Lees, the national mental health report of 1994 indicates a reduction in expenditure of 5.8 per cent on mental health services by the Victorian government between the base year 1992-93 and the reporting year 1993-94. I do not have a figure here that says that is the $14 million-plus figure you have quoted, though I suspect that is the same figure.

PARA.TAB: Minister Lawrence has actually written to the Victorian Minister for Health, the Hon. Marie Tehan, seeking an explanation for the points that you have just made prior to considering what action might be appropriate. I have also been advised that there are allegations about the situation at the Rosebud Hospital in Victoria. I understand that these allegations raise legal questions relating to the Health Insurance Act, and that they have been referred to the Health Insurance Commission. I am therefore not in a position to comment on the detail of the Rosebud Hospital issue at this time.

The Medicare agreements did require precisely that states maintain their efforts in expenditure on mental health, and certainly no government can claim that there is not continuing unmet need for expenditure on mental health services. Similarly, the blatant examples of cost shifting as exemplified by the closure of outpatient services are not consistent with the Medicare agreements, and they are not consistent with recent agreements with the health ministers at Alice Springs. So, as to the two points that you have raised, Senator, I can give you that amount of information to this point. Minister Lawrence is following those up and, as anything further comes to hand, we will make sure you are provided with it.

Any reduction in commitment to mental health would be directly counter to what is an agreed need across the community for a commitment to mental health. The Commonwealth funding of $269 million has been made available under that national mental health strategy and, of that, $188 million has been made available to the states and territories to assist in service restructuring in a manner consistent with the strategy. So the concern you raise is a matter of very grave importance. As I say, the minister has that under consideration, and I will certainly let you know should anything further come to hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—I provide the following additional information to a question asked of me during question time yesterday. In relation to the child-care advertisement, I provide the following information. The advertisement referred to was rewritten by the Victorian office of the Department of Human Services and Health to appear in a special child-care supplement in the Sunday Age on Sunday 2 July. It was designed to provide information on the range of Commonwealth-funded children's services and financial assistance to families using them. The advertisement cost $10,242. It was to appear only once. However, the ad was not run in colour as planned, and the Sunday Age offered to run it again the next week, this time in colour, and it did so on 9 July free of charge. The ad contained one paragraph referring to the budget decision relating to eligibility for child-care assistance for families with a parent at home, although the legislation is not passed. As it was a special advertisement for a particular supplement, it is not intended to run the advertisement again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice by Senator Abetz this day, relating to ministerial responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things the people of Australia are clamouring for is integrity in government. One would have thought that when a minister, especially the Leader of the Government in the Senate, is asked about the standards that the Prime Minister applies to Labor ministers, he would have accepted the opportunity to outline to the people of Australia the sorts of standards and the disciplines that apply to his ministers.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, Senator Gareth Evans failed to do that. In his failure to do so, he has confirmed the very worst fears of the people of Australia. The longer this government is in power, the further the arrogance and the attitude of this government will be exposed. First of all, the former numbers-cruncher, the person who got Mr Keating the job of Prime Minister, acknowledged in his book Whatever It Takes that lying was part of his political weaponry. We then had in recent times Senator Robert Ray acknowledging that in politics we are not concerned about fairness and those sorts of qualities but only the outcomes.

In recent times the question of the truthfulness of the ministers of this government has been aired quite considerably, and it is no wonder that it has been aired. If we look at the Hansard of 10 November 1992 in the Western Australian parliament, we see that the then Premier and now Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) said about the petition in relation to Penny Easton:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I learned the detail of the petition and its general thrust upon its tabling. That is the way it is, and that is the way I have explained it; that is the position.
She claimed that she only learned about the general thrust of the petition after it was tabled.

PARA.TAB: Without prejudging the outcome of the Marks royal commission, the significant fact is that her former deputy premier and many of her other ministerial colleagues and her senior staff members have given a version of events that would suggest at the very least the minister was aware of the `general thrust of the petition'—to adopt Dr Lawrence's term—well and truly prior to its tabling. It is for that reason that we on this side of the house have been pursuing the question of Dr Lawrence's integrity and whether she ought to stand down whilst the royal commission is under way.

A suggestion has now come into this debate that we on this side of the house are trying to link the unfortunate suicide of Penny Easton to the tabling of the petition. I can refer honourable senators to a doorstop interview undertaken by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) today in which he says very clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it very clear that the Opposition is not, I am not and nobody will be asserting that Carmen Lawrence was responsible for Penny Easton's death.

Of course I agree with that, and I would not wish to draw that link in relation to this debate. The Labor Party would like to make us do that because that way it will divert our attention from what Carmen Lawrence actually said and did.

PARA.TAB: Allow me to remind the Senate that the Hansard of Western Australia on 10 November 1992 tells us that Dr Lawrence learned the detail of the petition and its general thrust upon its tabling. We have had a whole cricket team—11 people so far—giving a version of events in great contradistinction to that. Whilst there is a cloud over the minister, she ought to stand down until such time as the Marks royal commission has made its determination in relation to the veracity of that version of events. It is to the government's shame that Senator Gareth Evans refused to dissociate himself from Senator Graham Richardson's comments and failed to respond to my question and to take the opportunity to outline that the government was concerned about integrity in politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a recurring theme, and it was expected that it would be, given the fact that the opposition is taking the politically understandable course of trying to score points against the government. But what those opposite ought to distinguish between in that exercise is the mixing together of some sort of legal approach that they might purport to take, which implies that they are going about this in a responsible, calm and reasonable fashion, and the political exercise they are on about. Clearly, what they are on about is a political exercise.

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz, for example, said there is a cricket team of witnesses against Carmen Lawrence, the minister in question. That is not a legal proposition because, as Senator Abetz knows full well and as such great judges as Justice Richard Newton used to say, it is not a proper legal exercise to count up the number of witnesses on one side and compare it with the number of witnesses on the other side, and to conclude that because one side has more witnesses than the other, that side is right. That is certainly not a legal proposition. A political proposition, it is.

A political proposition is what Senator Abetz so effectively put. But he is not—nor is anybody on the other side—to be seen as putting forward legal propositions that have any merit. That is not what they are doing; and it is proper that that be understood. This is an exercise to get—and I think nobody pretends it is otherwise—Carmen Lawrence. That is what it is all about. As an exercise in that, they put questions which are quite objectionable to Senator Evans, `Do you countenance lying? Are you a part of a government that countenances lying?' There are all sorts of political questions.

When those opposite get a political answer, which is what is justified, they then get very upset and say, `Oh, no. You should not take this approach. We are here as responsible quasi-legal people going on in a very proper way asking these questions. When you do not give us an answer that we really want we are going to impugn you because you are acting in a political way, even though we are acting in a political way.' If you ask the leader of my party, Senator Evans, questions that are political I, as a backbencher, expect him to give a political answer and treat them on the basis that they are put—as a means of trying to gain an advantage for one side and a disadvantage for the other side, which is what we are all about in this chamber.

But what we cannot and should not be obliged to accept is an exercise of saying that somehow there is a moral virtue on the other side that is founded on some proper sort of legal basis and that on this side, when we give an appropriate answer, that has not got the same sort of quality. The sorts of questions you are asking and the sorts of answers we are giving are of exactly the same quality and are very proper. I think Senator Evans has done an outstanding job, from the point of view of being a leader of a political party, just as you have attempted to do a job on your side in trying to bring political disadvantages upon us.

Let's remember that there is one body that purports to be an umpire in this; that is, the royal commission. But that is the one body that nobody really wants to let do work. We want to set up all sorts of commissions; we want to set up a Senate committee to investigate; we want to do anything but let this body go around in a quiet and calm way to come to a conclusion that you say it wants to. What you are using this commission for is to get evidence before it which you can then use in this chamber in a political way. The exercise you are going through is not to stand aside and let this commission go about its business; you are doing anything but that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney I have a great deal of respect for. I would like to correct something that he said because I am sure that Senator Cooney would not say anything that could not be verified. My understanding of what he said was that the royal commission is the place for this question to be answered and that the government should resile from any attempt to allow it to go about its business. I would remind Senator Cooney that the question is that the government put up the funds to try to stop the royal commission proceeding. So Senator Cooney cannot have it both ways.
—I did not say that. I said that you had set up the royal commission to decide that issue and are not now letting it do its job.

—The reason that an attempt was made to stop the royal commission was purely political, Senator Cooney. You cannot wash your hands of that. The question that I ask of Senator Cooney is: when the royal commissioner brings down his finding, will the government accept that finding if the finding is that the minister lied? That is the question that needs to be asked. I accept Senator Cooney's statement that the royal commission should be unimpeded in its access. But if it then brings that down, I would expect Senator Cooney to accept the decision of the royal commission and I would expect the government to accept the decision of the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Margetts this day, relating to the proposed appointment of Lieutenant General Herman Mantiri as Indonesian Ambassator to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise to seek some clarification which I believe Senator Evans needs to make regarding his comments about my questions concerning the role of General Baker in the placing or otherwise of General Mantiri as Australia's ambassador to Australia, otherwise he may be seen to be in danger of misleading the Senate.

PARA.TAB: The reason I rise is that it was my recollection that it was clear on the Four Corners program that the outcome of the telephone conference from General Baker to General Mantiri was that of a friend reassuring another friend that he would be welcome in Australia. In the meantime I have received a fax with the transcript of the program. The question posed to General Mantiri—and this refers to General Baker—was this:

SPEECH.PARA: Q. Is it true that he rang you up as a friend and said, look don't bother coming to Australia because you'd just get too much friction.
The response from General Mantiri:

He told me. . . No. . . He phoned me. It was on a Tuesday, I don't remember the date, but he phoned me in the morning, because I was phoned on Monday by the Embassy here, the Australian Embassy. When was the convenient time to phone me, I told them at the time, please phone tomorrow about 7 o'clock and he phoned me 7 here. It was 10 o'clock there in Canberra. He said, hello how is life Mantiri and oh all running well but when I told him what. . . There are so many comments about me. Oh yes you know that and that. . . I told him then no problem about the comments. I'm a loyal soldier if the Government will not allow me to go there I'm a loyal soldier. I told him. Then he told me that, he answered by phone, I appreciate your attitude, you are sure a loyal soldier. And then he told me also that we are very disappointed if you're not coming and ADF will support you.
Q. Australian Defence Force will support you?
A. Yes.
I seek leave to table the faxed transcript from the Four Corners program and look forward to Senator Evans's explanation of the difference between the two opinions.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think a great deal is to be gained by tracking any further over the detail of this exchange which can, after all, only be known to the two people engaged in it, General Baker and General Mantiri. But I think there obviously has been some misunderstanding in the way in which the conference has been characterised by Senator Margetts and, presumably, on the Four Corners program. I have no doubt that General Baker was expressing his own personal sympathy for General Mantiri. He was probably saying that there was a strong measure of respect and appreciation within the Australian defence forces for the role that General Mantiri had played in building closer links between the Indonesian and Australian militarys, because all those things are true.

PARA.TAB: General Mantiri had been one of those in the Indonesian system most closely associated with building and nourishing those links. That is, no doubt, why he was thought by President Suharto to be a particularly appropriate choice. I have no doubt that there was a lot of warmth expressed in the conversation. But, equally, I have no doubt whatsoever—because I consulted with General Baker both before and after he had the conversation—that the essence of the conversation was to try to get the message to General Mantiri that, whatever the degree of personal friendship he could be expected to maintain with people in Australia, his friends in Australia, in particular General Baker, thought that he was going to be in for a very difficult time if he in fact came to the country, for reasons I earlier spelt out, and that it really would be better in all the circumstances if there was some reconsideration of that.

That is my very clear understanding of what the gist of that particular conversation was. It was a conversation that I, in fact, encouraged General Baker to have with General Mantiri because I thought it might help—in all the circumstances—smooth the way for an easier resolution of this particular problem. I have no doubt whatsoever that that was the flavour and substance of the conversation. Again, people's recollections of conversations, as with their recollections of events, can be quite different, can be quite fallible. People emphasise different things and de-emphasise others in their accounts. I do not think it is surprising that the aspects that you have recorded there from the Four Corners program—General Mantiri's interview—tend to accentuate the more positive aspects of that particular conversation. But my very clear understanding of its gist and its substance is as I have described them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Murphy this day, relating to industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to tell us about the ANL strike?

—No, I am just going to tell you how well we have done in industrial relations and how badly you have done. In fact, I will start with the very figure which proves conclusively how well you did when you were last in office. The fact is that we have now got industrial disputation 66 per cent lower than when you left office. That is of fundamental importance.

PARA.TAB: What is of more importance to the Australian people and to the future of this country's economy is what you are going to do with industrial relations if you ever get back into government. It is one of the areas the people have a right to know. In terms of your policy, which is primarily Jobsback—and I understand that Jobsback is still on the agenda—I want to deal with the issue of wages. Mr Howard, in a number of interviews over time, has made various statements that deal with how people will be paid under Jobsback and how you will negotiate your lot in terms of conditions, because Jobsback means the abolition of awards. You say that that is not the case, but the reality is that that would be the case. I quote Mr Howard, going back some time now—

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago?
—In this case it is 1992, but I will bring you forward to 1995.
—It is now 1995.
—That is right, but the position has not changed. We will wait to see whether it has changed. Mr Howard was asked a question by a radio compere:

SPEECH.PARA: What if the boss says to me, "I'd like you to work 50 hours a week now at the minimum award hourly rate and if you don't like it, there's lots who'll do it, see you later"?
Mr Howard said:
That becomes a matter of negotiation and you have to make up your mind whether in those circumstances you can get a better deal elsewhere. If you're a good worker you can get a better deal elsewhere.
Ultimately, what people are paid for, or whether they have got a job is determined by economic circumstances. If you can't reach agreement you go your separate ways.
At some point in time the opposition is going to have to come out and tell the Australian people whether or not that is their fundamental position on industrial relations.

TALK.START.PARA: —You break strikes by bringing in foreign scabs.
—With regard to productivity, for your benefit, Senator Macdonald—
—Under your administration one million Australians are out of work. Seven hundred thousand are still out of work and you want to lecture us on jobs. You have a nerve!

—You ought to look back at how many were out of work when you were in office. Productivity is so important to you lot on the other side that the other day you came in here, Senator Short, saying, `We want labour market reform. We have to get the cost of employment to the employer down.' The real unit labour cost under Labor has gone down 6.3 per cent—and that does not include the cost of superannuation, which is another important factor to the Australian people. Yet you said your policy is that you will abolish the award superannuation. What would that do to the savings of this country? You have to come out and tell the Australian people exactly where you stand.
—We didn't say that. When did we say that?
—You have said that.
—When did we say that?
—You want to check a few speeches of Mr Peter Reith to see whether or not you have said it.
—Tell me where? Where is your quote?
—Order!
—I will quote quickly from Mr Reith on superannuation.
—Where? Go on, quote us!
—On 2 August 1992, Mr Reith said:

SPEECH.PARA: and that's on top of and up to 100,000 people—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's 1992!
—Order, please!
—What's changed? You haven't changed anything. You haven't come out with a different policy. The quote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: who are losing their jobs in the next two or three years as a result of the superannuation levy.
That is your position and nothing has changed, and that is the unfortunate fact.

PARA.TAB: What are you going to do about unfair dismissals? Are you going to get rid of the court that deals with unfair dismissals? It doesn't matter whether people are in unions or not, you will not support workers if they lose their job illegitimately—and if you will, then come out and tell the Australian people.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess that is the first instalment of this fear campaign that we have been hearing so much about because this government is not going to look for an objective analysis of policies at the next election at all. This government is not interested in the battle of ideas. This government is interested in frightening the electorate yet again and misleading the electorate yet again. But the trouble for you is your side has lied to the Australian people too often—all too often! And the Australian people will never forget the l-a-w tax promise when your Prime Minister, Mr Keating, had no intention whatsoever of keeping that promise after the election. You simply deliberately misled the Australian people—and he will do it again and you will try to win the next election simply on the basis of lies and fears.

PARA.TAB: We heard it again—we heard it from Senator Murphy in his contribution just then when he said, `Your policy is to abolish awards' and he went back and quoted 1992. He said he had Peter Reith's speeches in front of him. If he had referred honestly to those speeches he would have told the Australian people that we have no intention whatsoever of abolishing awards. No Australian will be forced out of an award under the policies that we will take to the Australian people at the next election.

Have you got that clear? Why did you come in here today and tell another untruth in an attempt to frighten these Australian workers, so many of whom have been forced out of work under your administration? We have had 13 years of Labor. What a record! There have been up to one million unemployed and there are still 700,000 unemployed. We have had the highest interest rates since the war and the worst recession since the 1930s. What a contribution to the wellbeing of the Australian workers. What a nerve you have to come in here and contribute in that way.

All you did was reinforce the untruth told by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) in the chamber today in answer to your dorothy dixer. What your minister Senator Cook said today is that Mr Howard had suggested in Western Australia that we would adopt the Western Australian IR model. He was referring to an article that appeared in a newspaper. You and Senator Cook would know that Mr Howard, on 23 August 1995, had said in the House of Representatives in a personal explanation that that was not true. In referring to an article in the Australian, Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that I said no such thing. I have never associated the federal coalition with any so-called new or second wave industrial laws in Western Australia.

You knew Mr Howard came into the parliament and said that on 23 August 1995. You have no first-hand answer to anything that he said to the contrary. Why did Senator Cook get up in question time today and misrepresent the truth?

PARA.TAB: Isn't it about time that we got a bit of truth and honesty and that we restored a bit of integrity to Australian politics? It is about time that we started with just a touch of truth. In the last election, Mr Keating lied to the Australian people. Senator Richardson retired from this place and said that lying to the Australian people is legitimate. During the election campaign, Mr Carr, the new Premier of New South Wales, promised to remove the tolls. After the election, he said, `I am sorry. I cannot do it, but I will keep other promises that I made. You will have to accept that I misled you on that.'

Isn't it time that a bit of integrity was restored to Australian politics? Isn't it time that ministers started coming in here and telling the truth? Isn't it time that backbenchers, if they are going to contribute to these debates, have a go at standing by the truth as well?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask Senator Murphy a couple of questions. He talked about the great record of the Labor Party. Is it not a fact that the unions are just about to go out on strike on the waterfront, clog up the Australian ports and ruin Australia's export performance yet again? Is that right? We are supposed to have this great industrial relations record. They are just about to go out on strike.

PARA.TAB: What about Mount Isa? They all went out on strike on an inter-union demarcation dispute. What a great record! The Labor Party's record in industrial disputation is to bring in foreign scabs and the defence forces to break strikes. What a great record from a proud Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once proud.

—Once proud. There are foreign scabs and the military to break a strike. The wharfies are just about to go out again. You call that a great industrial relations record. You should hang your head in shame.

PARA.TAB: Where is this once great Australian Labor Party that had some interest in the real workers of this nation? For any workers legitimately striking, you want to bring in foreign scabs and the military and break the strikes. When your mates in the ACTU unions want to go on strike, you will let them hold Australia to ransom. They are about to go on strike at this very moment. You talk about an industrial relations record. You people should hang your heads in shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long time since I have heard such a load of rubbish. Senator Ian Macdonald has so little experience of and knowledge about industrial relations matters. Look at the history of the party that he represents. For many years, they supported a proposition of confrontation.
—Order! The time for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Jones, I present additional information received by the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee in response to the 1995-96 budget estimates hearings.
—On behalf of Senator Childs, I present additional information received by the Economics Legislation Committee in response to the 1995-96 budget estimate hearings.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley) proposed:
That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of government business order of the day No. 1, the Racial Hatred Bill 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that this had been the subject of some discussion between Senator Hill and the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner). I was also of the understanding that Senator Hill had been negotiating with the Manager of Government Business in the Senate a time limit for the disposal of this item of business. That is not reflected in the motion. I wonder whether that could be clarified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Hill actually wanted a guillotine placed on this legislation. There is an expectation that it will take us approximately half and hour or so to complete the legislation. We were not going to make a formal expression of that expectation because of your historic aversion to guillotines.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Consideration resumed.
Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remaining parts of the Racial Hatred Bill deal with the access to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission by those who are victims of racial vilification. I ask the minister to clarify for the committee the constitutionality of the provisions in this section of the bill. My understanding of the implications of the recent High Court rulings on the implied right to freedom of speech in the constitution is that there is a constitutional question to be resolved. I want to know what impact this particular section of the bill will have on freedom of political expression. If the minister could clarify that point, it would assist with the consideration of the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice to the government is that this bill is consistent with the recent court determinations on the case law that you mentioned. You have to keep in mind that we are talking about a bill which is in essence a measured response to a situation in the community. As such, it would come within the High Court's acceptable limits of incursion on the freedoms that we are talking about. Those High Court decisions do acknowledge that in some circumstances there would be a need for government measures like this and that the measures would have to be commensurate with the sorts of problems that we are tackling.

PARA.TAB: There is enough history and detail on the record which has led to this particular legislation coming in to justify a measured response, especially when you look at the fact that, in terms of this particular proposal, it is very tightly framed. As I say, it is much more tightly framed than state legislation which has been in operation for years.

TALK.START.PARA: —As it now stands, after the amendment by the Greens and the coalition, the bill can really only be described as a gutted ruin. This parliament will actually be saying to the community that we place greater value on protecting the free speech of those who, on racial grounds, were threatened personal violence, damage to property and incitement to hatred, rather than those who are likely to be the victims of those actions. I think that is rather regrettable. I would like to ask the minister what the bill, as it now stands, will do that cannot be achieved through the Racial Discrimination Act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share with Senator Spindler his concern about the gutting of this legislation. The main thrust, which has been removed so far, is a very important aspect of it. It is an aspect which has been recognised as being important not just by us but by state legislatures and other parliaments across the world. We are talking here about a total gutting of the main parts of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: What does it leave us with? It leaves us with a bit more than what is in the RDA now. It leaves us with a widening of grounds on which the RDA and HREOC can operate in terms of some of its programs. It does do that. But my concern is that it does that without giving the strongest possible message to the community that the sorts of behaviour HREOC will have to combat does not incur the operation of criminal law. That is a concern you and I share.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a couple of the points that were mentioned earlier by Senator Short that significant sections of the ethnic communities had concerns with the bill. He named some of those communities, which included some of those who were actually represented at the last annual conference of the Federation of Ethnic Communities Council in Hobart. It may be of interest to senators that at that meeting all present representatives of all ethnic communities voted unanimously in support of the Racial Hatred Bill as it stood before it was gutted.

PARA.TAB: Very specifically, I am unfamiliar with the concerns that have been said to have been expressed by the Arab community. This morning I got in touch with the Chairman of the Arabic Council, Mr Roland Jabbour, since Mr Joe Wakim, the Secretary with whom I have dealt before, is overseas at the moment. Mr Jabbour confirmed that they were concerned that in some ways the bill does not go far enough because it does not address very specifically the educative process that protects people who are members of the ethnic community and who could be exposed, in the privacy of their own home sometimes, to vilification, threats of violence and even assaults.

He took great care to say that, while they did not think the bill went far enough to address some of those concerns, they did not want to be interpreted as saying that they opposed the bill. In view of some of the comments that were made by Senator Short, I think it is important to take note of that.

I would also like to make a brief comment about the comments that were made by a number of the speakers from the opposition about Mr Rebikoff's statement. Certainly, as the statement is reproduced in Hansard, it would appear to go too far.

I have spoken with Mr Rebikoff. The concern that he attempted to express and the concern that I had was that incitement to hatred is very often followed by violent action. Indeed, very often it is designed to be followed by violent action. That consideration certainly leads the Australian Democrats to support the provisions—which are now gone—that incitement to racial hatred in public where it is likely to succeed should be an offence.

I point out that the bill does not make the prison terms mandatory, if that is the concern that has been expressed. The tribunal or the court may use its discretion to impose a fine as a penalty, impose community service, or award no penalty at all. I do not think that has been properly brought out. Yet again I would like to express my concern that we have missed an opportunity as a community, and as a parliament representing that community, to set up a standard that says that certain behaviour is not acceptable and if people feel inclined to indulge in that behaviour they risk criminal sanctions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Spindler's contribution it is worth restating the case that I thought I had made clear vis-a-vis our position on the second reading. Either Senator Spindler was not available to listen at the time or he did not understand.
—I listened and I did not agree.

—Senator Spindler says that those people who oppose and have opposed criminal sanctions care more for the free speech of the perpetrators of evil than for the victims of such evil. I might say that that is something of a dramatisation of the case. As I said at the very beginning, this is not an exercise about who is more opposed to racial hatred. The suggestion put by Senator Spindler is that we are not really worried about racial hatred, we are more worried about free speech, and therefore we do not care about the perpetrators of racially based statements about others.

PARA.TAB: That is clearly not the case. I had hoped that this would not degenerate into a debate about, `I am in favour of this, therefore you are not.' Sadly, that is the level to which Senator Spindler is thinking of dragging this debate. I do not think there is a federal parliamentarian who is in favour of racial hatred. There could not be one in the Senate or in that other place that we rightly call the lower house.

Since we understand that—unless Senator Spindler wants to make some direct accusations rather than skirt around the issue with words—we might agree that, if we are all opposed to racial hatred, all we are discussing is the best way to deal with it. We have made it abundantly clear that we think there are two things to bear in mind. Firstly, there is the need for an additional $10 million for education. It is clear that the government has moved this way in domestic violence areas. I would have thought that there should be some support for using that amount to combat this type of evil in the community.

The second point is that the essence of our opposition to the government's criminal sanctions goes to the way that the government has designed them—in particular proposed section 60. That is the section that Senator Spindler was referring to when he said words to the effect, `It is so often those who incite hatred who do so and it leads to violence. That is why we support these sanctions.'

Senator Spindler neglected to say that the consequence of supporting the government's criminal sanctions, phrased as they are, is that those people who want to express a view—and it may be of hatred—and who want to get others to agree; who are encouraging others to agree with their view, as repulsive as we may find it; who are not persons who want to go and cause any physical damage to personal property and who are not inciting any personal violence and violence does not flow—under the government's proposed section 60 that sort of person would still be liable to a gaol penalty.

Now, Senator Spindler may say, `But that wouldn't happen.' He might have more confidence in law enforcement agencies than I do. If you draft a clause that says, `This behaviour is criminal,' you cannot then pretend that it has another clause attached to it that says, `Hey, you'll only ever be charged with this if some other consequences follow.' If that is what you mean, that is what you should say in the clause. But it does not say that.

This is one of the great deceptions that have been foisted upon the ethnic communities—I made this point yesterday in my speech on the second reading—by people who should know better, people who should have taken the opportunity to inform themselves. Mr Victor Rebikoff is one of those and Helen Teischman is another who have consistently, either out of ignorance or design—I do not know which but either is unsatisfactory, because when you hold yourself out to be a community leader you should get across the information—portrayed the view that the government's bill will only apply when violence is generated, and that that is the aim of it. Either they have not read the bill or they seek to misrepresent the bill, and the sorts of remarks Senator Spindler was making just then continue to misrepresent that case.

The case we make is that proposed section 60 is an unjustified limitation on freedom of speech—not because you should necessarily be able to go out and say what you like, but you should be able to say what you like if you are not promoting violence. That is the point that Senator Spindler forgets and that he seeks to gloss over in the remarks he made. He seeks to pretend, yet again, that proposed section 60 of the government's bill would have only got at people who were promoting violence, when that is simply not the case. It is an untruth, and he should not be allowed to perpetrate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the minister a question in relation to proposed section 18C(1), which says:

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlawful for a person to do an act, otherwise in private, if:
(a)the act is reasonably likely, in all the circumstances, to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or group of people . . .

With respect to the word `offend', is it true that the national inquiry into racist violence counselled against such a low threshold? The minister might also take advice on what is meant by the word `offend'. Has the government thought of any definition as to what might constitute an offence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will check out for Senator Ellison the assessment made by the national inquiry into terms of racist violence of the word `offend'. Having said that, I would ask him to note the words just preceding that—`if the act is reasonably likely, in all the circumstances'—because in those words an objective test is implanted. That is a measure which has been put in by government to ensure that there is a level of reasonableness judged on an objective standard in terms of the behaviour complained of.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether that concept was before the committee when it was making its deliberations. My understanding is that it is a measure which has been reinforced in this legislation in the more recent development of it. As I say, it is a measure very much intended to implant objectivity and reasonableness.

In terms of the formulation of the clause and of the term `offend', I can take that on notice. But I must say to Senator Ellison that it is not inconsistent with similar provisions in other legislation, in the states and also in other countries. It has not caused the sorts of problems he is concerned about. When he keeps in mind that the preceding test has been implanted, I do not think there is any legitimate cause for concern about it being too loose.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just two questions on 18D, Minister. Dealing with the exemption of anything that is done reasonably or in good faith, firstly, who has the onus of proof in that case, who has the burden of proving the exemption? Secondly, with respect to 18E(2), does the employer have to establish that all reasonable steps were taken to prevent the employee from doing the act? If that burden of proof is on the employer, then to what standard is it required?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just picking up on your earlier question, Senator, in relation to that concept of `offend' which you raised in your previous inquiry, the same language is in the sexual harassment provisions under the Sex Discrimination Act; the concept of `offend' is in there as well. In order to allay your concerns even more, I can say that there have not been concerns raised in terms of the operation of the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Act and similar language—if not the same, but for one word—in that legislation.

PARA.TAB: In terms of onus of proof, it is my understanding that those who make a claim, either asserting the act or asserting the defence, have the onus of proof resting on them. I think that is a normal principle of law.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the `took all reasonable steps'; is that the case as well for the employer?
—Yes, my understanding is that that is also the case.
—Is that on the balance of probabilities?
—It is the civil standard of proof which is required, so it is balance of probabilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong the debate. Most of the things I wanted to say are contained in the debate on the second reading, but I want to respond briefly to some of the points that Senator Spindler made in relation to my speech on the second reading.

PARA.TAB: Yes, Senator Spindler, I certainly acknowledge that FECCA, the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia, does publicly support the bill. That has never been at issue and, indeed, I made that point in my speech. What I did say as well was that privately there are some differing views. You would not expect those to become public, but I do accept the point—and made it myself—that FECCA does publicly support the bill.

You also mentioned the Australian Arabic Council and your contact with Roland Jabbour today. I have not spoken to him since my speech yesterday, but I have had very lengthy discussions with him, Joe Wakim and other members of the Australian Arabic Council over a period of a year or more now. We have had written correspondence, and they have made public statements themselves as an association.

What I said in my speech yesterday on the bill was that the Australian Arabic Council, although less condemnatory of the bill than the Australian Arab Association, which I will mention briefly in a second, has said to us in writing:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe only (multipronged education strategies) seriously address the roots of racism and ignorance, whereas legislation addresses the symptoms.
The council has also said, and I quoted this yesterday:
In the end, the bill becomes a token gesture, or what some proponents of the bill would call an educational tool. The most vilified groups—
and, of course, the Arab community is among the most vilified groups—
prefer more substantial educational measures which permeate the most powerful institutions responsible for spreading misinformation which then creates fertile ground for racism.

So I just put that back on the record. In doing so, I also point out, as I did yesterday, that in writing to the coalition in response to our request for views on the government's bill, the Australian Arab Association wrote unequivocally, `We strenuously oppose this bill.'

PARA.TAB: I should also point out, and I mentioned it yesterday in my speech, that the Islamic Society of Victoria and some other Islamic representatives have also been critical of the legislation. I realise, of course, that not all members of the Arabic community are Islamic, although many Islamic persons are Arabic. There is a linkage there, and there is no doubt at all, on the advice that we have received, particularly from the Islamic Society of Victoria, that that organisation is opposed to the bill. I want to put that on the record without prolonging the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one point in what Senator Short said that I wish to advert to as I think it is quite important. It relates to the meeting of the national conference of FECCA in Hobart where representatives of the communities, on behalf of the communities, expressed support for the bill. In his speech Senator Short quoted communities, not private individuals. The question arises as to whether he has the authority of representatives of those communities to speak on behalf of the communities when he says that they have concerns about the bill. I believe it would be helpful if Senator Short could clarify that for the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was quite clear from what I said in my remarks yesterday, which I have just repeated. I quote from my speech yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Federation of Ethnic Communities Councils of Australia publicly supports the bill . . .
I cannot be any more categorical than that. I then added:
. . . even if privately there are differing views amongst its members.

That is a matter of private conversation, and it would be strange indeed if you did not have that situation. Any association, amongst its membership, has differing views even though they have a public voice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, there are differing views in the Liberal Party as well—not just in the federal parliament, but elsewhere. Can I come in on this particular point? Senator Spindler, in respect of the Australian Arabic Council of Victoria, I also spoke to Roland Jabbour on Saturday morning when I launched their media awards and awarded the first one. He was concerned that their position was being misinterpreted. Their position, as has been expressed before the parliamentary committee, is one that supports the legislation, but he is concerned in fact about the extent of the exemptions. They said to me that the legislation is not strong enough because the exemptions will allow action to continue which in their mind should be attacked. I think the very solid point made to me on Saturday, which has been made to Dr Sumic and the department since, is that they believe in legislation. They also believe in education, but they believe in the need for both.
—They are criticising your bill.

—They are criticising our bill because the exemptions are too loose—exemptions which your side in fact has endorsed, which you agree with. They are criticising you because you are not going as far as we are. There is a need for a bit of debate in this place. I think the impact out in the communities is that the more you misinterpret their position, the more they will remember you, but not for positive reasons. If people want to misinterpret their positions, good luck to them—keep on doing it. But they will remember you when the time comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to two implications from Senator Spindler's remarks about the Greens' approach to this bill and the concern about the criminal sanctions. The first implication was that almost all so-called ethnic community groups wanted the criminal sanctions and wanted the bill in the form that the government was presenting it. I, and I am sure other senators, received boundless mail to let us know that was not a correct implication. I apologise to Senator Spindler if that is not what he meant. That is the underlying assumption that I derived from his comments.

PARA.TAB: The second implication was that the freedom of speech supporters had won. I want to rebut that, at least from my point of view. I want to quote a letter from the Executive Officer of the Social Responsibilities Commission of the Anglican Province of Western Australian in a letter to the editor of the Church Scene. Mr Hall said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply not correct to say this Bill enjoys widespread support in the Aboriginal and ethnic communities.

In parenthesis I should clarify that he was writing it in response to the Multicultural Affairs Commission, which he believes got it wrong with its enthusiastic support for the federal Attorney-General's Racial Hatred Bill. He goes on to state:

The best organised ethnic groups favour legislation because they are well resourced, enjoy networks and senior positions that allow them to take advantage of criminal legislation. However, the majority of groups who fall prey to racism and vilification are not so well organised. Former Race Relations Commissioner Irene Moss recognised this saying, "It seems, that those ethnic groups most in need of protection by this sort of legislation are least likely to use it." The two groups that experience racism the most in Australia are the first people here, the indigenous people, and the last people here; and the most recent arrivals always seem to just slot in above the first people here as far as racist discrimination and vilification goes.

PARA.TAB: A critical issue is the bill's criminal sanctions. It is important how we say no to racist violence and say yes to a more tolerant society. Racism and incitement to racist violence is totally unacceptable: however, making a criminal sanction or penalty for offences of this kind is not the best way to improve our society and promote tolerance and acceptance of all people. Criminal penalties do not change attitudes. What we want to see in Australia is a positive change of attitudes, hearts and minds; the threat of criminal sanctions will not be a deterrent, or a positive direction in which to go.

The other major concern is the exclusion clauses. These protect the powerful institutions, the people who fashioned dominant ideas and who have the power to construct racially discriminatory images. The media empires, Hollywood film companies and universities are safe to continue with impunity.

SPEECH.PARA: I gave that lengthy quote because the last section is also of relevance. It points out that the government's concern to protect any accusations of limitation of freedom of speech has actually offended another group in the community which believes that it will allow the operation of this bill to again discriminate in favour of those who are powerful and who have access to resources. It will perhaps make it more difficult for those who are less favoured in those aspects.

PARA.TAB: The second point I want to make is that this is not only about the freedom of speech issue. That would have missed the point of most of my comments on this topic. In some correspondence to me, William J. Lines stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The laws do infringe freedom of speech and do introduce ideological bias into legislative statute but their most undesirable feature lies elsewhere.

Legislation designed to counter racial vilification will fail because the legislation itself fosters racialist thought. Although vilification legislation does not define race, it depends on the idea of race. Race is the legislation's central organising concept. Thus racial vilification laws do not serve so much to banish racism as to promulgate race. The law ought not to perpetuate such confused, dangerous, and gross falsehoods.

Racial vilification laws are crude and self-defeating forms of developing compassion and of overcoming aversion for otherness. The state cannot mandate tolerance. The state can only sponsor conditions (a civil society) where learning and understanding can flourish. And learning and understanding, judging people by character, not by external appearances, are the only effective means of overcoming racism.

I think that is the central point. It is the reason why I have been very pleased to see that, with the assistance of the opposition's objection to the particular forms of criminal sanctions in this bill, they have been able to be struck out.

PARA.TAB: I am not saying that I do not have concerns about the civil remedies. The concern I wanted to raise was that, in the anxiety to allay any criticisms regarding the limitations of freedom of speech, the legislation may itself be slightly facilitating of some people's access to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on complaints. It may actually protect others—for example, the radio announcers and the politicians who are free to continue to make statements that could be interpreted as being racist in content and could cause offence. I will not continue any further.

I believe these sections of the bill that deal with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission clearly send a signal that racial vilification is unacceptable in this community. They offer redress for victims of oppression in that regard. While there may well be some kind of query about their constitutionality, I believe the bill is just sufficient to warrant the support of the Greens and, providing these criminal sanctions are not reintroduced at some later stage, I indicate that we will be supporting the bill.
Remainder of bill agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bolkus) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)in the recent Queensland State election, the Australian Labor Party (ALP) lost 9 seats to the Coalition and now retains Government by a one-seat majority;
(b)the future of the Queensland ALP rests on the result of a Court of Disputed Returns decision in the Townsville-based electorate of Mundingburra;
(c)on a two-party preferred basis, the ALP vote was 46.72 per cent compared with the 53.28 per cent vote for the Coalition; and
(d)the ALP campaign for the State election included the now common tactic of the ALP of lies and deceit, as instanced by the disgraceful `hospital sold' postcard campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: This motion relates to the Queensland election and certain matters arising from that. It is a matter for any senator to speak in this debate but I indicate to the Senate that my Queensland colleagues Senator O'Chee and Senator MacGibbon—and, perhaps, others as well—will be speaking on this.

PARA.TAB: My motion calls upon the Senate to note the result in the Queensland election and to note further the quite magnificent result by the coalition parties at the election. In that election, as my motion indicates, the Australian Labor Party government lost nine seats—four to the National Party and five to the Liberal Party. As a result of the election, the Labor Party now holds government by a slender thread of one seat. There is, of course, one Independent, Ms Liz Cunningham, the Mayor of Calliope—a good friend of mine but an independent person who was elected as an independent. She has done a quite magnificent job in the Calliope Shire. She defeated the sitting Labor Party member for Gladstone, a community that was once thought to be a pretty solid Labor community but is now held by Ms Cunningham as an Independent.

Congratulations must go to Joan Sheldon, the Liberal Party leader, and Rob Borbidge, the National Party leader, who did a magnificent job in running a campaign in the Queensland election. They confounded all the political experts in the way they conducted the campaign and in the success they achieved at that election. It is really a credit to them and to the Liberal Party and National Party organisations in the way that campaign was conducted. As a Liberal, I must place on record the magnificent effort of the Liberal Party organisation and that of Mr Bob Tucker, the state president, and Mr Jim Barron, the state director, in particular.

It really was a result that was not predicted by most people. It was an election that saw quite dramatic swings against the Labor Party from the people of Queensland who were sick and tired of the arrogance of the state government, in the same manner as they are sick and tired of the arrogance of the Keating government operating out of Canberra.

The election is not yet over. As honourable senators will be aware, there has been an application made to the Supreme Court sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns in relation to the Townsville based electorate of Mundingburra which you, Madam Acting Deputy President, would be aware of, having your base in that town, as I do. Senators will be aware that the sitting Labor Party member, Mr Ken Davies, won that seat—or at the present time, has won that seat—by a mere 16 votes. There were a number of irregularities in that contest. It is for that reason that the Liberal Party has taken steps to overturn that particular result.

The Senate will be aware that of 2,002 absentee voters, 347 were not allowed the vote they claimed. They were not allowed it because, according to the electoral office, their names did not appear on the electoral roll. Quite a number of them do not know why their names were removed. A number of them have rung my office and rung other Liberal Party people saying that they did not remove them; they were on the electoral roll last time. One wonders how their names came to be removed.

That speculation was referred to in the Sunday Mail of 20 August in a paragraph which indicated that `some North Queensland ALP members were saying they are a little nervous at what a tight audit from the Liberal Party legal challenge against the result in the seat of Mundingburra might turn up.'

TALK.START.PARA: —They would turn up a lot of dead bodies.
—They would turn up a lot of dead bodies and that is still to be checked when we check against the electoral roll.
—There is nothing like sore losers.

—If you ask some of the journalists what that article means, Senator Sherry, they will tell you—you know there is a bit of scuttlebutt that goes around the journalists watering holes. They tell me that the Labor Party are a bit concerned that it might be found out that the Labor Party actually removed the names of known Liberal Party voters—just wrote them off. That is not my allegation. I just say to you that that is what this paragraph in the paper refers to. That is what the journalists are saying; and it would not surprise me, Senator Sherry, because those sorts of tactics are pretty well known.
—I raise a point of order. That is a very serious accusation for Senator Macdonald to make.
—What is your point of order, son?

—Just you be patient. I would suggest that under standing orders—if you want to be abusive, we will have to raise these points of order—it is not appropriate for Senator Macdonald to make those sorts of accusations; and he should withdraw straight away.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. As I understand it, my colleague Senator Macdonald was merely referring to an article that appeared in the newspaper. He was commenting on that. As such, I would imagine that would be within the terms of the debate in this chamber.
—How do you come to that conclusion?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order, Senator Sherry! I think that in all the circumstances, given the nature of the debate, Senator Macdonald, you should proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry comes from the union movement. He would know that it has actually been proved that in the case of union elections this sort of thing goes on. I do not say Senator Sherry has been involved in those sorts of things, but he is a member of the union movement and everybody knows that the union movement controls and is one and the same body almost as the Australian Labor Party. So this paragraph in the Sunday Mail would perhaps have little bits of truth attached to it. So that is one of the grounds, but we will look into that.

PARA.TAB: As this newspaper article says, a number of people in the ALP in Townsville are a little concerned about what a proper audit might just bring up. In addition to that, when the marked roll is available we will check allegations of double voting and dead people voting. We will have a look at that. We also want to look at what happened to the 20 Australian troops out there serving their country who were denied a vote. I understand that Senator Ray has been asked by Senator Newman, the shadow defence minister, just what happened there. We have not been favoured with a reply yet, but it would be interesting to see.

According to newspaper reports—the Townsville Daily Bulletin of 27 July—20 troopers, 20 soldiers, who were serving their country in Rwanda and who were registered on the rolls in the Mundingburra electorate were denied a vote. I repeat the figures: there were 20 of them. The Labor Party won by 16 votes. Soldiers vote all over the shop, but it is pretty well-known that the bulk of votes from the military forces go to the Liberal and National parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?

—Just have a look at any polling data. I am not saying that these 20 would have all voted for the Liberal candidate, but it is a pretty fair guess we would have got a majority of them. When you are only 16 in front and 20 have been denied a vote, it looks a bit suspicious. But let us look further. Mr O'Shea, the electoral officer, said that on 6 July the electoral commission had been notified that the troops in Rwanda had not received postal votes. That suggests that they must have asked for them before 6 July but they had not got them. That in itself is interesting. He then said that they were allowed to fax in an application for a postal vote. This arrived on 10 July. By 12 July, that is the previous Wednesday, the ballots were in the hands of the military. I will tell you this, Senator Sherry: if Mr Keating wanted to go to see the troops in Rwanda—

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I understand Senator Macdonald's concern at losing the election in Queensland. I understand that he is upset about that. But he is continuing his stream of totally unwarranted accusations, which are contrary to standing orders. He should be asked to withdraw those accusations.
—He has not specifically mentioned anyone.
—I am basing my point of order on the precedent you set in this place. I think he should withdraw and be asked to desist from this endless, ceaseless stream of accusations which are blatantly untrue.

—There is no point of order. It is certainly true that Senator Macdonald is making a number of allegations that are no more than allegations based on certain media reports, but I do not think I have any authority to rule him out of order at this stage.
—Thank you. I am sorry that Senator Sherry has put you in the position of having to make rulings like that. He should be chastised for disrupting the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I wish Senator Ray were here to answer this but Senator Ray is not here today. Do you know where Senator Ray is? He is up in Townsville greeting home those troops from Rwanda. He did not invite Senator Newman to go with him. Senator Ray has left parliament to go up and welcome the troops home from Rwanda. It is a pity he did not pay as much attention to allowing those troops their democratic right to have a vote in the state election. He did not seem to be too concerned about that. I say to you, Senator Sherry, that if Mr Keating had wanted to go to Rwanda I am quite sure the Australian military forces, the Australian defence forces, would have enabled Mr Keating to get there within one or two days at the very most.

The electoral commission gave those postal voting papers to the defence forces on Thursday, 12 July. I say to you, Senator Sherry, that had the defence forces, had Senator Ray, wanted those people to vote, do you know how he could have got them to vote? He could have got those votes over to Perth on any of the many commercial aircraft that fly to Perth every couple of hours every day of the week. Once they got to Perth they could have left Perth at 1.10 p.m. on Thursday, 13 July and they would have arrived in Harare in Zimbabwe at 6.20 p.m. on Thursday, 13 July. After that, it is a five-hour flight from Harare via Nairobi. My authority for this is Senator Herron, who went to Kigali via this very route. So they could have got to Kigali in a further five hours. Maybe that would have happened the next morning. You can get an Air Zimbabwe flight out of Harare to Nairobi. Senator Herron tells me they run every couple of hours. You then charter from Nairobi into Kigali. That takes a couple of hours.

So if Senator Ray was at all interested in giving those troops their democratic right to vote, those votes could have been in Kigali on the Friday prior to the election, that is, the day before the election. The electoral rules state that as long as those troops voted by 6 p.m. on the Saturday their votes would count. Do you know what Senator Ray's office told us and told the Townsville Bulletin had happened? The defence forces sent those votes to Kigali, so they tell me, via Brussels. Why would you send them to Brussels when you can send them to Perth and straight across to Harare? But they went to Brussels. They say they tried very hard to get those votes from Brussels, would you believe, to Kigali but the plane they had them booked on was cancelled. What a pathetic excuse!

Those soldiers who are doing their duty for Australia deserve to be entitled to vote. They were not entitled to vote. They missed out on their vote, those 20 soldiers, in an electorate that was won by the Labor Party by 16 votes. I do not cast any aspersions but I do say this: the defence forces and the electoral commission should have tried much harder to ensure that those soldiers who did want to vote were able to vote. They are some of the things that will be raised in the Court of Disputed Returns.

There are a lot of irregularities in that election—people coming in saying they applied for absentee votes in other parts but were denied them. With an election that is so very close one would wonder why that sort of thing happened. So the election is not over yet. If the Supreme Court should decide that there were irregularities, that the election should not stand, and if the court should decide to give that to the Liberal candidate, then there could well be a change of government in Queensland. So the Queensland election is not yet over by any means.

There is the matter that was raised quite a lot in the papers at the time of the poll. Mr Ken Davies, the successful Labor Party candidate, is, according to newspaper reports, being sued by the Commonwealth Bank for a large amount of money. The papers report that if Mr Davies is unable to pay those debts that the Commonwealth Bank says he owes them, he may he forced into bankruptcy. If he is forced into bankruptcy he would have to forfeit his seat in the Queensland parliament. So even if the Court of Disputed Returns application is not successful there may need to be a by-election in the seat of Mundingburra as well.
