The Commonwealth government is still the major shareholder in the Commonwealth Bank and we will be watching very closely to find out whether the Commonwealth Bank does pursue that action, those legal proceedings, brought against Mr Davies or whether somehow they just disappear off the face of the earth. I will be watching to make sure that no pressure is brought to bear on the Commonwealth Bank to settle some debts that are alleged to be owing in a way that is not proper.

I know my colleagues want to speak on this. Whilst there is a lot more I would like to say, I will curtail myself. In concluding, though, I want to refer to the final paragraph of my motion that the Senate is debating. That asks the Senate to note that:

SPEECH.PARA: the ALP campaign for the State election included the now common tactic of the ALP of lies and deceit, as instanced by the disgraceful `hospital sold' postcard campaign.

That disgraceful and dishonest campaign by the Labor Party, by Mr Mike Kaiser, the ALP State Director, and by the Queensland Premier, Mr Wayne Goss, has been published and written about in almost every media. It was a silly stunt that backfired enormously; it was just dishonest. Nobody could produce a skerrick of evidence that that was ever proposed by the coalition or any member of it. It was a direct and outright lie, yet it was done in all the marginal seats throughout Queensland. These postcards came out with a photo of the local hospital on them and with a sign across them saying,`sold', and on the back it said, `This is what the coalition wants to do to your hospital'—just an outright and direct lie that has not in any way been refuted by any member of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: I know that there are a lot of decent Labor Party people who were as disgusted with that tactic as most other Queenslanders were. But it is the sort of thing we have come to expect from the Labor Party these days. You just have to look at the New South Wales election. The New South Wales Labor Party quite clearly won that last state election on the basis of a promise to do away with tolls on roads. It is clearly said by a lot of the commentators that up to three seats went to the Labor Party as a bribe from that promise to do away with the toll roads. What happens? We find out a few months afterwards that Mr Carr, in the same mould as Mr Keating and Mr Goss, as soon as the election is over, as soon as they have won it, says, `I am sorry, we told a little fib about that. We are not going to do it.' And they expect the Australian people to wear that.

I tell you this, Senator Sherry: the Australian people are sick and tired of the Labor Party and Labor Party leaders lying to them, and they will not wear it any more. I warn you that, as I go round Australia and round my state of Queensland, people tell me that they just do not believe any longer anything that Mr Keating says. It does not matter what he says in the future, people will not believe him—and neither should they. Despite all the fine words at the National Press Club today and this so-called new approach from Mr Keating, people do not believe him any more; and that will be quite clearly shown in the next federal election.

I conclude finally by pointing out yet again that in the Queensland election, as in so many others, the Liberal and National parties received 53.28 per cent of the vote and the Labor Party received 46.72 per cent of the vote—the same sort of thing happened in New South Wales—yet the Labor Party are in power. And one has to wonder about those sorts of things as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the coalition on their very good showing in Queensland, especially the Liberal Party, which gained, I believe, five extra seats in the election. It certainly was a very good performance. I do not want to be too critical, but I guess I must ask what the coalition would have done if they had won government, because I am not sure they were expecting to. If they had won, perhaps they would not have been ready to take over the reins of government. That is a hypothetical question, and I need to get to the substance of this debate.

PARA.TAB: I note that Senator Ian Macdonald in his motion points out the very curious result in terms of the final percentages on a two-party preferred basis. On that two-party preferred basis the ALP vote was 46.72 per cent compared with the coalition's combined vote of 53.28 per cent. I remember that for years we had debates about one-vote one-value, and certainly that result again raises that question. But I might point out that, in terms of longstanding Democrats policy, had Queensland been operating under a system of proportional representation with multi-member electorates, the coalition would be in government today in Queensland. I might also add that the Democrats would have won at least one seat in Queensland under proportional representation, with over 30 per cent in Springwood after distribution of preferences. It certainly does make one wonder about that longstanding policy which, we have always claimed, gives the fairest representation in parliaments if it is followed.
I would like to turn now to part (d) of Senator Macdonald's motion, in which he says:

SPEECH.PARA: the ALP campaign for the State election included the now common tactic of the ALP of lies and deceit, as instanced by the disgraceful `hospital sold' postcard campaign.

Much as I abhor these kinds of tactics, I have to say that I think Senator Macdonald is right in this instance. There is a glaring need for reform in this area, not only in Queensland but in every state of this Commonwealth and certainly in federal elections—a glaring need for checks and balances on the substance and integrity of political claims made at election time.

PARA.TAB: The Senate would be aware that the Democrats have tried for some time to have amendments moved to various pieces of legislation which would bring truth in political advertising onto the statute book. In fact, only a week or so ago we had a forum at which representatives from all the political parties debated this very issue. We got, certainly from the coalition, a fairly firm commitment to move towards this kind of legislation, but the Labor Party felt that there were too many problems with it and, at least in Queensland, were not prepared to support legislation of this kind.

I also need to say that in that election campaign it was not only the Queensland Labor Party which we would criticise. We would also want to criticise the coalition, and certainly Mick Veivers on the Gold Coast. He lowered himself, we believe, by distributing what we believe were mistruths and, in doing so, gave further reason for Queenslanders and Australians to mistrust politicians and their claims and, therefore, to lower the credibility of all of us. That is why the Democrats believe we must put an end in some way to these kinds of political campaigns. With each of the major parties telling fibs to the electorate, how can we ever restore the faith and trust which people ought to have in their political leaders?

I must return to the pamphlet put out by Mr Veivers on the Gold Coast. I found it incredibly offensive, and it misrepresented the position that the Democrats took on the issue which he was dealing with. The Labor Party will have to defend itself, but the claims he made about the Democrats were simply wrong. I noticed that the opposition leader, Rob Borbidge, following the election, demoted Mr Veivers from his former shadow tourism portfolio to a junior and less responsible portfolio. I suspect that Mr Borbidge saw fit to act upon the mistruths which Mr Veivers letterboxed across the 20,000-strong Southport electorate in the last 24 hours of his campaign, against, I understand, his leader's advice and the information provided to him by the Democrats that his claims were factually incorrect.
Perhaps I could enlighten the Senate by mentioning a couple of the things that he said. He made this claim:

SPEECH.PARA: DID YOU KNOW THAT the Democrats have a Private Members Bill before Parliament to force all schools to teach our children homosexual practices?
Absolutely wrong—
DID YOU KNOW THAT Labor and the Democrats want to legalise homosexual marriage?
No, wrong again—
DID YOU KNOW THAT Labor and the Democrats want to allow homosexual couples to adopt children?

If he is referring to Senator Spindler's bill, that bill refers to the current legislation on adoption and continues the wording of that legislation, `that the welfare of children will be paramount at all times'. Another claim in Mr Veivers's leaflet states:
DID YOU KNOW THAT Labor and the Democrats plan homosexual Mardi Gras parades through the streets of Southport?—
Sorry, absolutely wrong, at least from the Democrats' point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Labor Party.
—I presume from Labor's point of view too, only I cannot speak for the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: So, you see, there is a problem. I do not make a distinction between the claim of the coalition wanting to privatise hospitals, or Mr Veivers's particularly misleading advertising, but both of them, to me, certainly lowered the tone of the campaign.

Unfortunately, section 162(2) of the Queensland Electoral Act does not provide a recourse against making such misleading claims—it is left to the civil courts. There is legislation but it is very difficult to enforce.

The Democrats would like to see the code of conduct for ministers and senators extended to political candidates. If nothing is done politicians will remain at the bottom of the list of respected members of Australian society, and that is very sad.

I trust that Senator Ian Macdonald and the federal government—and the coalition, of course—will give their full attention to this important matter to ensure that the forthcoming federal electoral campaign does not decline into a litany of lies. To that appeal I certainly want to add the scrutiny of all parties, including the Democrats.

If my colleagues are at all genuine about this matter, then they will give their full support to forthcoming Democrat amendments to the federal Electoral Act. Then Australians—especially the 95 per cent of young Australians—will be able to `trust' their politicians, as they should be able to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I congratulate Senator Ian Macdonald on finally realising the result of the Queensland election—that we had re-elected on 15 July a state Labor government under Premier Goss.
—Pro tem.

—On the sorts of allegations that you made, Senator Macdonald, you would have to say that it was pro tem. In relation to the allegations, particularly the ones that you made about people not gaining a vote—those people that weren't on the roll and the soldiers that were overseas—if you have any evidence other than allegations you should appear before the Court of Disputed Returns. You should go in there and test it out in the court like other people, because the Labor Party would be willing to accept the referee's decision.
—There will be plenty of people doing that.
—You are making the allegations. You say, `People know this.' It is a bit like the bloke in the red hat that you brought up in here at one stage—we had never seen him or heard of him.
—He just changed the legislation to catch him.
—You want to ring that number and do all the reporting and talk about the bloke in the red hat again.

PARA.TAB: Fancy a Queensland senator who comes from Townsville having the hide. We won the final seat in Townsville! Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds should feel quite proud that she lives in the area that returned the last member that made us the government in the state of Queensland. I suppose, Senator Macdonald, that you will have to report back to your party to tell them what went wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Macdonald was there running the campaign.

—That's right. We should look at a number of elections. In your notice of motion you talk about the Labor Party winning government with 46.72 per cent of the vote compared to the coalition's 53.28 per cent. You should cast your mind back a bit and remember when Joh Bjelke-Petersen was there. He was winning elections on 20 per cent and 30 per cent of the vote. That's when the gerrymander was working.
—He always had a majority.

—Yes, 20 per cent or 30 per cent of the vote because of the gerrymander—that's how he got the majority, and you know it! The difference with the Goss government is that Goss has put the electoral matters in the hands of an independent source. He has taken those matters out of the hands of the politicians.

PARA.TAB: Before the election I did not hear the Leader of the National Party of Australia, I did not hear the Leader of the Liberal Party, I did not hear a backbencher from either party, and I did not hear any senator from the Liberal Party or the National Party complaining about the boundaries.

You have to remember that the Labor Party learned a lesson in the election. We accept that. But I think the Queensland Labor Party are doing something about it. They have accepted the fact that the people gave them a message. It was not that the people wanted the National Party and the Liberal Party coalition to go into power. They wanted to give the government a rap on the knuckles, which they did.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know that?

—A survey was taken after the election, which was reported in the same newspaper in which you made the allegations. A survey was taken in which people said that they wanted to give the government a rap on the knuckles but that they really did not want to remove the government.

PARA.TAB: During the campaign Mr Borbidge said, `Give me a protest vote. Protest against the government.' At no stage did he say, `Vote for me because of my policies.' He said, `Vote against the government. Give a protest vote.' That is what happened and the government has learnt a lesson from it.

The names of 300 or 400 voters—I am not sure of the exact number—were not on the roll. It is a joke for Senator Macdonald to suggest that those names were taken off by the Labor Party or someone else.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't. It is in the Sunday Mail.

—If you have any evidence other than holding up the Courier-Mail you should appear before the Court of Disputed Returns and give some evidence. But time will go pass and we will look at what happened. I will bet anything you like—to every senator I would lay $10 down here that Macdonald doesn't appear and give evidence.
—You are a bit sensitive about this.

—I can't understand you. You are a shadow minister for the federal party. We're talking about a state election that the Labor Party won. You are a federal shadow minister for the Liberal Party. You have a motion here talking about a state election. You're wasting time. Why don't you put up a motion saying you are going to put forward some of the policies or some of the things that the federal Liberal Party stands for? Or don't you have any? Or are you a bit like Borbidge or Sheldon and have no policies? That's your problem—you're up here wasting the time of the Senate talking about a state election that the Labor Party won, waiting on the result of the Court of Disputed Returns. You are also wasting time in the Senate and not taking the opportunity to put forward any policies. You haven't got any and that's the problem. That's why they didn't win the election. They picked up a few protest votes but they're still not the government.

PARA.TAB: I must congratulate Senator Macdonald, because I think it's the first time that he's really realised that the Labor Party has been returned for a third term in the state of Queensland. I say to you: we are confident that we'll win in the Court of Disputed Returns and we'll go on for three years and we'll win another three years after that!

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to follow in this debate my friend Senator Jones, who is from the Labor Party in Queensland. I disagree with Senator Jones; this debate is important, because the lessons that the Labor Party should have learnt in Queensland in the state election, and which it will not learn—I will get on to the reasons why it will not learn them—are the same reasons why the Labor Party will lose monstrously when the federal election gets called for this country either at the end of this year or at the beginning of next year.

PARA.TAB: I understand that Senator Jones is busy and that he has work to do. It does not matter how many times you tell the people in the Labor Party what they ought to be doing to get the country on the right track. It is like throwing pearls at swine. It does not matter whether they are in the chamber or not. You can talk to them, but they do not always hear. That is the great problem.

There are a number of reasons why the Labor Party did so lamentably badly in the state election. Senator Ian Macdonald, in his motion, raises one of those matters, which is the postcard campaign of the hospitals sold. Honourable senators on this side find it very humorous, because we know that the only person who wanted to flog off hospitals at the last election is the state Treasurer, Mr Keith De Lacy, and he belongs to the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Faulkner. Veterans' affairs—he sold all the repat hospitals.

—That is quite true. I had forgotten about that. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) has made so many egregious errors in his time as minister. Surely he is only going to get one shot at being a minister. I had forgotten all about that one. I remember all the other faults that Senator Faulkner had, but I had forgotten that one.

PARA.TAB: Two ministers wanted to flog off hospitals, and they are both from the Labor Party. Senator Faulkner succeeded in flogging off the hospital at Greenslopes. Mr De Lacy did not get a chance to flog off the hospital in Cairns before the election. Heaven knows what he will do now that he is back in power. Mr De Lacy has flogged off just about everything else in Cairns.

Honourable senators would know that it was Mr De Lacy who sold the Cairns central school for a little over $10 million to get an inner city block of five hectares in the middle of Cairns. It is a beautiful site that has always been part of the Cairns community. He flogged off a kiddies primary school for a miserable $10 million because his government was so broke that it could not pay bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —How terrible!

—That was just the start of the wholesale auction in Far North Queensland. You would have thought that this fellow had an auctioneers licence from the way that he was carrying on. Everything that moved or did not move was up for sale.

PARA.TAB: He made sure that we got a casino, not for any great benefit to the community but to get extra tax revenue. In doing so, he desecrated Anzac Park. He flogged off the railway station to put in another shopping centre just a couple of hundred metres from the centre of the CBD. Goodness knows what that will do to businessmen in the CBD.

Everything is up for sale when the Labor Party is in power. Not just real estate is up for sale. Under the state Labor government, principle has been up for sale as well. Madam Acting Deputy President Reynolds, I know that on a couple of occasions you have had disputes with the state Labor government on a number of issues to do with Aboriginals and the environment. I pay tribute to your courage and to the fact that you are willing to stand up for principles.

Unfortunately, many people in the state Labor Party in the parliament in Queensland are not willing to stand up for principle. That is why they did so badly at the election. I had person after person come up to me and say, `I have voted for Labor for 40 years. I am going to break the habit of a lifetime because I am never going to vote for these'—I will leave out the expletives—`people again.' They knew that the Labor Party in George Street which was in power in Queensland was going to sell them out. That is exactly what it did. It sold out the workers.

Senator Ian Macdonald, where was one of the highest swings in Townsville against the Labor Party? Was it not in the railway estate? It used to be the bastion of the Labor Party. The swing was something like 20 per cent. The workers knew that the Labor Party had sold them out. They knew that their jobs were not safe.

For all the rhetoric that people opposite like to throw at Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the National Party, the Liberal Party and the coalition, the workers in Queensland in the railways knew that they had a secure job. With the Labor Party, all they know is that the story they get today might not be the truth tomorrow. That is why the ordinary workers voted heavily against the Labor Party. They saw that the Labor Party was increasingly pandering to minority groups who were not representative of the general community. Pandering to the minorities is the track record of the Labor Party in Canberra and in Brisbane. These are some of the reasons why the Labor Party did so badly.

They are also some of the reasons why the Labor Party will lose the next federal election. It does not matter whether it is Bob Carr's Labor Party in New South Wales, Wayne Goss's Labor Party in Brisbane or Paul Keating's Labor Party in Canberra; you cannot trust what a Labor leader says to you. This has been a long running saga of deception on the part of the Labor Party. For example, in New South Wales, in the lead-up to the state election, there was a fulsome promise by the leader of the Labor Party that he would abolish the tollways. He came into power and waited a couple of weeks. His hands then went up in the air, and he said, `I am sorry. I just cannot keep that promise, but I will keep some others,' as though that would be an amelioration of the deception of the people. He said, `I cannot keep that promise, but I will try to keep some others.' That was the promise that got the Labor Party elected.

In Queensland, the Labor Party made numerous promises. I do not know if I want to indulge in bet taking in this chamber. If I were a betting man, I would bet that half the promises that the Labor Party made in the lead-up to the last state election will not be kept in Queensland, just as the promises made in the lead-up to the New South Wales state election are being broken right now.

Where did they learn this tactic? They learned it from their great leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He is the man who promised tax cuts and then scrapped them. He is the man who promised to solve the current account crisis and who has found that it is worse now than it has ever been. He is the man who promised to solve Australia's savings problem and has presided over the decline of this nation's savings base from 15c in every post-tax dollar to 3c in every post-tax dollar. This is the track record of the Labor Party. It is nothing other than deception.

I said earlier that there was a reason why the Labor Party would not learn anything from the election. One reason why the Labor Party will not learn anything from the last state election in Queensland is the people they have at the top. As far as we are concerned, on the part of the coalition, the longer the Labor Party keeps Mr Mike Kaiser as their state secretary, the better it will be.

Watching a factional brawl in the Labor Party is like having a ringside seat at the World Wrestling Federation matches. It is wonderful. Mr Kaiser carries on like a pork chop. He says, `People who do not like my being state secretary can get out of the ALP. Any branch that has the audacity to criticise the state secretary ought to be closed down.' This is the sort of behaviour we get. That is why they will never learn anything. Mr Kaiser's ego is writing cheques that his intellect cannot cash.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't get rid of Mr Kaiser, please.
—As I said, I want them to keep him. This is better than watching Ricky the Dragon Steamboat and Hulk Hogan go at it.
—And don't forget Wayney boy Swan.
—What an asset Wayne Swan is to the coalition. If you put the Three Stooges in charge—
—And the other boy in the seat is Kevin Rudd.
—If you put the Three Stooges in charge of the ALP in Queensland, they would do a better job.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators might not know this, but I had the misfortune to come across Mr Mike Kaiser seven years ago in a youth debate in the Queensland parliament. Mr Kaiser's manners were no better than they are now. The man cannot string a sentence together without directing at least three pieces of invective at somebody from a different political party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a different faction.
—Or a different faction. Sometimes he saves his worst invective for some of his Labor Party mates.

PARA.TAB: A leader of the Labor Party in Canberra once said, `If you cannot run your party, you cannot run the country.' If you cannot run the Labor Party of Queensland, you certainly cannot run the state of Queensland. That is reflected in the results. Look at the disastrous health system. The same ideology that runs the health system federally is now running the health system in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the National Party doing with the health system in Queensland?
—I am glad Senator Sherry interjected, `What was the National Party doing with the health system in Queensland?' Senator Sherry, when you were still in your political short pants it was a fact that—
—He is still in them.

—I know he still has not graduated to trousers. It was a fact then that the coalition in Queensland ran a health system that was not subsidised by Canberra and where the hospitals were free. People got treated quicker than they are now with money supposedly coming from Canberra. Why? Because when the coalition was running the hospitals in Queensland the money went to paying doctors and nurses, not paying bureaucrats to sit there and shuffle bits of paper.

PARA.TAB: Since Senator Sherry raised the issue of the health system in Queensland, it is interesting to note that, prior to the last election, the pathology lab at Cairns Base Hospital had windows that would not seal, had an air-conditioning system that did not work and had mushrooms growing in the ceiling. The only decent building for the health department in Far North Queensland was the regional headquarters down the street from the hospital where they had the nice shiny windows, the nice furniture and the nice computers, desks and telephones and they got paid to sit there and twiddle their fingers. The people who delivered the services were the ones who lost out. That is why everybody knows that the Labor Party cannot run the health system.

Prior to the last election, we even had the state Labor government trying to defend the health system. They sent the short lived Minister for Health, Mr Elder, up to Cairns to explain the situation. When caller after caller phoned the radio station and said, `I'm afraid it's not good enough; the queues in the public hospitals are dreadful' his response—and this is beautiful; Senator MacGibbon will appreciate this—was, `Of course you have to queue. The hospitals are free. After all, you have to queue for anything that is free.' That was his excuse.

The problem is that the people of Queensland are having to queue up for a metaphorical slap across the chops. They are getting abused by the Labor Party in every imaginable area of state government activity. The health system is an absolute disaster. The railway system is a shambles. The government is busy closing down the railways when what it ought to be doing is providing the infrastructure to open up Queensland. The state government has pulled all the people out of the courthouses. They have pulled out ambulance workers. They have pulled out dentists and doctors. They have pulled out policemen. They have pulled out nurses from regional Australia. Is it any wonder there was such an enormous backlash against the ALP?

Add to that the fact that the main preoccupation of the state Treasurer is to flog off his home town to foreign businessmen. Is it any surprise that people get a bit disappointed? But of course we know that what they did in Queensland is entirely consistent with the Labor Party's infatuation with foreign investors in Australia. We know that the Prime Minister of Australia hopped into bed with some foreign investors in a failed piggery venture—an absolute lamentable disaster.

As Senator Baume has said in this chamber before, Mr Ole Jacobssen of Danpork is publicly saying that he regretted ever meeting the Prime Minister. This fellow who pretends to be the Prime Minister has the audacity to run around South-East Asia and tell leaders of very successful countries how to suck eggs. All Mr Keating should be advising them on is how to get egg all over their faces.

The arrogant interjections that we have had from the other side, such as the interjection about the health system, are indicative of the fact that the Labor Party cannot open their eyes to the truth. That is why they copped such a hiding in the Queensland election and that is why they are going to cop an even bigger hiding in the federal election.
I will summarise our wish list. At the top of our wish list is keeping Mike Kaiser state secretary of the ALP in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Too right.

—If we paid him he could not do a better job for us. People dislike the sorts of politics of personal abuse that Mr Kaiser indulges in. They should keep the same cabinet, headed by Mr Goss because Mr Goss refuses to listen to what people have to say. He is very good at swimming around in luminous wetsuits with dolphins, seals, dugongs, or whatever they were, but when it comes to making the hard decisions he always gives them to somebody else. He does not have the courage to make those hard decisions himself. He is like the Prime Minister; if there is something bad that has to be said, he fobs it off to one of the junior ministers, but if there is something good to be said or a new publicity campaign he will do it. If only Mr Keating could swim around in a luminous wetsuit with a dugong. I think the dugongs would have the good taste not to turn up.

PARA.TAB: They should keep the arrogance of the leadership and the arrogance of the cabinet because the people are fed up with that as well. Finally, all the Labor Party has to do as far as we are concerned is continue down the track of ignoring ordinary Australians; ignoring the aspirations of people who want to have a decent family life, who want to have a home and a car and who want to live free of debt. Those are the simple things that the Labor Party has to do—they are doing them very well at the moment—and the coalition will win the next federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep Keating there too.

—Keep Mr Keating there as well. We are quite happy to have him as the leader of the Labor Party. We think he will give us a landslide victory at the next election. Those on the other side of the chamber should keep him there. I say to those opposite: ignore those lessons at your peril.

—With the greatest of respect, all I can say about the speech of the only Labor person who has spoken in this debate and who has tried to defend the indefensible, Senator Gerry Jones, for whom I have a very warm and genuine affection despite his misguided policies and politics, is: once a party secretary always a party secretary. I do not feel inhibited in speaking on this matter before the Senate. The Senate is concerned with state affairs. We have a very interesting state of affairs now.

PARA.TAB: The greatest state of Australia is in the seventh year of gross mismanagement by the Labor Party. It is downhill all the way. There has not been one major development in Queensland since the Labor Party came to power. There is no interest in the government in looking for new business and new industry. It is still very much a branch office state. It is still very much a state that relies on its primary production, such as minerals, and on its agricultural and pastoral activities.

It is the business of the government to find new business and develop the state so that we can utilise the great assets and great resources in this marvellous part of Australia. All Australians will benefit from that. We are led by a government which is driven by factions and which has no policies other than the retention of power.

The other point I would like to make is that, through the election campaign, Mr Goss had the temerity to abrade the Senate and say that the Senate was falling down in relation to its functions and had done nothing for Queensland. I put out a press release which pointed out very clearly that in the six years of the Goss government I had never been approached on one occasion by the Premier, the ministry or the government of Queensland to negotiate or take part in the promotion of anything relevant to Queensland's interests.

I do not expect them to approach me for support in one of their grubby little factional deals or one of their deals where they are trying to do over their hated enemy, the Prime Minister, Mr Keating. But there are a huge number of issues which relate to Queensland and its development when it would be quite proper for the Premier, his ministry and his government as a whole to call in their senators and say, `This is something which is relevant to the development of Queensland. This is the point that we want you to defend and debate with the southern hordes.'

I have never had the courtesy of one letter let alone a phone call or meeting with Mr Goss or any of his team. I have always been prepared, despite their appalling political bent, to talk with whoever is running the state I have the honour to represent. So much for that.

Let us look at what Queensland was like before the election was called. We had the situation where the ALP had 54 seats, the National Party had 26 seats and the Liberal Party had nine seats. The Labor Party enjoyed a huge majority of nearly 20 seats. We had Mr Goss who was the most popular Labor figure in history—state and federal. He was Mr Seventy Per Cent. Everyone loved him. He was teflon suited and never put a foot wrong. We had a government which had a very strong majority in the parliament. There were no blemishes on their performance because they played a straight bat to everything. They undertook no social reforms and no economic reforms. Ultimately, the fact that they were a do nothing government was their undoing.

Their position was very strong. As all the polling showed, 75 per cent of Queenslanders—I even saw one figure of about 78 per cent—believed that the government would be returned. They had the resources of office which they, like the federal Labor government, used absolutely ruthlessly in pork-barrelling and in every other way to defend their position.

So we went to the election and the result was that the Liberal Party came out with 14 seats and an increase of roughly three per cent on their first preference votes—and remember that under the coalition agreement they only contested about half the seats in the state. The National Party increased three seats to a figure of 29 seats and got roughly two per cent on their first preference votes, again they only contested about half the seats. The ALP lost nine seats and ended up with 45 seats, with one Independent.

As Senator Ian Macdonald and Senator O'Chee have said, we have this appalling situation where the overwhelming majority of Queenslanders voted Labor out of office yet they are saddled now with a Labor government. It is not correct for Senator Jones to say, `That's too bad. We got the majority of seats even if you got the majority of votes.' It is even worse for him to say that all the electors wanted to do was give the government a slap over the wrist.

In no sense is the landslide vote against the Labor Party a slap over the wrist. The Queensland people had had enough. They were fed up to the back teeth with the incompetence of the Labor government. They did what people in a democratic society do: they voted against them. They ended up only voting 46.2 per cent for the Labor Party versus 53.4 per cent for the coalition—and, because of the gerrymander, we lost. The point is that the immorality of it is something that the Labor Party will not face up to.

The average swing against the government and the swing to the Liberal and National parties was 7.2 per cent. That, in historic terms, is a landslide. It cannot be described in any other way. One of the earliest results to come up on the night in the polling room was the count for one of the strongest booths in the seat of Mr Burns, the Deputy Premier. His face nearly fell through the floor when the announcer said there had been an 18 per cent swing against Mr Burns in his safest booth.

I have campaigned many times in Wynnum and I do not think there is a Liberal or National Party vote there. I have been abused on street corners more times than I can count, but that will not stop me going back whenever the next election is called. It is tough country. Generation after generation there have voted Labor. The area from Cannon Hill through to Lytton and south of the mouth of the river, Murarrie, is as hard core Labor as you will get. In that area, 18 per cent of the Labor Party faithful walked away because of the intense disappointment the electors had with the lack of action by the Goss government.

In the seats where there was a Liberal-Labor contest, the swing averaged eight per cent. Where there was a National-Labor contest, the swing was almost the same, at six per cent. There was only one three-cornered contest in the state, and again that was bad news for the Labor Party because the Labor Party eternally tried to split the Liberal Party away from the National Party and focused a lot of emphasis and propaganda on the fact that it leads to friction between the two. But we did the Labor Party in the seat of Barron River.

We gave the lie to the Labor assertion that a three-point contest leads to disharmony because there was not a cross word in that campaign. We took the seat from the Labor Party and the aggregate vote reflected a swing of nearly five per cent. There was no swing at all against Liberal candidates, and there was only a slight swing against some of the National Party candidates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why was that?

—There was a huge swing against the Labor Party candidates, and that is the thing we all know. Senator Sherry, you are not too numerate but you might reflect on a hard core Labor area like the seat of Springwood, in which there was a 19.5 per cent swing from the ALP to the Liberal Party. In Ipswich—they all love the Labor Party there—they lost 11.4 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not too articulate, Senator Sherry, but I thought you were talking about the National Party. Can I tell you that in Hinchinbrook the National Party got an increase of 12.4 per cent in their vote. Where will all your Labor mates be in the House of Representatives when you get swings of 12.4 per cent?

PARA.TAB: What went wrong? We have now, as Senator Ian Macdonald said, a Labor Party in power with a nominal one-seat majority. That one seat is the subject of a challenge before the Court of Disputed Returns. There are very serious concerns, and this is really at the heart of why this motion was raised this afternoon by Senator Macdonald.

We do have grave concerns about what happened in the seat of Mundingburra. A large number of voters on the roll—namely, in excess of 100—are members of the Australian Defence Force who are overseas at the behest of their government on humanitarian purposes. For some inexplicable reason, the Department of Defence messed up the Queensland Electoral Commission's first-class polling arrangements. The commission complied to the letter and spirit of the law in every way; it was the Department of Defence—and we will be going into this in meticulous detail in due course at the estimates committee—which somehow or other messed up the delivery of the votes from the servicemen in Rwanda. The votes did not get back by 5 o'clock on the Tuesday or the Wednesday, 10 days after polling day. Therefore, they were declared invalid.

You might ask, `What is 100 plus votes out of an electorate of 12,000 or 14,000—whatever Mundingburra is?' The relevance of it is that the vote in that seat was declared for the Labor Party on a margin of 16 votes. Anyone with any decency, anyone with any integrity at all, would have called for a re-election or a re-contest in that electorate, given the closeness of the votes and the disparity between the winning margin and the number of people who we can prove beyond any shadow of a doubt were denied their basic civil rights of voting in an election. That is why we are concerned. We have the Labor Party in power in that state, in effect, on 16 votes.

Senator Macdonald has referred to the number of allegations in the community about phantom voters, double voters and people being denied access. I cannot comment on that. It is a matter for the courts to decide. I am quite sure those things must have some substance, they just do not come up out of the air. It is certainly not the Liberal Party which is complaining about being bad losers, we are just objectively and dispassionately stating the facts of the matter.

What went wrong? What went wrong from a Labor Party point of view is that they stopped listening to the community. They were far more concerned with the perks of office, the smell of the ministerial leather, the committee chairmanship and all the benefits that office brings for them, and protecting their position in those leather chairs against the incessant fratricidal combat between the factions in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —They even had factional disputes over committee chairs.

—Everything. They were completely out of touch with the aspirations of the normal Queenslanders. Let us not buy any of this Labor propaganda that Queenslanders are conservative. Queensland is a very thoughtful state. It is full of electors who think about what they are doing and know what is going on. They do not want change that is irrational or capricious, but they do think about their politics quite a lot. I think they are better informed than any other state in Australia. They recognised that the Labor Party simply was not performing and they were going to change that.

PARA.TAB: They were aided in that wish for change by the people whom Senator O'Chee so aptly referred to as the boys in suits. The `boys in suits' is not a creation of Senator O'Chee; it is the public appellation given to the managing group in Queensland by the Labor Party itself. The Labor Party factions talk about the boys in suits. The chairman of the boys in suits is the redoubtable Mr Wayne Swan, the former state secretary of the ALP and now the member for Lilley.

Mr Swan has a very great reputation in Queensland because he is regarded as the mastermind who got Mr Goss into power after 32 years in the wilderness for the Labor Party. But what no-one in the Labor Party says is that the 1989 election that took the Labor Party into power in Queensland was an election that could have been won by blind Freddy or the drover's dog. It was quite impossible for the Liberal and National parties, in the wash-up after the Fitzgerald inquiry, to win that election. On that alone is Mr Swan's reputation based.

Mr Swan was aided by the two members of the committee. The first was the redoubtable Mike Kaiser, whom Senator O'Chee referred to so eloquently and with such affection; another apparatchik, a great numbers man and a great manipulator of the factions, but again totally out of touch with the Australian community and the Queensland community in particular.

The third member of the boys in suits is Mr Kevin Rudd who now aspires to be the member for Griffith in the next federal election. I have news for Mr Rudd. He need not be packing his bags to come down here. He wants to be looking for a billet somewhere in his old department, the Department of Foreign Affairs, because there will be no place for him down here come the general election. I cannot imagine anyone more out of touch with the community than that trio.

They have to take the blame because they ran the campaign for the Labor Party. They made these appalling errors of misjudging public taste and misjudging public tolerance. We had Mr Goss almost in tears in the debate with Mr Borbidge the day before the election when he confessed that the lying campaign over those postcards, which suggested that the Liberal and National parties were going to sell the state hospitals, had been a tragic mistake.

It all gets back to the boys in suits. It did not come from Mr Burns or Mr Goss; they would not have had the brains to think about that. It came from the boys in suits. They were a very, very great campaign asset for the Liberal and National parties.

I said earlier that the results demonstrated that the gerrymander is alive and well in Queensland. We have a situation where roughly 23 per cent of the vote went to the Liberal Party and it won 14 seats; the National Party won 29 seats on about 26 per cent of the vote; and on 46 per cent of the vote the Labor Party gained a majority of seats. The facts of life are that there is a persistent and longstanding gerrymander in Queensland that has survived over generations, and that gerrymander is delivered against the Liberal Party to confine it to a few seats in the capital city.

It is as strong today as it was in the days of Ned Hanlon, Vince Gair, and all the other apparatchiks of the Labor Party in the past. Until that is corrected it is going to be very difficult for us to win government in Queensland. But it will come in time because if the Labor Government sees its term out it will sink so heavily in public esteem that it will not get anywhere near a winning position in the next election.

Finally, I would like to congratulate the management of both the Liberal Party and the National Party throughout the campaign. It was a very well coordinated and cooperative campaign. To Bob Tucker, the president of the Liberal Party, Don McDonald, the president of the National Party, Jim Barron and Graham Young of the Liberal Party, Ken Crooke and whoever in the National Party supported him, I offer my thanks and my respect for what was really a brilliant campaign. It turned around what was a losing position for the Liberal Party and the National Party before the election and took them over the line with a majority of votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you lost.
—In all the circumstances, they are free of any censure. They are deserving of our praise. They lost, Senator Sherry, because of the gerrymander and for no other reason.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 21 June, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased today to take this opportunity to look at the issues that have been canvassed and are raised by these particular papers that have been tabled in the Senate by the President. A code of conduct for parliamentarians is overdue. For too long we, as elected representatives, have allowed the sins of the few to undermine the public's trust and confidence in the integrity of the parliamentary institution.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to note that, at last, a parliamentary working group has drafted two important sets of principles; principles that set minimum standards of behaviour for members of parliament and for ministers and presiding officers. These principles do not, and cannot, prescribe or legislate for honesty or integrity, but send an important message to the people of Australia that we share their concerns about abuses of parliamentary standards.

The question of whether we should have a code of conduct goes back to April 1991 when the independent member, Ted Mack, asked the Prime Minister in question time whether he would initiate the development of such a code. The Prime Minister subsequently asked the presiding officers to establish a parliamentary working group, but the matter lay dormant until the Marshall Islands affair—involving former Senator Graham Richardson—broke in 1992. I am sure I do not have to remind the members of the Senate who were here in 1992 what happened at that particular time.

However, the furore subsided and the matter stalled again. Then, in 1994, Ros Kelly hit the headlines over her administration of funds under the community, cultural, recreational and sporting facilities program. The working group was, not surprisingly, reconvened and work on the codes began in earnest.

At this point I would like to say that public trust and confidence in the institution of parliament were restored. But how can we ignore the subsequent impact of revelations in Graham Richardson's book, or the controversies surrounding Alan Griffiths and Carmen Lawrence? It is fair to say that the parliamentary working group has an obligation to the public on behalf of the federal parliament, and for this reason draws its members from both houses and across the political spectrum. The members include a cabinet minister, Senator Robert Ray, his Labour colleague Jim McKiernan—a Western Australian who has taken a very close interest in the recent controversies in Western Australia and particularly those involving his colleague Dr Lawrence—Democrat Senator Vicki Bourne, Independent member Ted Mack, Green Senator Chamarette, as well as Liberal Party and National Party representatives, including myself.

The so-called codes of conduct are, in reality, two sets of principles. Firstly, there is a framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers. This framework comprises nine principles, including: impartiality; honesty; the use of influence; gifts, benefits and hospitality; public property and services; and administrative accountability. The second set of principles consists of a framework for ethical principles for members and senators. This framework comprises eight principles, including: loyalty to the nation; integrity; and personal conduct.

Let me look for a few moments at the precedents. It is academic to ask whether the implementation of such codes of conduct would have prevented or limited the damage inflicted on the integrity of this parliament in recent years. But it is appropriate to put the code in a practical context. I turn to the so-called sandwich shop affair which involved then Minister Alan Griffiths and led to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) establishing an inquiry to examine:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)whether there was any conflict between Mr Griffiths' private interests and the performance of his public duties; and
(b) whether he authorised or condoned any inappropriate, improper or illegal activities by any of his staff in relation to the conduct of his private interests.
The inquiry found there had been no direct conflict or personal breach. But let me quote from its report:
. . . there has been conduct on the part of Mr Griffiths which does not meet standards which might reasonably be expected of a Minister . . .
And in relation to three specific matters it states:
. . . the inquiry finds errors of judgment and/or a want of diligence.

The report from which I was quoting was released just three weeks ago. As well as the Alan Griffiths affair, the report lists a who's who of Labor misadventures. There is Young in the Combe-Ivanov affair, Young in the Paddington Bear affair, Dawkins in his mother's shares affair, Young in the election donation affair, Richardson in the radio 2HD affair, Richardson in the Marshall Islands affair, Kelly in the sports program affair and Collins in the pay TV affair.

PARA.TAB: I might remind Minister Collins of the Senate select committee's report into the pay TV affair, which called for `a form of guidelines against which a minister's exercise of responsibility can be assessed'. Well, those guidelines now exist on paper, and we are certainly looking at them today in these particular issues that are before us. The specific code for ministers and presiding officers reads, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers and the Presiding Officers are responsible for the competence with which they handle their public duties, the relevant actions of their personal staff and their departments, and their personal conduct insofar as it affects their public role.
Further, it reads:

Subject to action taken by the Prime Minister and Cabinet, each House of the Parliament may consider matters raised by Members and Senators under this framework and a majority of two thirds of Members of a House will be necessary to resolve a matter.

It is worth speculating on the controversy now involving Dr Carmen Lawrence and how she—and her fallible memory—would stack up against just two of the principles outlined by the parliamentary working group. Let me quote the first on honesty:

Ministers and the Presiding Officers must be frank and honest in their public dealings and in particular must not mislead intentionally the Parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently by a Minister or Presiding Officer must be corrected at the earliest opportunity.
The second relates to use of influence:

Ministers and their Presiding Officers must not exercise the influence obtained from their public office to further their personal interests, obtain any improper advantage or benefit for themselves or another, or any promise of future advantage.

Certainly, the controversy involving Dr Lawrence raises more questions than it answers. Surely she kept notes or a diary, particularly on matters of tactics; surely she knew the difference between right and wrong. Such speculation is all the more interesting given that Carmen Lawrence's own colleagues signed their names to the code of conduct—what we are looking at here today. She stands to be judged by them as well as by the people of Australia. Her honesty and integrity are very much on the line.

PARA.TAB: Yet Dr Lawrence has an overriding obligation to this parliament and to the people of Australia to stop indulging in political and legal gamesmanship and to finally lay the facts on the table. As a minister of the Crown, she has no alternative. If she is not to expose any further hypocrisy in the Labor Party, she needs to be reminded of these documents that have now been tabled both in the House of Representatives and here in the Senate. Dr Lawrence must read those documents very carefully because her colleagues—in particular Senator McKiernan, who is one of the authors, and her ministerial colleague, Senator Ray—have both signed off on them. I hope they will come in here today to speak on this document and remind Dr Lawrence that she has an obligation to abide by these documents or further expose a great deal of hypocrisy within the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that my colleague Senator Tambling was going to go on much longer, but I enter this debate. I took a while to stand up because I thought someone from the government might have taken the opportunity to get up. But, seeing they have not, I am very willing to carry on from where Senator Tambling left off.

PARA.TAB: First of all, Senator Tambling gave an outline of this proposed framework of ethical principles for ministers and presiding officers. There is a separate one for senators and members, but I will address the one particularly for ministers and presiding officers at the present moment. It is a very worthwhile document that has been drawn up by, may I say, a very eminent group. I will read into Hansard the membership of that working group. There was the Hon. Stephen Martin, the Speaker of the House of Representatives; Ted Mack, the Independent member; Leslie Scott, Ian Sinclair, Roger Price—

TALK.START.PARA: —Crichton-Browne, is he on the list?

—I haven't finished reading the list out but, if you sit down and listen, I might even read his name out. The other members were Michael Beahan, Robert Ray, Vicki Bourne, Christabel Chamarette, Jim McKiernan, Margaret Reid and Grant Tambling himself.
—He is not there.
—He is not there, no. But that does not mean he wouldn't have done a good job of it and contributed to the working group if he had been there.
—I am disappointed.

—It is good to hear you say that you are disappointed but, if he had been there, no doubt he would have carried out his work with the highest integrity. That is the group that drew up this proposal. With those eminent people in the group, I believe that we do need to take some notice of what they had to say. I will just read a couple of quotes from the draft proposal. I won't read the whole lot, but a couple of quotes are well worth it. It starts off:

SPEECH.PARA: All Members of the Commonwealth Parliament are obliged to meet a number of ethical and administrative requirements in respect of their behaviour and personal interests.
That goes without saying, whether they have drawn up a proposal or not. Further down, it states:

The Prime Minister enunciates standards and determines the penalty for any failings of Ministers, but it is to Parliament and, through it, the people, that Ministers and the Presiding Officers are accountable. Ministers and the Presiding Officers are responsible for the competence with which they handle their public duties, the relevant actions of their personal staff and their departments, and their personal conduct insofar as it affects their public role.

The last Prime Minister to adhere to these principles was Malcolm Fraser when he took no nonsense from any of his ministers whatsoever and sacked the ones that stepped out of line and transgressed these principles.

PARA.TAB: I will repeat a couple of lines that I have just read out: `it is to Parliament and, through it, the people, that Ministers and the Presiding Officers are accountable'. So when ministers or presiding officers tell lies to the public—it does not matter about when they are to the parliament, because that can be dealt with by the parliament—it is obvious that they have to be made accountable. I am afraid that with this government we have seen example after example, with the l-a-w tax cuts and the Premier of New South Wales in recent weeks. I make the point that it is of the highest order that a framework like this has to be put together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't you oppose this within the coalition?

—Did I oppose this in the coalition? It came out of a consensus bipartisan group, so I will ignore that. But, out of that, nine ethical principles were set down. The first was impartiality; the second, honesty; the third, use of influence; the fourth, what you have to do if you are in receipt of gifts, benefits and hospitality; the sixth, ministers and presiding officers must not use official information for personal gain—I will come back to all of these; the seventh, administrative accountability, which Senator Tambling mentioned on the way through; and the eighth, compliance by staff.

PARA.TAB: You may remember that, in the Fraser years, the fact that a member of staff did the wrong thing was not an excuse for ministers not to have to tender their resignations, because the minister is in charge of the whole department and is responsible for the department. That not only goes to parliament. In private enterprise, a manager, the CEO, of a mining company or any other company is responsible for everything that happens, and that has been proven in the past even out there without principles like this laid down in writing.

The ninth principle is the continuing obligation after being a minister and after being in parliament. Having read what those nine principles spell out, I thought I might go through and see how our health minister from Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, stands up against those nine principles I just read out. I went right through and saw how she would shape up. But she has shown on publicly known and accepted facts—

TALK.START.PARA: —How would Noel Crichton-Browne rate?

—I am willing to debate. There is plenty of time between now and the end of this debate, Minister, and you can stand up and give your delivery at that time. But I am willing to debate with you any time anything and defend my colleagues on this side. I will do it any time.
—Including Noel Crichton-Browne?

—Yes, all right. Okay, we will debate it at any other time. Getting back to Carmen Lawrence, on publicly known and accepted facts she has broken eight of those nine ethical principles that are laid down by—
—You are prejudging her. Isn't this the role of the commission? There is a commission that has been set up.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. The parliamentary secretary at the table continues to interject. He clearly does not want to get to his feet and make any sort of cogent and coherent contribution to the debate. I think, in the interests of allowing Senator Panizza to get through his delivery, it would be appropriate that Senator Sherry be asked to comply with the standing orders in relation to interjections.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—There is no point of order in that it is up to Senator Panizza to ignore any interjections if he so decides.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for your support, Senator Campbell.
—What about the chair's support?
—Mr Acting Deputy President, are you going to pull that minister into line or aren't you?
—If you request me to pull him into order, Senator Panizza. I think you should ignore the interjections.

—Okay, I have been able to. I thank you for your support. I can generally put up with that rabble from over the other side. Anyhow, Carmen Lawrence has failed on eight of those nine principles. She has failed miserably. Presiding officers established, via the working group, this draft proposal and she has failed miserably—she has passed only one out of nine.

PARA.TAB: I will shortly deal with how she has done this, but I say up-front that there is no question in my mind that she should resign now—and should have resigned long ago. She has proven herself unfit for public office. She proved that in Western Australia by her actions with her loss of memory in front of the royal commission. She had done that very ably before she came over here.

TALK.START.PARA: —But she was a member of Burke's cabinet.

—Of course, she was a member of Burke's cabinet and, when the WA Inc. proposals were put on the table, she sat around that table. Yet when the royal commission came along, she could remember nothing. She has proven herself to be unfit to be a minister of this Crown.
—She forgot about $5,000 in her bank account, too.

—That is right; I am coming to the bank account. Don't worry about it; I haven't forgotten that one, Senator Campbell. So she has proven that she is unfit to be a minister and unfit to be a parliamentary representative of decent people of Western Australia, especially the electorate of Fremantle. Her own colleague in the state, Mr Jim McGinty, has said that his recollection was that she knew all about it—but I will come back to the petition that went in front of parliament over there.

PARA.TAB: I will now deal separately with the ways in which she has broken eight of those nine very important ethical principles. You have to put her actions right alongside these principles that have been set down. We will look at impartiality. It is now clear from the evidence given at the royal commission into the circumstances of the Easton tragedy that Carmen Lawrence, as Premier of WA, introduced the subject of the tabling in the state parliament of the petition supplied by Penny Easton's former husband.

That petition made false accusations about Richard Court, who is the current Premier of Western Australia. Dr Lawrence knew the date of the election and she knew that Labor was going to be rightfully thrown out of office in Western Australia because of what happened in WA Inc. and all that. So the only way the Labor Party could survive was to destroy Richard Court. What did she do? Instead of destroying Richard Court, she destroyed an innocent life.

Basically, the false petition was put down on a Thursday evening in the upper house of Western Australia. There were accusations about Richard Court and, of course, there were accusations about Penny Easton. Richard Court was cleared on the Friday by the police investigation. They came out on the Friday and said that he was cleared of any imputations in that petition.

By the Tuesday, Penny Easton was also cleared of any wrongdoing that she was accused of in that petition—that is, by some time on Tuesday morning. Unfortunately, Penny Easton took her own life some time on Monday evening. That is what happened with that petition. So on that document, Carmen Lawrence, the minister, was nowhere near impartial.

Dr Lawrence clearly wanted to counter the criticism and destroy Richard Court. Now I come to the point that Senator Tambling raised in an interjection. By putting the heat on Richard Court and Penny Easton, she thought she would take the heat off herself about the $5,000 she had accepted of taxpayers' money for travel which she never undertook. She banked the money and held it for 2 1/2 years. To a lot of people, $5,000 is a massive amount of money. To a lot of people, it is not a great amount of money. There are various degrees in between. In 2 1/2 years, you could file three tax returns but say that she filed two. I take it that she is not like Mr Keating and she does file her tax returns. If nothing else, her accountant would have asked, `Where has this $5,000 come from?' She kept it there 2 1/2 years before being investigated by the WA royal commission, which found her out and caused her to repay it. So she failed on the part of impartiality.

No. 2 is honesty. It was clearly dishonest of Carmen Lawrence to keep that $5,000 after she cancelled travel plans—totally dishonest. She could have repaid that money immediately. If nothing else, the first tax return after that occasion should have found the amount in her account. It is not a small amount. She went unpunished because a decision was taken by the police that it was not an illegal act. In my view, holding $5,000 of taxpayers' funds for 2 1/2 years in your own private bank account is on par with a recent federal pronouncement this week that $4,000 worth of sexual services for Graham Richardson could not be considered a bribe when it was paid by somebody else. I will not go into that any further. I think everyone knows about it. In Dr Lawrence's case, it is quite clear that she did not get $5,000 worth of services.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! You are really stretching it now.

—I am not connecting that with the other one, so get back in your box. It is quite clear that Carmen Lawrence did not get $5,000 worth of services but what she got was cold, hard, bankable cash. She then dishonestly kept it until it was investigated.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order. We have a royal commission supposedly set up to establish some form of truth in respect of Carmen Lawrence. It has not reported yet. Senator Panizza is supposedly going into some depth about issues relating to the matter, prejudging the outcome, which is one of the reasons why that royal commission was established. It is not relevant to the issue that is before the Senate. It is about as relevant as Noel Crichton-Browne's activities in Western Australia. He should come back to the issues before the Senate rather than talk about allegations pertaining to Carmen Lawrence which are before a royal commission at the moment.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I am simply going through the nine principles and comparing her activities to the nine principles. So I believe I am being very relevant.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—I think there has been so much debate on the issues both in this chamber and in the other place, and there has been a wide latitude in the other place today. There is virtually no restriction in this regard in either chamber, so I do not think there is any point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will give you an example of the $5,000 that was kept for 2 1/2 years. Within the last two weeks, I had a constituent in my office who was charged with offences against the Social Security Act. She was a youngish woman with a child of four years, and she had been accepting cheques from Social Security for some time as a single mother whilst she was in a bad relationship. She has been charged with various offences because, with Social Security, each cheque that you get is one offence. She knew when she came to my office that she would go to gaol. It was an amount somewhat the same as this, around $5,000. She had come to my office for my help in convincing legal aid to have her represented in court, to put her side of the story and minimise the gaol sentence. The matter is still in front of the courts; it has been adjourned.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, once this young woman broke away from the relationship, she secured a job, went to Social Security and said, `Look, I am coming clean, I have been accepting cheques.' Social Security charged her and she is facing gaol. She has already paid a fair amount of it back because she has been working for a while. Once she got some money together, she was ready to pay some back and at least make some arrangements. That was about the same as this amount of $5,000. She came clean and she was in much worse circumstances than Carmen Lawrence. Where is the justice in this world, where on the one hand you can have someone who got $5,000 and paid it back after 2 1/2 years and on the other hand you have a constituent like this? She has failed this test as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: I am not normally sensitive about such things, but the senator seems to be making allegations about a member in another place that are not supported by the facts. Some of his comments about this incident involving Carmen Lawrence and the payment of travel allowances are quite false. He continues to cast aspersions or impute motivations and almost criminal behaviour against that member. I suggest that he ought to be called to order. I am not sure what you think he is addressing, but I do not understand him to be addressing anything currently before this chamber.

—I understood that Senator Panizza was making the point over a serious of nine points of conduct. It was relevant to the context of the matter before the chamber in the sense that he was relating it to each issue as he went along. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will carry on. No. 3 is use of influence. Carmen Lawrence breached this principle when as health minister in the current Labor government she sought and accepted open-ended legal aid to challenge the royal commission into the Penny Easton tragedy. So I believe she has failed that one.

PARA.TAB: No. 4 is gifts, benefits and hospitality. Once again, the $5,000 was a gift that she gave herself by applying for money with the stated intention that it was to be used for travel. She then did not conform to the applicable procedures by handing back the money when she cancelled the travel.

No. 5 is public property and services. That would cover that $5,000-odd itself. No. 6 is official information. This is the only principle which I believe, on the information that I have and the current available information, that Carmen Lawrence has honoured. No. 7 is administrative accountability. She is accountable to nobody over that $5,000—not the parliament, not the public and not even the department of which she was the head. So I believe that was another failure.

No. 8 is compliance by staff. The Easton royal commission has heard of the prior knowledge by the staff working for Carmen Lawrence of the infamous petition and of the intention to use it to damage Richard Court. Dr Lawrence did nothing to stop the staff from continuing to deal with the elements of this disgusting affair. So she too is responsible for the staffers' obligations and neglect.

Finally, No. 9 is continuing obligation. An example of improper advantage is a former Premier of WA, now a federal minister, using federal taxpayers' funds to challenge a state royal commission, just because it is trying to find out the truth of what Carmen Lawrence once claimed about her advance knowledge of the Easton affair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which you are prejudging, surely.
—No, I am not prejudging it. I am placing the information in front of you. I am going through the nine principles.

PARA.TAB: I asked a question in the Senate quite some time ago which Senator Gareth Evans took on notice, but has not answered. The fact is Minister Lawrence got this allocation of $10,000 a day to try to knock the royal commission over. By the same token, your colleague in the other place, Graeme Campbell, has been taken on in a libel case by the DPP of Western Australia—and I am not judging who is right and who is wrong; the courts will sort that out. What is the federal government doing for your colleague Graeme Campbell? I have not got an answer from anyone on that. A draft proposal has been brought up by eminent people. I believe there have been a lot of failures by Carmen Lawrence. In the short time I have left—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about Noel Crichton-Browne, are you?
—If you have got something on Noel Crichton-Browne, you can get up and move a motion, Senator Sherry; and do what you can.

PARA.TAB: I will now list a few of the other members of the government and ministers who have failed in their obligations under No. 3, use of influence. Senator Tambling, I think, mentioned former minister Graham Richardson using his influence in the Marshall Islands affair, which caused his eventual downfall. That is a principle that he broke; and it is something that he stood up time and time again about. He rang the President of the Marshall Islands and used the excuse that he was working for his brother-in-law, cousin—or whoever he was—just as a friend. Can you imagine then getting through to the President of the Marshall Islands as a `John Citizen'—not using his influence as a minister?

I heard Senator Gareth Evans defend him in this chamber. I have called it the Gareth Evans defence ever since then. He stood up and defended Richardson on that basis. Senator Evans used the example that if he was going to his daughter's school to see the principal, he would be there only as Gareth Evans, not Senator Gareth Evans, Minister for Foreign Affairs. I would say that if he went to see the principal he would be right up at the front of the queue, rather than just having to wait his turn like anyone else.

So this government has made a full mockery of these nine principles. I go to No. 7 again, administrative accountability. Ms Kelly, the former minister for sport and recreation, was really brought to task. That saw the end of her. Senator Campbell did a lot of good work on that one.

The last principle I would like to mention again is continuing obligation. I believe that most former Prime Ministers have adhered to that, but I think there could be a few question marks on the previous Prime Minister. I will not go into that.

In the limited time I have got, I would just like to quote from the front page of the West Australian of 17 August 1995. I will hold it up for people on the other side in case they have not seen it before. It is entitled `MPs told of plan to destroy Court.' The opening paragraph reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Days before the Easton petition was tabled, Legislative Council clerk Laurie Marquet told MPs that the Labor Government had information it believed would destroy Richard Court.
Mr Marquet said that the Labor Party had information that it was going to use to destroy Richard Court, and that was passed on to Mr Charlton.

PARA.TAB: That came from a very independent person, and I know no more independent person in this institution, and in institutions of other parliaments around Australia, than the clerk. Good examples of clerks are our own clerks here. They are very independent. And I take the word of the independent clerk of Western Australia. I support this draft. It was drawn up according to those nine principles. But, unfortunately, judging from the pieces that I have read to you today, many ministers and senators on the other side have breached those principles. It is not too late to start today. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss the framework of ethical principles for ministers and Presiding Officers. I say at the beginning that one of the harsh realities one learns from being in this place is that you cannot legislate for honesty. You cannot impose integrity on people who have no integrity. No matter what rules, requirements and measures are introduced to enforce integrity and honesty, unless there is a capacity for people to be willing to accept those rules, to abide by them and not to spend their time trying to get around them, it is almost irrelevant what kind of facade is presented to give the appearance that all is kept above board in this or any other place.

PARA.TAB: It is my earnest hope that these proposals work, because there is no doubt that people of Australia have a very low opinion of their politicians. This is largely the result of one area which is not covered in this matter; that is, the persistent behaviour of politicians telling lies to the public of Australia at election time, of promising things that politicians know they cannot deliver, of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) saying he was opposed to these dreadful consumption taxes and then increasing his KST—Keating sales tax—by 50 per cent since the last election.

There was an increase in sales tax on motor vehicles alone by 46 per cent since the last election. So the hundreds of thousands of Australians who will have to renew their motor vehicles within the next year or so are going to find an increased cost, as a direct result of Keating's sales tax, of between $1,000 and $3,000 per vehicle.

It is no wonder the politicians of Australia are held in such low repute. Who in New South Wales would take any notice of any promise by Mr Carr, the state Premier, having won his election on the basis of a solemn undertaking, of two or three years standing, to remove the tolls on the roads leading to the western and south-western suburbs of Sydney, the areas where the battlers live, where the workers of New South Wales are heavily concentrated?

He won two seats in those areas, which gave him government, and he won them by deceit. They are the areas of integrity and honesty that these proposals cannot and do not touch. While we have members of this place, of this government, while we have the Keating government following the principles set down by their operations manager, former Senator Richardson, that they will do anything it takes—Anything It Takes, the name of his book—to achieve their objectives, then so long as you have that kind of person in government, you are going to have that kind of response by the public, with the public saying, `We do not trust these people. We do not like these people.' Hopefully at the next election they will not vote for these people.
