It is particularly disheartening, I suppose, to many of us on our side of politics, having been involved in telling the people honestly and up-front what we planned at the last election to do. Some people did not like it and, having been honest, we got beaten. There is a price, apparently, for honesty and that is defeat. There is a reward for deception and it is being in the Keating government; the Labor Party being in power. It is against that background that we have to see to what extent this draft proposal of a framework of ethical principles may increase the status and standing of parliament in the eyes of the public and, perhaps even more important, increase the capacity of the parliament itself to perform better than it has. These are the things we should consider when we look at this framework of ethical principles.

No doubt there are many matters to which we can look to see where there have been failures along these lines. There are many matters in this area where clear failures to behave according to basic questions of integrity have marred, have limited, have affected, the capacity of this place to behave and to perform effectively. I am not going to go through the great list of misbehaviour by ministers of this government or, should I say, ex-ministers of this government mainly—although there are still some around who, having managed to blame their staff for their extraordinary activities are still there, despite a matter that I will deal with later where they are to be responsible for the actions of their staff.

Let us look at the ideal situation, at least as seen by those who have prepared the framework for ministers and presiding officers. It says in this document that all members of parliament are obliged to meet a number of ethical and administrative requirements in respect of their behaviour and personal interests. A fundamental obligation in respect of ethical behaviour is to comply with the framework of ethical principles for members and senators. The word `comply' is particularly important. We have to see when we are looking at establishing new clear guidelines to what extent there has been a willingness to comply with the existing arrangements. This is of particular significance at the very top of the tree.

I agree with the proposition that the code of conduct on public duty and private interests recommended by the Bowen committee is accepted as the model for general application, declaration of interests dealing with lobbying, hospitality, benefits and gifts that are the subject of procedures laid down by successive governments. In general that is outstanding and sound. It seems to be directed at the small change and not the big bikkies, judging by the way people in the Labor government come into this place with very little, struggle to bring up their families on parliamentary salaries and then magically become extraordinarily rich. That certainly raises questions about what happens to big bikkies.

This document goes on to say that guidance to ministers on administrative procedures and requirements pertaining to cabinet are provided in the Cabinet Handbook. It says that the Prime Minister enunciates standards and determines the penalty for any failings of ministers. That is all very well; we have a situation where there are requirements and they have to be complied with. As I said, this word `comply' is very important. But when you start at the top, isn't that where you should be looking for guidance for the establishment of the right sorts of procedures and for the sort of behaviour that is ethical?

If you start at the top in this place you start at the Prime Minister. But the Prime Minister did not comply with the requirements of the Cabinet Handbook. Let me tell you that the Cabinet Handbook in 1991 required the then Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, to reveal to his then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the fact that he had invested $430,000—goodness knows where he got it from when he was bringing up a family on a parliamentary salary—in a piggery.

He was obliged to reveal all details of any changes in his assets or liability situation to his Prime Minister. He failed to do so. At no stage did he ever advise his Prime Minister at the time—this is in the middle of May 1991—that he had acquired this half interest in a piggery.

People might say, `Oh, well, that doesn't matter because three weeks later he resigned as Treasurer.' The fact is that the Cabinet Handbook requires that information to be provided to the Prime Minister immediately—immediately! There can be no rationalising the then federal Treasurer's failure to abide by the rules, to comply with the framework of ethical principles of members and senators. And when you do not find the Prime Minister complying with the basic rules that already exist, how can you expect his ministers to have any greater regard for decency, honesty and integrity?

On the question of what members of parliament, let alone ministers, do, no doubt there is a set of rules about their advising parliament of their interests. So isn't it intriguing, when you look at what the man who had been the Treasurer did. He went on to the back bench for a while to work out how to dispose of his Prime Minister and replace him, and while he was there he revealed some of the details of the transaction that he failed to report to his Prime Minister, in breach of the rules.

But how did he go about reporting it to the parliament? Mr Keating told the parliament that he had acquired an interest in a company that had an interest in a piggery. Of course, the facts are that he acquired a half ownership of a company that entirely owned a piggery. He was simply misleading the parliament.

But according to Mr Keating and his mates that is quite acceptable. You can quite clearly misled the parliament by saying you only had an interest in a company when you half owned it and that that company only had an interest in a piggery when it entirely owned it. You can get away with that, apparently, because that is the way the rules can be interpreted if you are of such a mind—that's the important point. If you do not have the basic integrity to meet the requirements fully and honestly, then, quite frankly, the experience we have with this situation is that it almost doesn't matter what the rules say, you will have people who are prepared to do what they can to get around them.

So we have this question of accountability and the question of to what extent this is being led from the top. And I must say that under this present government I have no confidence that any of these recommendations will lead to any improvement from the government and ministers in particular—I exclude presiding officers from this consideration at this stage. I have no confidence in these ethical standards improving the behaviour of ministers while we have this kind of example continuing from the top.

It is not just a question of Mr Keating having misled the parliament when he acquired control of his piggery group, but when he disposed of it only recently we had the same sort of problem. The Prime Minister himself who enunciates standards and determines the penalty for any failings of ministers has no-one enunciating standards for him and determining what penalties for any of his failings should exist.

In the absence of that kind of external control there is clearly a total absence of self-control. When the Prime Minister disposed of his piggery group it is now evident from documents filed in current legal actions in which the Indonesian buyers sought to have the piggery group wound up because of the extraordinary situation they found after they had acquired Mr Keating's half interest, that Mr Keating's half interest was subject to a memorandum of understanding for sale to Indonesians three days before Mr Keating announced in parliament that he had disposed of this interest not to Indonesians but, allegedly, to his piggery partner, Mr Constantanidis. Yet this was three days after a memorandum of understanding had been signed for Indonesian interests to acquire these.

Why would this facade, this farce, be done? Was it to avoid one of the principles stated here about the potential for conflict of interest—the conflict between private interest and public duty? Let's face it, had that sale been direct from Mr Keating, and evidently direct from Mr Keating to the Indonesian interests, Mr Keating and the Indonesian interests would have had to get Foreign Investment Review Board approval for that sale to be effected.

In other words, the Prime Minister would have had to ask his Treasurer to approve of a deal that would double the Prime Minister's money at least on his investment. All we do know from these documents is that for his $430,000 investment he got a return of about $850,000, even though the company had been losing massive amounts of money during his period as a half-owner and despite the fact that the Commonwealth Bank—the people's bank, the government bank, the bank that Mr Keating was the head of in political terms in this place—made a provision for bad debts of $4 1/2 million which the bank sought to keep from the public, to hide from the public by taking out an injunction against the Channel Ten television station in Sydney when it sought to reveal that fact the day before the last election in March 1993.

There is no doubt about the facts—the bank wanted the figures hidden. The simple fact is this: Mr Keating would have had to make public, had he revealed that he had sold the shares to Indonesians, that he was to get a benefit as a result of a government decision, which was an FIRB decision. There was the potential for a conflict of interest—the very sort of ethical issue raised in this framework that we are now dealing with.

What I am saying to this chamber is this: it is so easy for people of a mind who wish to get around the rules to do so. In this case, Mr Keating purported to sell his interests to his piggery partner, who then magically a couple of days later on-sold it to Indonesians, when in fact the transaction was patently a direct matter where Mr Keating's interests were bought by Indonesians, as is evident from the draft memorandum of understanding of three days before Mr Keating's disposal of those shares.

When Mr Keating agreed to dispose of his shares and when the Indonesians agreed to buy them, that memorandum of understanding three days before the sale took place indicated that there was a repurchase option—it was a repurchase option not just a purchase option. Obviously you cannot repurchase something unless you have sold it.

The only person who was in that case eligible to exercise that option was Mr Keating, but he was not named in the option. The option was that an unnamed person was to be nominated either by Mr Constantinidis—Mr Keating's piggery partner, who I might say has managed to breach something like five different statutes, both state and federal, while running Mr Keating's piggery—or, failing him, by Mr Coudounaris, who just happens to be not only Mr Keating's solicitor but the secretary of Mr Keating's family company. Isn't it remarkable that this unnamed person was to have a repurchase option when the only person who had sold anything, as I have said, was Mr Keating? He therefore was the only person eligible to repurchase.

I noted with amusement that, when the final document was eventually signed on 17 March, `repurchase option' had been altered to `purchase option'. Obviously, when the solicitors looked at it in greater detail, they realised that the word `repurchase' in the draft gave the whole game away. At no stage has Mr Keating ever responded to the repeated requests that I have made here, and I do not know whether the press gallery has had the intestinal fortitude to ask Mr Keating about this matter. At no stage has he ever deigned to indicate whether he is the unnamed person who has the repurchase option—he has never denied it either.

The reason this is of significance is that an option to purchase is an interest within the meaning of the word `interest' as far as declarations of interest for parliamentarians go. Yet there is no such declaration of interest, and no indication that he may well have access to such a repurchase option in his declarations of interest to this parliament. As I said, he did not tell Mr Hawke what he was obliged to tell him. He did not tell the parliament in an honest, full and proper way what he was supposed to tell the parliament when he bought his half interest in this disastrous piggery. He did not tell the parliament. He did not abide by the rules. He certainly did not abide by the principles when he disposed of it.

My concerns are clearly these: if we have this willingness and enthusiasm to breach ethical standards from the very top of this government, how can we expect ministers like former Minister Kelly, for example, to stick by any standards that are acceptable? I suppose it is unfortunate for her that, considering the way she misled the parliament by saying that all these sports rorts payments had fitted into the criteria when they had not, she got caught out.

Quite frankly, she could have got away—as Senator Richardson, who initiated this procedure, had got away with it for years—with quite improperly handing out many millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to marginal seats irrespective of whether the proposals for facilities were appropriate or in their best interests or would have served Australia best. They went to marginal seats. This massive, multi-million dollar rort could have gone on. It only ended because—I am grateful to him—the Auditor-General took up the concerns that I and some others, particularly Senator Campbell, had expressed about this sort of thing in Senate estimates for something like four years. They kept getting away with it for four years.
I do not know to what extent we would look at this guideline, which says that ministers should not do things that bring particular benefits. I will read it:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers . . . must not exercise the influence obtained from their public office to further their personal interests.

We have already dealt with that with the piggery. It is curious to note that the Danish people involved in the piggery joint venture only really wanted to get involved and only signed the deal ultimately after Mr Keating had become Prime Minister in April 1992. They obviously took the view that there was some political benefit in doing a deal with a company half owned by the Prime Minister. They had not signed it when he was a backbencher. But doing a deal with the Prime Minister obviously has some `benefits'.

PARA.TAB: What is of great concern is that Mr Keating, having paid $430,000 for his half interest before the Danes had signed their joint venture deal, could then double his money after the Danes had signed the joint venture deal. They only signed that joint venture deal after Mr Keating became Prime Minister.

Nothing else was going favourably for the company. It was losing millions. There is the potential for a conflict of interests in the sense that Mr Keating's personal interests were served by his company signing a joint venture deal with the Danes after he became Prime Minister. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Ministers . . . must not . . . obtain any improper advantage or benefit for themselves or another, or any promise of future advantage.

I should perhaps move away from the Prime Minister because he is not the only minister who is interested in providing advantage. For example, I sought to move from my Wollongong electorate office after my lease had expired to the Camden/Narellan area in New South Wales for some very good personal reasons. For example, having a house there is a pretty good reason, apart from the fact that my wife and her children and grandchildren live in that region. I was banned from moving there, despite the Department of Administrative Services supporting and recommending the move, because the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Frank Walker, did not want me to have my office in a Labor marginal seat. He was seeking a direct political benefit by ignoring the recommendations of his department.

PARA.TAB: This is the sort of unethical situation that exists in this government. I have been forced to move into Sydney at a nominal rent—something like three times the size what it would have cost to be in the Camden/Narellan area. I might say how gratifying it is in the circumstances that the Labor man the minister was trying to protect has lost his preselection. Here we have a situation where you cannot, as I said, legislate for honesty. If you have a government made up of ministers who have no concern for basic integrity, there is nothing in this framework which will force them to have it. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! The time allocated for the consideration of general business having almost expired, the Senate will proceed to the consideration of committee reports and government responses.
Consideration resumed from 30 June, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the report be adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
The response read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE BY MS YOLANDA BROOKS AGREED TO BY MS BROOKS AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF 28 FEBRUARY 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: I wish to raise a matter of concern to me in relation to two speeches by Senator Ian Macdonald in the Senate on 18 November 1993 and 28 June 1994.
I wish to seek redress under the Resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988 relating to the protection of persons referred to in the Senate (Privilege Resolution 5).
I apologise for not submitting a response earlier but I was not aware that I could do so.

My concerns relate to references by the Senator to the dismissal of the Shire Clerk of the Whitsunday Shire Council in Queensland. The Senator revealed the content of affidavits that are still in the jurisdiction of the courts. The affidavits referred to were filed in the Supreme Court relating to reasons why four councillors moved to terminate my position. The hearing is still pending. The purpose of the court hearing was to determine whether or not my position was terminated for being a "whistleblower".
The following is a brief history of events which are pertinent:
1.I was appointed by the Whitsunday Shire Council as Shire Clerk in September 1992, commencing duties on 16 November 1992.
2.I was selected from 45 other applicants for the position and I was the only woman applicant.

3.I am a qualified Municipal Clerk and have been since 1971. I hold the Clerk's Certificate for Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. I am a member of the Institute of Municipal Management, member of the International City Managers Association and hold a Continuing Programme Development Certificate. I have been awarded by the Institute of Municipal Management two overseas study fellowships; one was to study office automation extensively throughout the USA and the other was to study occupational health and safety legislation throughout Australia and New Zealand. I have also studied garbage disposal throughout China with the Australia China Foundation Society.

4.I have held various positions in Local Government since 1971: Chief Administrative Officer, City Accountant for 7 years, Deputy Town Clerk for a period over 11 years; assisted the Chairman of the Local Government Commission in Melbourne in relation to research into feasibility studies of amalgamation proposals of councils, and more recently Shire Clerk and Chief Executive Officer.

My principal employers have been the City of Collingwood in Victoria—17 years, the Local Government Commission, Victoria—4 years, the Shire of Narrabri, New South Wales—approximately 2 years, and the Whitsunday Shire Council from November 1992 to the present.
The above is a list of all my employers since commencing my career in local government. My position has never been terminated prior to 12 July 1993.
A brief account of events between 1992 and the present will I believe assist.

Shortly after commencing with the Whitsunday Shire Council I was required to investigate the disappearance of the pecuniary interest register. This investigation included internal investigations and led to police investigations culminating in my alerting the Criminal Justice Commission in my capacity as Shire Clerk. Whilst this matter was ultimately resolved it precipitated the beginning of political, administrative and internal problems which have plagued me ever since.

There has been ongoing and continuing contact with the Criminal Justice Commission (C.J.C.) over a number of matters during my period of employment. The matters which were reported to the C.J.C. all related to pecuniary interest.

The series of events mentioned above culminated in four councillors moving to terminate my position on 12 July 1993. What followed was industrial action, intervention by the Criminal Justice Commission, Minister for Local Government, the Attorney-General and other legal intervention which is still ongoing.
1.On 18 November 1993 Senator Ian Macdonald said:
"The council voted, for reasons I will not go into, to dismiss the shire clerk because members of the council were not able to work with her, and for other reasons". (Senate Hansard, p. 3121)
This comment is damaging to my reputation. This is particularly so when it is read in the context of the speech as a whole.
2.On 28 June 1994 Senator Ian Macdonald again referred to the matter (Senate Hansard, pp. 2186-2188).

I do not believe that the Senator's version of the circumstances is an accurate reflection of the situation. The revealing of the content of the affidavits by my opponents prior to the court hearing has been damaging to me personally and professionally. It has been an attempt to prejudice my position but it does not reflect the extraordinary circumstances that existed at work.

The speech on 28 June 1994 has given an opportunity for a local paper to publish the transcript verbatim from Hansard. It took two full pages on 6 July 1994, all page 1 and 3. There was also a front page Editorial on 13 July 1994. This exercise is particularly interesting when it is known that one of the persons who gave an affidavit along the lines mentioned was the Editor of the Whitsunday Times.
The allegations against me are without basis in fact. The publication of the material has had direct detrimental impact on me.

By making the affidavits of my opponents public it has no doubt affected the public perception of my professional credibility and has done irreparable damage to my future career in local government or indeed any future employment prospects I may have had. The affidavits referred to portray a completely different situation to that which pertained at work, the seniority of my position and the extent and degree of my responsibility as the Shire Clerk.
I have high moral expectations and am an extremely hard working individual. I find the insinuations totally offensive.
Senator Ian Macdonald's remarks in relation to my general competence and unwanted sexual advances were completely unnecessary and unwarranted.

The comment "dispute between elected councillors and the Shire Clerk" implies that there was a problem between "all" councillors and the Shire Clerk. This statement is not true. The Shire Clerk had the support of 5 of 9 councillors and all indoor and outdoor employees, as well as a good part of the community. This was witnessed by "all" employees going on strike etc. Therefore, reference to the "council" when the council was so divided is misleading.

Reference to the campaign of smear and innuendo is exactly what these ex-councillors are doing to me . . . the opportunity that Senator Ian Macdonald has given these persons by revealing their affidavits in the Senate pre-empts the decision of the court. Indeed even though the court may find in my favour the adverse, negative publicity has irrevocably damaged my credibility, and caused exceptional private hardship financially, emotionally, physically and socially. The statements by Senator Ian Macdonald are incorrect and the publication of his speech in the local paper, the Whitsunday Times, is damaging to my proven reputation as an honest and hard working person.

During the period March 1994 to May 1994 negotiations between council and my solicitors continued in relation to settling outstanding matters. The transcript of the Senator's speech in the Whitsunday Times inflamed the situation, new councillors were embarrassed, it tarnished their view and alienated them in some way which was apparent in the manner some of them spoke to me.

In carrying out my duties I did no more or less than any other person in my position was required to do according to law. It is my impression that one reason I was appointed was because certain councillors felt that they could "bully" me to be a "rubber stamp" rather than what was required from a professional Shire Clerk.

In summing up, Senator Ian Macdonald has no personal knowledge of this council's procedures or operations. He does not know me personally, nor has he had discussions with me. He has no direct knowledge of my performance as Shire Clerk. He has relied on biased opinion and secondhand information. No attempt has been made to substantiate the allegations levelled against me mainly by former councillors who were subsequently not elected at the last council elections held in March 1994.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 June, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to discuss the government response which is before us. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee inquired into both the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 and the Family Law Reform Bill (No. 2) 1994, which was an exposure draft. Senators may recall that the committee delivered a report on that legislation. As a result of that report there were further requests from the community at large to have further input into those two pieces of proposed legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee quite properly considered that further hearings ought to be held. It is quite clear that in the community at large the question of family law legislation and proposed changes to it are of vital interest and concern to people. At the end of the day, the legislation deals with the very fabric of our society—that is, the family unit.

The committee considered a number of proposals. For those who might be interested, I refer to the second report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee at pages 14 and 15 where there is a summary of the evidence in relation to the question of whether grandparents' interests ought to be specially recognised in the Family Law Act. It is to that matter that I will address my remarks this evening.

The committee had the pleasure of hearing from Mr Robert Payne, Vice-President of the Grandparent Action Group of Western Australia, and Mr Brian Lane of the Grandparent Action Group of Western Australia. I believe those two gentlemen put to the committee a very cogent argument.

Yesterday I had the pleasure of meeting with Mrs Di Underwood and other members of a grandparents action group based in the eastern states who had a similar point of view. I am pleased to say that in conclusion—and this is shown on page 20 of the report at recommendation 1—the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the specification of grandparents be considered as an amendment to section 69C of the Family Law Reform Bill 1994.

That recommendation was signed off by the chair of the committee, Labor senator, Barney Cooney. In fact, there was unanimous support from the Labor, Democrat, Liberal and National Party senators for that recommendation.

PARA.TAB: The government response of June 1995 quite frankly astounds me and a number of other people. The government response stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Committee has asked the Government to give consideration to the specification of grandparents in the Family Law Act, in particular in proposed section 69C.

The Government agrees that more should be done to encourage separating parents to consider the beneficial role that grandparents may play, and will address this issue in the educational campaign accompanying the reforms contained in the Bill. While recognising the valuable role that grandparents may play, the Government believes that this legislation needs to present a proper balance, consistent with the theme of the child's best interests, and not unduly limit the Court's consideration of the best interests of the child in an individual case. The Government is concerned that an amendment to the proposed section 69C might detract from that fundamental theme.

The government agrees that more ought be done in recognising the very important role that grandparents play when families, unfortunately, disintegrate. Often, the children of those relationships do seek solace and guidance from the grandparents involved. Grandparents today are playing a greater role within the community and with the assisting of bringing up young children where there has been dislocation in the family due to separation between the partners.

PARA.TAB: We as a committee saw the cogency of the argument of simply inserting the word `grandparents' in the new proposed section 69C. That would have put the word `grandparents' simply in front of the term `other persons'. It would not in fact change the law in any substantive way but would give recognition and consideration to the very real role that grandparents play within the community and in assisting children when they are unfortunately dislocated by family break-up.

The response of the government is, quite frankly, unbelievable. It is the sort of stuff that Sir Humphrey Appleby would be very proud of. Whilst accepting everything that is said about the role of grandparents and the importance of the role they play, they somehow come to a conclusion completely divorced from the facts and completely divorced from the evidence that was before our committee. Indeed, there is in fact nothing that would detract from the fundamental theme that the best interests of the child ought be looked after by recognising the very important role that grandparents play. I unashamedly support the proposal of the Grandparents Action Group of Western Australia and of New South Wales and the number of other groups that have been established around Australia in recent times.

All of us would be aware through our electoral offices of unfortunate situations where, because of family dislocation, grandparents have been dealt out of care for the children that are the subject of Family Court proceedings. Having been, and still being in fact, a practitioner in the area of family law, I suppose I have a greater understanding of that than I would gain simply through my electoral office.

The role that grandparents play is one that ought be recognised, fostered and supported by anybody who really and genuinely has the best interests of children at heart. For the government to say that somehow by recognising the role of grandparents you diminish the importance of the best interests of the child is really to engage in bureaucratic mumbo jumbo which is based on the view that it is too hard to amend the legislation or they are not really bothered with it. It is a very simple amendment which will not change the substantive law but give legislative recognition to the important role of grandparents.

I am genuinely disappointed in the way the government has approached this matter. To say that they will address it through the education campaign under the legislation is, with respect, to not deal with the issue as it ought be dealt with. We so often hear from the government that legislation is not only about the cold law but also very important for educative purposes, that legislation and the words in legislation play an important role in educating the community. To a certain extent, I agree.

But if that is the government view, why are they not willing to recognise the role of grandparents in educating the community as well? When men and women separate, they should give consideration to the role of grandparents who are often the mainstay and the anchor sheet for the young children who suffer the unfortunate consequences of family separation. I would urgently ask the government to reconsider its approach to this matter on behalf of the hundreds, if not thousands, of grandparents around Australia who are very genuinely disappointed by its stance.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 28 June, on motion by Senator Ferguson:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report from the Senate Economics References Committee deals with a most important matter—that is, the tax treatment of small business. It is widely acknowledged that the role of small business in Australia is probably far more important than in any other industrialised or developed country in the world. Australian small business is by far the greatest employer and contributes far more to the economy than, to my knowledge, in any other country.

PARA.TAB: According to the statistics, as I understand it—and depending on your definition of small business—it accounts for about 96 per cent of all businesses in Australia and employs about 3 million out of the 5.5 million people employed in the private sector. Of those enterprises, about 74 per cent employ fewer than five people. As we can see, it provides employment to millions of Australians.

According to research prepared for the industry task force, small firms in Australia have been the source of almost all private sector employment growth since 1991. So when the government boasts of the enormous increases in employment, which have still left a horrendous level of unemployment, we see that it is basically in small business. The task force predicted that most new jobs created in Australia up to the year 2000 will be generated by small to medium enterprises.

As this report notes, with unemployment still a major problem facing the Australian community, support for the important small to medium enterprises sector takes on added meaning, especially because of the potential for them to become increasingly important contributors to Australia's expanding export base. It is worth noting that the other fact that emerges from this situation is that small business is the most vulnerable in Australia not only to economic swings and roundabouts but also to offensive, intrusive and damaging government intervention.

If we are to depend on small business for increasing employment, this report shows how vulnerable the prospect of increasing jobs growth and reducing unemployment really is. I think this report is of particular significance because it deals with some of the problems that still exist and which I believe must be corrected, if we are to have healthy growth in small business bringing with it healthy growth in employment. It is stated on page 3 of the report:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.8The Senate Economics Committee found during the course of its inquiry into the tax treatment of small business that although the implementations of some of the recommendations of the Beddall Committee report had been of considerable benefit to the small business community, some of the taxation problems encountered by small business remained essentially unchanged.
Also:
This report attempts to address these concerns.
And I support the report in so doing.

PARA.TAB: The main matter that I want to raise—and other senators may wish to raise other elements of it—is the cost of compliance. I know many people complain about the individual taxes themselves—and, heaven knows, there are enough of them. Here are just a few of those affecting small businesses: provisional tax, wholesale sales tax, pay as you earn tax, fringe benefit tax, prescribed payments system, capital gains tax, company tax, and superannuation guarantee. They are just the federal taxes, quite apart from all the state taxes that then hit small business.

We have a situation where all small businesses in Australia must comply with at least one, and frequently several, of these taxes, the report says. As the following chapters in this report illustrate, none of these taxes in themselves are simple; and when three or four different taxes apply to the one business, compliance may become a considerable burden on the operation of that business.

This question of compliance seems to me to be central: the cost of compliance. I am strongly of the view that, when we have a decent government in this country, that government will have an inquiry into this whole question of the cost of compliance with governmental taxes, governmental regulations, and so on. We are getting to a situation now where the costs of compliance are strangling the small business end of Australian enterprise—and that, as we have noted, is the end where we can hope for and look for the greatest economic growth and the greatest job growth. We have to act to get rid of some of these absurd costs of compliance.

In recent years we have seen the taxation act—under this government, which promised to simplify it—increase from 1,130 pages to 3,370 pages. We have also seen a whole range of activities where the costs of management on the government side may well have been kept small, but the costs of compliance by business have massively increased.

In fact, a recent study undertaken by a reputable accounting organisation showed that, for the average small business, the cost of compliance with one tax alone, sales tax—the Keating sales tax, the KST: the consumption tax you have when you have a Prime Minister who pretends he does not support consumption taxes—is something like 25 per cent of the total tax collected. That is the impact it has on the average small business, according to this very reputable study.

As this report notes, a number of people making submissions to the inquiry were unhappy with the requirement that sales tax payers act as unpaid tax collectors. The Beddall committee, in fact, recommended that some kind of offsetting benefit be provided to small business because they do not have the economies of scale involved in big businesses; in other words, they have a far higher cost of compliance than big businesses. So the way the rules work discriminates against small business in Australia, which is the very area where, if there is to be any discrimination, there should be favourable discrimination. They are the employers who are, in fact, providing the increased employment.

One of the particular problems is that so many small businesses are involved in collecting sales tax when there are multiple different sales tax rates applicable to the products provided. There can be disagreements about the appropriate rate of sales tax. There are exemption certificates if you provide goods to some particular people. It is a massively expensive regimen that small businesses are put through.

The Senate Economics References Committee has gone part of the way to meeting my request that there be a total overall review of the whole question of the costs of compliance to business, big and small. This committee quite properly recommends:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Government conduct a comprehensive review of the sales tax exemptions and classifications system with a view to:
(i) removing the ambiguities and complexities within and between the sales tax classification schedules; and

(ii) establishing a simple, effective process whereby the classification of new products can be quickly and simply achieved, thereby lessening reliance on the general rate of sales tax as a default rate.

I object to the way that the Taxation Office, in a sense, blackmails small businesses—it might be a hard word to use—which may well have inadvertently charged the wrong tax rate. They end up being prosecuted and being talked into arriving at settlements which they may well have not had to pay had they been able to afford the legal actions to protect their interests against the commissioner.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned that there has been an unfortunate situation in the area of tax and in the costs of compliance. I hope that this report will direct attention to the great needs of small business. I believe such attention would be in Australia's overall best interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Senate's attention to the conclusions by the Senate Economics References Committee into the tax treatment of small business because the summation is that small business faces a plethora of tax regulations. The combination of many taxes that business has to comply with and the sheer complexity of each tax frequently results in an overbearing burden of responsibility on small business, as my colleague Senator Baume has so eloquently pointed out.

PARA.TAB: This quest for money, the attempt to close loopholes, and the attempt to get money from limited sources creates complexity that is really beyond the ken of most small business people. If large businesses are getting into trouble with tax audits, I fear for small businesses because they do not have the expertise or the money to buy the skills that are necessary nowadays to understand tax law.

An enormous amount of time is required by small businesses just to meet their obligations and the costs associated with them. I refer to the costs associated with the employment of specialists and the costs of the entrepreneur having to take additional time out from selling and doing the things that he knows best just to meet the tax obligations of this federal government. There is also the cost of miscalculation of tax obligations in terms of the nature of the penalties—the time interest penalties and the culpability penalties that apply.

I must draw the Senate's attention to what I believe is a fairly unrealistic crackdown. When a lot of small businesses run into trouble and get behind with their debts, they suddenly find themselves, having almost paid off their debts, at a very late time being put into the court and their businesses wrecked. Currently a business in Tasmania is facing that very situation. Having struggled for perhaps 18 months to meet their tax obligations, they get within sight of paying it off and they suddenly find they are put before the courts and all they owe—perhaps 90 per cent of it—is tied up with penalties. In other words, the Taxation Office just got too demanding and was prepared to throw people out of work and destroy people's livelihoods.

I draw attention to last year's report from the Ombudsman, in which she said that too often marriages are ruined and businesses are destroyed by pre-emptive action by the Taxation Office. We know that the courts will always support the Taxation Office in the collection of revenue, but they fail to take into account the human misery that is caused as a result of too much pre-emptive action.

I also want to use this opportunity to draw attention to a number of the recommendations that perhaps have not been addressed in the public arena as much as they should, and I refer back to the concept of the carry back of losses and the carry forward of profits. Under the Australian tax regime, businesses are allowed to carry forward losses to a subsequent year of income where that loss may be offset against the profit and thereby the taxable income produced in the subsequent year. But, in the meantime, businesses may have suffered.

I draw attention to a situation where a small business might be very dependent on one major customer. In one year, you bring to account all the revenue, which could be quite substantial, but if that business customer fails to pay the debt—the bad debt can amount to some hundreds of thousands of dollars—and if the business then gets into difficulties there is no carry back of that debt. In effect, in the previous year, as a result of the bringing of income into account on an accrual basis, tax is paid on the income. There is no cash flow because the debt has gone bad. At that stage of the business there is not sufficient income to allow the bad debt to be offset when it is actually bad.

There is a question about the time which is allowed before a debt is really bad, but it is the small businesses that tend to suffer most because of their lack of access to other forms of capital. So there is a dislocation to revenue in a depressed period, and there is a lack of finality in assessment.
The recommendation from the committee is that the government should investigate the efficacy of limited carry back of losses for a limited period. Mr Shann Turnbull submitted to the committee:

SPEECH.PARA: The carry forward of profits is of special value to small businesses who do not have access to capital markets to make up for loss of liquidity when losses are incurred. In addition, banks are unlikely to provide carry-on cash to small business when losses are incurred and liquidity is most desperately required.
I would urge the government to look at that particular recommendation.

PARA.TAB: Under the capital gains regime, you have to keep your records indefinitely for capital gains transactions. The committee recognised that a proposal to phase out capital gains tax on assets which are held for the very long term—we are talking about 25 to 30 years—needs to be examined. Documents nowadays rarely exist for that sort of time, and there are going to be difficulties in vouching for them.

There are also difficulties with the prescribed payments system when payment is not received until the year of income following completion of work and rendering of an account; for example, in the period June to July. The income is assessable on those earnings in the earlier year even though the prescribed payments tax is not deducted until the later year, because it is withheld at the time of payment. Therefore, the person cannot get a credit for that tax.

The result is that, when the return is lodged, the taxpayer is taxed as if the prescribed payments tax had not been deducted, notwithstanding that he or she will get a credit in the following year. So a suggested solution was to allow the credit in a year in which the income is assessable, despite the fact that the tax will not be remitted until the following financial year. Here we virtually have a situation where, while you bring your revenue into account on an accrual basis, you are not allowed your deduction on an accrual basis; it is on a cash payment system. That works very much to the detriment of small business.

The other matter the committee was concerned about was with wine growers, particularly those wine growers who are in a small business and are provisional taxpayers. One of the difficulties in that industry is that the receipts are often received in three instalments before the end of the year and following through after the end of the financial year—in April, June and September. Small growers whose lump sum provisional tax of $8,000 or less is due by 31 March will not have received any payments for income which has been accrued and assessed, which will force payment through debt financing. We recommend that the wine growing industry look at taking advantage of the new PAYG system of payments because, without that, it will have some difficulties.

The government should also look at the valuation of stock in the wine industry because when some of the better wines—the higher valued wines that Australia is particularly good at producing, particularly my own state of Tasmania—are put in stock there is a tax component which must be financed. This works very much to the detriment of the speciality wineries and those wineries that produce higher valued products.

I believe this is a first-class report. I recommend that those people who are listening to this particular debate speak to their local politician and get a copy of this report on the tax treatment of small business, because it outlines the problems that small businesses face, particularly in areas of liquidity. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just noticed the report entitled A question of balance: the tax treatment of small business in today's list of documents and would like to put down a very short comment on the matter. The Senate Economics References Committee was chaired by Senator Ferguson, who ought to be commended on this particular report; as he was commended on it yesterday at the National Press Club by the President of COSBOA, the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Both sides of the house would welcome this report on the effects of tax on small business, because we all recognise the overwhelming importance of small business to our economy. The fact is that, together, the some 800,000 small businesses—depending on exactly how you define it but, certainly, it is greater than 800,000; some would put it around the 900,000 mark—are the major employers of our economy. If you put together all the institutions and major businesses, such as BHP, that are so keen on stripping employees, the small business sector has actually outstripped them in the employment area.

With the government's boast about the creation of two million or so jobs over the last so many years of employing, the majority of employees have gone to the small business sector. A small business is defined as having around seven employees; seven is about the average that a small business would employ but, of course, we know they can vary from one or two people right through to about 50.

It has been described as the engine room of employment. That really was the focus of Rob Bastian's speech at the National Press Club yesterday: that the government really has to refocus on small business and have a bottom-up approach in its budget and in its economic strategy so that we can get small businesses to employ that one extra person in their business and basically wipe off the unemployment problem we have in this country, particularly in the area of youth unemployment.

Historically, small business has been the grounding of employment for youth. That is where they have got their first job; that is where they have got their confidence in employment. They have often gone on to an institution such as BHP, AMP or one of those big institutions. They have got their first job and their confidence in the workplace by beginning in a small business, such as a small retailer or a milk bar. In the areas of tax and industrial relations, which I do not have time to go into but which have been well canvassed in this house, small business really needs a refocus from this government, with a bottom-up approach.
