TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly tonight about a particular problem facing Australia's tourist industry. The issue relates to the tax regime applied to bareboat charter operations. Bareboat charters are a fast expanding area of tourism in North Queensland in which people charter a boat, generally a sailing boat, without a crew. This particular tourist activity is becoming increasingly popular.

PARA.TAB: Sales tax is imposed on some tourism vessels, including game fishing boats, sightseeing boats operating non-scheduled services and bareboat charter vessels. As the situation now stands bareboat operators are slugged with sales tax, discouraging domestic production of these vessels and discouraging the growth of this particular area of tourism. The actual level of sales tax, I think, is now 21 per cent. It was 20 per cent. If you are talking about a $250,000 vessel, that is a lot of money which is paid in sales tax—about $60,000.

In contrast, vessels which undertake scheduled sightseeing services and those used for commercial fishing are eligible for sales tax exemption. That is the same for those of us involved in agriculture who buy many of our implements and vehicles sales tax exempt, as do companies involved in mining. It seems a little unfair that the tourism industry has developed at a later stage. If there had been this sort of developing tourism industry when mining or agriculture were being developed, then I am sure the sales tax exemption that applies to those two industries would have been applied to the tourist industry as well.

In March of this year the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration released the report called Taxing relaxing, which investigated this aberration. The anomaly was succinctly put by a representative of the Whitsunday Bareboat Operators Association. He had bought the Solo, a 70-foot vessel which slept 13 passengers and departed at regular intervals each Sunday. It was sales tax exempt. He also had a 40-foot bareboat sailing vessel, the Lady Catherine, which slept eight passengers and departed at noon on any day he was able to hire it. That vessel was subject to sales tax.

When it came to the issue of taxation the House of Representatives committee took evidence from a wide range of people, especially in relation to tourist buses, vehicles and vessels that carried fewer than 12 passengers and did not have scheduled departure times and dates. Sensibly, the committee recommended that a sales tax exemption be granted for tourism buses and four-wheel drive vehicles of 12 seats and under. However, bareboat operators were not as lucky.

Among the other recommendations made by the committee were that all vehicles which are used exclusively for earning assessable income be fully depreciable; that access to the diesel fuel rebate scheme be extended where the fuel is used in electricity generators which provide an essential service to areas not linked to the national electricity grid; that the export market development scheme be fully implemented in that consideration be given to the provision of equal access to the scheme for single service providers in the tourist industry at a rate of 50c in the dollar; and that the Council of Australian Governments consider means by which the payroll tax system can be reviewed in connection with the tourist industry.

Coalition members of this committee had to dissent from the Labor members, and recommended that the sales tax exemptions be available to genuine bareboat operators for the purchase of vessels and parts for business use with unscheduled departure and arrival times. Unfortunately, the government has failed to act on this advice. This inaction was borne out when the committee visited a boat building factory which had closed largely as a result of the inability of the bareboat industry to implement their fleet replacement program and fleet growth programs.

Some people have taken the view that an exemption from sales tax for bareboats without a compensatory tax on outputs of these businesses would effectively create a new anomaly within the taxation regime. The coalition members believe that, to a substantial extent, this already applied in industries that are wholesale sales tax exempt and the present system is anomalous to bareboat operators. Put simply, sales tax is not an appropriate tax to levy on the tourism industry. Evidence before the committee well and truly proved that.

Tourism is one of Australia's most successful growth industries, generating revenue of more than $11 billion in foreign earnings last year. This represents a fivefold increase in 10 years from $2.4 billion earned in 1983-84. More than half a million Australians, or six per cent of the work force, are employed in the tourist industry, which itself generates jobs in small business.

For these reasons, we must nurture this industry. One way of doing this is for the government to immediately consider these sales tax breaks that would be very beneficial to an industry that is important to North Queensland and has an enormous potential.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last spoke in this place, on Thursday, 29 June 1995, I was speaking about some good news and tonight I am repeating that—it is again good news. Tonight, as we debate matters of public interest here in the Senate of the parliament of Australia, some 71 illegal entrants to this country in November, December and January just gone by are back in their homes in different parts of southern China. They left Port Hedland—that wonderful, almost tropical town in the north-west of my state of Western Australia—in the early hours of this morning and are now back in their homes, probably reunited with their families, whom they have missed.

PARA.TAB: Today marked the fifth return of boat people to China, people who arrived in that wave that caused great fear in the Australian community through November, December and January of this year. It brings to a total of some 325 people who have now been repatriated to their homes.

I have a particular interest in this issue, as I think most senators would appreciate and recognise. The interest is so much that last month, in July, I accompanied a group of some 81 boat people who were being repatriated to their homes. I went on the aircraft that took them into Nanning in southern China. I watched their embarkation onto coaches in Port Hedland from the detention centre. I watched their embarkation onto the aircraft at Port Hedland. I watched their disembarkation at Nanning in southern China and I watched some of them being loaded into coaches to be taken to their homes. Most on that plane last month, in July, were taken back to the town of Beihai and the surrounding areas, where most of the people on that plane came from. It was a very interesting experience to go back to China.

As the Senate may or may not be aware—some senators do know this—in April this year I accompanied the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to China on a trip that involved some very heavy negotiations with the Chinese authorities about the repatriation of these people and implementing the memorandum of understanding that was negotiated between the governments of the People's Republic of China and Australia in January this year. I am very pleased that matters contained in that memorandum of understanding are being fulfilled. Indeed, we saw proof of that today with the latest plane load of people being returned to their homes.

I have sought permission from the opposition to table two editions of the newsletter which I publish on this matter. The newsletter is called The boat people: the saga continues. These are the July and August editions of this year. They are already in the public domain. The newsletter does not pull any punches, I might add. I have shown it to representatives of the opposition and seek their permission to table both of the documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have incorporated in the newsletters some photographs that I took on a trip to Nanning last month. I have outlined some of my experiences on that trip. There were 81 people on the plane, which is quite distinct from the 45 that were on the plane I spoke about when I last addressed the Senate about this issue on 29 June. There were only 45 on that plane in June because a number of people had gone to the rooftops at Port Hedland to demonstrate. In some cases they were not allowed to get their boats back.

PARA.TAB: There were a number of reasons why they sought to demonstrate. It was a demonstration which unfortunately got nastier as it progressed. It was nasty enough on Thursday, 29 June but I think that on the weekend at the end of June, after negotiations had taken place and some of the people had left the rooftops, a number of additional people got onto the roof. Unfortunately, they chose to take some of the children with them.

I have great concerns about this, as the Senate would know. So too would the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, of which my colleague Senator Short is the deputy chair. This committee has done a major inquiry into Australia's detention of illegal entrants. We have grave concerns about the detention of children. We certainly have grave concerns about how those children were used at the end of June and early in July at Port Hedland during those demonstrations.

It has been put to me personally that not only were the children used as shields to stop the authorities using, for example, water hoses or water cannons on them to get them down from the roof. It is also thought the children may have been used as weapons. Indeed some of the boat people had weapons on the roof with them. I saw the weapons myself. I saw the rocks; I saw the sticks; I saw the pieces of metal. Fortunately, by the time I got to Port Hedland the demonstration had culminated and the people demonstrating had come down from the roof. Because of the actions of those people at that time, they are no longer able to get on the rooftop of those buildings. Unfortunately, there is increased usage of wire at Port Hedland.

Before I was diverted I was drawing attention to some photographs that I took while I was on a trip in China last month. I draw people's attention to them. People may care to get from the Table Office additional copies of those photocopied newsletters. Unfortunately, I did not bring additional copies with me and, because I have been so busy this week, I did not have time to copy them.

Three photographs contained on page 5 of the July edition identify me with some of the people who have been repatriated and returned to their homeland in China. There is a photograph of me with a young couple as we dined in the restaurant that these people owned. It was dining that would measure anything that one could get in Chinatown in Sydney or in Chinatown in any other capital city of this country. The people that I am photographed with are the owners of this restaurant who put on the feed for us. They were so pleased after they had received so many free feeds from the Australian authority whilst they were here. It cost some $A14,000 for him and his girlfriend to come on what he described as an adventure to Australia. He is now successfully repatriated back in his home and his restaurant is doing very nicely.

The second photograph is of me in a jewellery shop paying for a necklace that I purchased from another of the returnees, a person with magnificent skills to fashion a silver necklace such as this one. This necklace was actually given to my wife. So, Jackie, it is yours if you are looking in; I will not hang on to it. It shows you the skills of some of the people who have come to Australia, people who are held up by some as running in fear of persecution. There was certainly no persecution evident in the person who made this necklace for me, nor was there in his girlfriend who was in the same shop in the Beihai region.

The third photograph—which is not the best nor the most enlightening photograph of me—is of another young woman that I met in the fish processing factory. The reason I included this particular photograph is that she said she would love to return to Australia. Given the chance, she would probably come back illegally. The reason I mention that and put some emphasis on it is to show that, whilst I was using an interpreter from Australia—an Australian interpreter who could understand an Irish version of the Australian version of English and Chinese—the individual was not scared to speak up and say that, given the opportunity, she would return illegally to this country. It was a great experience for me to see these people who had been repatriated to prove, at least for these people—and I believe for everybody else who has been repatriated—that no persecution has taken place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to speak about the appalling treatment being meted out by this government to the science and research effort in this country—specifically that aspect of science dealing with the basic sciences, the fundamental sciences and those sciences which, paradoxically, are fundamental to the applied science, which this government seems to think is the only science that should be supported.

PARA.TAB: On many previous occasions I have pointed to the way in which the present Labor government has run down the basic science enterprise in this country, how it has seen science merely as the handmaiden of industry and the economy and how it sees no intrinsic value whatsoever in science for the sake of its cultural and educational enrichment. It is my belief that Senator Cook has no understanding of science whatsoever and is so bemused by his superficial economical rationalist model of society that he is quite incapable of understanding the real scientific effort or what it is that drives science and drives scientists.

In the 1940s the CSIRO began the development of several genetically pure strains of chickens. These genetic lines have been continued ever since, and there is now a great deal of knowledge in their genetic make-up. This biological resource is extremely valuable. All wild populations of animals and plants have very diverse genetic make-up. For properly controlled work in a number of areas, not just in animal work, one needs a source of animals with a known standard and an invariable genetic composition. Such animals are not only invaluable for work directly on those animals but also as models for a large range of other species. For example, these purebred chickens have been used quite extensively for very valuable work on the immune system, and this work has been carried out by scientists working on the human immune system.

These chickens, which started breeding in the 1940s, have been developed by the CSIRO Division of Animal Production and have been used for research purposes over a period of nearly 50 years. Through the failure of the government to provide adequate funding and to direct the CSIRO to acquire funding from private sources, together with its inability to appreciate the value of such a resource, this 50 years of painstaking work is about to go down the gurgler. The minister has refused funding, CSIRO does not have sufficient funds to maintain the genetic stock and both have said that private sources have to maintain this valuable stock if it is to be maintained at all.

Both yesterday and today the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) made great play of the fact that 20 eminent scientists had reported on the French nuclear tests. Therefore, he was taking note of what they had said. A much greater number of eminent scientists have appealed to the minister for science for the retention of this genetic stock, but the minister has shut his ears.

Let me read from this list. It includes: the Australian Genetic Society; the Australian branch of the World's Poultry Science Association; the Australasian Association of Animal Breeding and Genetics; the Australian Veterinary Poultry Association; Professor Kevin Lafferty, director of the John Curtin School of Medical Research at the Australian National University; Associate Professor Richard Frankham, Macquarie University; Dr Trevor Baghurst, CSIRO Division of Animal Health, Parkville, Victoria; Dr Max Whitten, formerly chief of the CSIRO Division of Entomology, Canberra; Dr Stephen Prowse, CSIRO Division of Animal Health, Parkville; Associate Professor Frank Nicholas, Department of Animal Sciences, University of Sydney; Dr Tony Dellaporta, Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong; Professor Stewart Barker, Department of Animal Science, University of New England; Dr Harvey Wesbury, Australian Animal Health Laboratory, Geelong; Dr Jim Peacock, chief, CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, Canberra; Dr Bob Pemm, Veterinary School, University of Queensland, St Lucia, Queensland; Dr Phil Glass, Parafield Poultry Research Centre, South Australia; Professor John James, School of Wool and Pastoral Sciences, University of New South Wales; Dr Nick Tierney, Animal Research Institute, Yeerongpilly, Queensland—I do not know whether he is a relation to Senator Tierney, who I understand will follow me—Professor John Mattock, Centre for Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, University of Queensland; Dr Peter Young, Animal Research Institute, Yeerongpilly, Queensland; Dr John Dingle, Intensive Livestock Department, University of Queensland; Dr Roger Chubb, Faculty of Rural Science, and so it goes on. I could read 50 names from that list of eminent, well-qualified scientists who are supporting the retention of this very important facility.
In a letter to Dr Bruce Sheldon, who has been working frantically to maintain this genetic stock, the minister wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: I have an obligation to administer my portfolio in such a way as to give optimum effect to the government's policies . . . I am advised that the continuation of support for the research in question has been considered without success by the CSIRO and the private sector. In other words, I have put a straitjacket on the CSIRO funding and the minister then blames the CSIRO for not continuing the funding of this basic research and, by implication, also blames the private sector for not picking up the tab. But much of the research that may have been based on this material does not relate to easily applicable results. Much of it is likely to be of a more basic nature which may or may not have extremely valuable but unpredictable results many years down the track.
There is also a letter from the division pointing out that the division does not have the funds to maintain the stock. The corporate secretary writes:

Although these poultry represent a great asset, the Division finds that it is not in a position to sustain this work and the birds in question. Thus the Division thought the stock was valuable, unlike Senator Cook.

Dr Sheldon tried to get the executive director, Dr John Stocker, to take the matter to the board, but he refused to do so. Perhaps the letter from Dr Stocker to Dr Sheldon is the most damning of all. It may help to explain why the government appointed Dr Stocker in the first place. Dr Stocker wrote:

I can well understand your frustration and disappointment at this situation, particularly after such a distinguished and energetic career in scientific research, largely based on these lines of poultry. However, given the lack of industry support for continuation of the lines I can see no option for CSIRO other than to listen to the marketplace. I cannot offer you any ray of hope and therefore cannot see any benefit in raising this issue with the CSIRO board.
Senator Cook in another letter to Dr Sheldon emphasises the same bald economic imperative that he and the government think should drive the research effort in Australia. He says:

It is expected that research in CSIRO will be driven significantly by the needs of industry and other users with long term needs having an important part to play in decisions . . . Maintenance of the flock without industry support, as you suggest, is not consistent with CSIROs mission to allocate funds to research which is driven by the needs of its partners.

In other words, goodbye basic research; the government is not prepared to fund you. If private industry, which by its very nature is not interested in this type of research because of its long-term nature, does not fund you, bad luck, you won't get funding.

PARA.TAB: There we have it. The basic research effort of this country is being rapidly strangled by government decree. That research which industry wants will get funding; that which it cannot see an economic profit from or use for will cease. In this way, the very basis of our applied research will dry up in a few short years. Unless there is a change of direction, even the applied research will wither away, for applied research depends fundamentally on that basic and strategic research without which the applied research simply has nothing on which to build.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak about a meeting that occurred yesterday with small business people in this city. I had a delegation from the Hunter come to see me about their concerns with government policy in relation to the small business area. At lunchtime at the National Press Club, the head of COSBOA, the Council of Small Business Organisations in Australia, Mr Bastian, addressed over 300 people and the national press on their concerns.

PARA.TAB: What was central to the problems facing small business in this country, as outlined yesterday, was that what we have been faced with in the last 13 years under this Labor government has been a growing set of policies that were distinctly anti-small business. Year after year, this government adds further and further burdens to small business. The latest, of course, is the unfair dismissal provisions. I will come back to that in more detail later. We also saw, in the middle of this year, wholesale sales taxes go up yet again. The government were a little bit sneaky about this; they announced that in last year's budget for two years running, so they could automatically add it without announcing it.

We have seen increases in the FBT rate. We currently face upward pressure on interest rates. In this last budget the government increased company sales tax from 33c to 36c. In case people think that is hitting only big businesses, let me say that it is also hitting 300,000 of the 860,000 small businesses in Australia.

The combination of these recent measures with all the other measures this government has added over the last 13 years creates a very hostile business climate, where it is extremely difficult for businesses to grow and for new businesses to establish. The five minutes of economic sunshine that John Howard alluded to, and so successfully encapsulated in that comment, is very much true for the small businesses of Australia, particularly in rural and regional Australia.

As a matter of fact, many parts of Australia are still back in that 1990-93 recession. Many areas have come out of it but many small businesses are still there. So, it is with some hide that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says, `This is as good as it gets.' If this is as good as it gets for many small businesses in this country, they will go to the wall very soon and Australia will lose a golden opportunity for further economic expansion. It will be a tragedy for the people affected, not only in their livelihood but, in many cases, in the loss of all their assets.

In the Hunter, this is happening consistently. One small business a day is closing down in the Hunter. We invited Minister Schacht to come up and speak to us last May. He got a very hostile reception because of the small business people's reaction to the policies of his government over the last 13 years. But he did promise to do some things. That was back in May; it is now nearly September. About six months have gone by. Remember that one business is closing down every day. You can do the maths as to how many businesses have been lost over that time. We are still waiting, in this time of economic crisis for many small businesses, for the minister to act.

He did promise to try to do something about those areas which he can do something about. He keeps trying to fob this off as a local government or state government problem. But under the Trade Practices Act he can certainly do something about the abuse of market power and unconscionable conduct by groups like chain stores, particularly with regard to their use of predatory pricing. A lot of big chains are using these sorts of practices which the minister refuses to act against. They are increasingly gaining market dominance. Seventy-seven per cent of economic power is now in the hands of these very large chains, much to the disadvantage of many small businesses.

I draw to the Senate's attention an example of this sort of behaviour by chains. The examples are from the Hunter Valley, from the towns of Port Stephens and Singleton. I have here virtually identical ads showing the price of broccoli. In one town it is being sold for 98c a kilo, which one would assume is its proper price, and in the other one it is being sold for 49c. That is almost half the price. What happens to the fruit and vegetable shop opposite when the chain nearby charges half price and consistently charges low prices? When they have driven these people out of business, they put their prices back up again. That is what is called unconscionable conduct and that is what this minister has some power to do something about. But he refuses to act.

On top of that, this government, not content with not acting within its power to help to improve the lot of small business, introduces additional legislation to make it more difficult. I refer particularly to the unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act. This is not only a tragedy for small business, because they cannot operate properly, but also it is a tragedy for employment because many small business people say, `If I've got to act under that sort of tough law, how can I survive, how can I put people on?' So they do not put people on, and that is an additional tragedy for unemployment.

One of the small business people who visited us yesterday told us the story of how he wanted to dismiss an employee under this provision. The employee worked in his fruit and vegetable shop. He noticed that she kept taking out boxes which had lettuce leaves sitting on top. He got a little suspicious so he checked what was under these lettuce leaves. He found chocolates, bottles of other products being sold in the shop and some of the more expensive fruits. She was taking these home.

He had observed her for a few days and then he uncovered this. What would normally happen? If it was 200 years ago that employee would get seven years in Van Diemen's Land for such action. But today the employer is fearful of undertaking any action against an employee because the employer can end up in court. The person whom he is charging, his former employee, can end up paying out very little, if anything. Not only does the employer lose a lot of money in this action; he also loses a lot of time.

So we have a government that is making it very difficult for small business in not applying the laws that exist and also in introducing new laws that make it even more difficult for business. Probably that is the reason why we did not see anything of Minister Schacht yesterday at the National Press Club. We had 300 small business people, not just business people but representatives of their organisations. It was a golden opportunity for the minister to present the great record of his government and what he was doing for these people. But where was Minister Schacht? He certainly was not down there. He did not even show his head. The reason he did not show his head was the appalling record of his party and his administration and the way in which they have made it incredibly difficult for small business.

The people of Australia should realise what this government is doing to small business and to unemployment in this country. They should take this very much into consideration when we get to the ballot box. It is just one more reason why this government should be thrown out when we get to the election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some brief comments in relation to a document which has been circulated in recent times entitled `Community attitudes to violence against women, an executive summary produced by the Office of the Status of Women'. Few people within the community would do anything other than condemn domestic violence and violence towards women. Having been a legal practitioner prior to my entry into this place and having had experience of acting for both victims and perpetrators of domestic violence, I have an ongoing interest in this matter. It really is a very unfortunate social phenomena and one which is causing a lot of dislocation within the community.

PARA.TAB: It is good to see that this report indicates that the tolerance or acceptance of domestic violence is virtually non-existent and that attitudes to it are hardening within the community. The matter that I wish to address is not so much the bandaid section, although I will do so briefly, on how to deal with it. I want to deal with the causes. It is interesting on page 11 of this report to read about measures to reduce violence against women. This is what the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: When asked about ways to reduce violence against women, the knee-jerk response is to change the laws and introduce tougher penalties. After consideration, however, community education and counselling for those committing violence are given a higher priority than legal measures as ways to reduce violence against women.

That is a very cogent summary and indicates the stance we as an opposition took to another form of social evil and how to overcome it, and that is in relation to our attitude to the Racial Hatred Bill, which was discussed earlier today. The way to overcome these sorts of social problems is community education and counselling, rather than having a simplistic knee-jerk reaction of trying to toughen the laws.

PARA.TAB: But that is dealing with the measures that need to be employed to overcome the problem. What gives rise to these problems? On page 8 of the report we are told that a wide array of factors contributes to domestic violence. When people are asked, `What do you think brings about domestic violence?' the top rated issue was financial pressure. Financial pressure on the family is the sort of pressure that is brought to bear on families because of taxation regimes by the federal government and the lack of support this government has shown to families. If we want to deal with the question of domestic violence we can do so by supporting the family unit. We on this side of the House, the Liberal-

SPEECH.PARA: National Party coalition, are unashamedly supportive of the family unit and will continue to be supportive of it. One of the spin-offs of that will be a reduction in domestic violence. Also, there is the concern that there are problems with communication. We as an opposition would support extra funds to allow communication to continue within family units on a proper basis.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice,

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the attitude of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) to `product placement'.
(2) Is the issue of product placement covered in the ABC's editorial policies; if so, please specify.

(3) Does the ABC's attitude to product placement in relation to programs purchased from other broadcasters or producers vary in any way from its attitude to product placement in relation to programs produced in-house; if so, please specify.
(4) When the ABC receives a program in which there is evidence that product placement has occurred, what checks are undertaken.

(5) Is the ABC aware of any drama programs which it has televised in the last eighteen months in which the practice of product placement may have occurred; if so, please specify the programs, the product placement that may have occurred, and the checks that were undertaken in each case.
(6) Does the ABC consider that any, and if so, which types of product placement would represent a breach of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has advised that:
(1) Section 15.2.1 of ABC Editorial Policies states that "the presentation of identifiable or clearly labelled brand products or services should be avoided".
(2) As stated in part (1) above.

(3) In the case of purchased programs, the ABC is involved after the production is completed and therefore can have no control of production details. However, the system of program purchase involves safeguards against any unacceptable standards. All programs are first viewed by experienced program assessors who filter product before it goes to relevant program departments and schedulers. Any program in which there is blatant and obviously deliberate promotion of product or which features a product in a way that is not essential to the theme or storyline is rejected. It is recognised that product placement has become an integral part of under-financed film industries so that a character, for instance drinking a certain brand of whisky may be doing so as part of the character delineation or as a contra to an investor. The ABC has no control of such production elements but does not hesitate to reject the program if it looks like product placement.

(4) In relation to purchased programs it is not possible for the ABC to check on any private arrangements that may have been made by overseas or local independent producers and business organisations at the time a production was being set up. Such detail is not revealed in any of the contract material exchanged between vendor and purchaser. Judgement as to acceptability is made on the program's contents. In relation to co-productions, ABC Editorial Policies provide that the Directors of Radio and Television must reject any proposal where the Director is not satisfied that the ABC's independence and integrity are fully protected.

(5) The ABC is not aware of any drama televised in the last eighteen months in which the practice of product placement has occurred. This applies to in-house productions, co-productions and purchased product.

(6) The ABC considers that any kind of deliberate product placement of which the Corporation was aware at the time of production or purchase would constitute a breach of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act.
However, in drama or comedy productions with a contemporary setting, the everyday lives of the characters will lead to their participating in a world where items are branded.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 29 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: Has the Government estimated the total cost of fraud against the Commonwealth and Commonwealth agencies: if so; (b) what areas of fraud are there; and (c) what is the cost of fraud in each of these areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The issue of fraud against the Commonwealth is one that this Government takes very seriously and has addressed in considerable detail. As you will recall, on 8 December 1994, I tabled in Parliament the Government's response to two important reports on fraud. These were a report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance, and Public Administration entitled Focusing on Fraud (the Elliott Committee), and Chapter 9 of the Review of Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements. The review, undertaken at my direction, was a comprehensive examination of the then current law enforcement arrangements in place within the Attorney-General's Portfolio.

The Government's response to these two reviews is one of the most comprehensive and significant policy initiatives taken in the area of fraud control, both nationally and internationally. That initiative is outlined in the Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth incorporating an Interim Ministerial Direction on Fraud Control which I tabled in December 1994 as part of the Government response. For the first time, the Commonwealth has a fully comprehensive fraud control policy which sets the framework for best practice standards in fraud prevention, fraud reporting, fraud case handling, and training of officers involved in fraud control activities.

The Elliott Committee report and the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Review both highlighted the lack of information available to the Government on the extent and nature of fraud against the Commonwealth. All Commonwealth agencies have had in place fraud control measures as a result of the Government's 1987 decision on fraud control, but the total cost of public sector fraud is unknown. Prior to the introduction of the new Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth no formal process existed to provide whole of Government data on the actual cost of fraud against the Commonwealth.

In order to rectify this gap in information, the Government, in its Fraud Control Policy of the Commonwealth, introduced a series of requirements that will assist in identifying the scope, nature and extent of fraud against the public purse. The Government:

introduced comprehensive fraud reporting requirements for all Commonwealth agencies that come within the scope of the proposed Financial Management and Accountability Act, and entities within the scope of the proposed Commonwealth Authorities and Companies Act which are budget funded for their operating costs; and

established the Commonwealth Fraud Information Database (CFID), administered by the Australian Federal Police, to collate the fraud information reported by agencies. The CFID will provide information and intelligence to support agency and AFP investigations, and be a source of statistical reporting to Government.

In addition to the obligation to report fraud information to the CFID, there is a requirement on agencies to report information on general losses, overpayments and recovery of money which is not directly attributable to fraud to the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board.

The AFP now has in place computer hardware and software to operate CFID, and agencies have been requested to report to the CFID cases of fraud detected after 1 July 1995. It will be some time before the CFID contains sufficient information to permit valid conclusions to be drawn about the cost, nature, and extent of fraud against the Commonwealth. The reporting arrangements are now in place to allow this to be done.

The Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board is also required to report annually to Government through me on progress on fraud control within the Commonwealth. The first Board report will be provided before the end of this calendar year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 30 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the biodiversity series written by the department, entitled Native Vegetation Clearance, Habitat Loss and Biodiversity Decline, which lists the total area of land cleared of native vegetation, both nationally, and on a State-by-State basis, in the period from 1983 to 1993.
(1) How are these figures ascertained.
(2) Do the figures represent the amount of actual land cleared, or do they represent the area for which clearing licences have been granted.
(3) How many hectares of land have been planted with native vegetation in this, period.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Indicative rates expressed in the report were drawn from the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory. They were derived mostly from two sources:
primary time series data based on the interpretation of satellite imagery
secondary time series data based on native vegetation clearance permits granted under State planning or native vegetation management legislation.

Indicative estimates of native vegetation clearance were calculated for 1988 and 1990 and extrapolated or projected to indicate the extent of land cleared between 1983 and 1993. This allowed an Indicative estimate of annual clearance rate for the period of some 500 000 ha to be calculated.
The methodological approaches used to calculate these figures are set out in the report.

(2) Where possible interpretation of satellite imagery and aerial photography was used to determine actual native vegetation change over time and where this was not possible clearance permits were used to give an indication of changes to native vegetation over time.

(3) No Australia wide figures for the period 1983-93 are currently available. For the period 1983 to 1988 no figures are available but the Commonwealth did provide funds towards the National Tree Program for revegetation works. For the period 1989 to 1993 an average of 30 000 ha were established per annum by activities funded under the One Billion Trees Program. The annual revegetation figure could be expected to be significantly higher since there are a number of other Commonwealth and State funded tree establishment programs in operation. These include programs under the Murray-Darling Basin Commission's Natural Resource Management Strategy, and the Land and Water Program administered by the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Defence: Military Bases in New South Wales

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Government intend to reduce either personnel levels or funding to any military bases in NSW; if so: (a) what bases are they; (b) what levels of reduction in personnel and funding are being planned for each base; and (c) when are the changes, if any, planned to take place.
(2) Will the Minister give an undertaking that there is no plan to reduce either personnel or funding to the Holsworthy Army Base.

(3) If it is the Government's intention to reduce the size of or remove the Army base from Holsworthy, what is planned for the future use of the land and how does the Government intend to dispose of it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a)-(c) Defence currently plans to rationalise several of its major bases in NSW. The impetus for these initiatives has come from the 1991 Force

ANSWER.PARA: Structure Review and specifically related to the Defence Logistic Redevelopment Project; the Commercial Support Program; the move towards two ocean basing for the Navy; the relocation of the Army's 1st Brigade to Darwin; and the need to ensure the most efficient possible utilisation of the Defence estate. Major bases affected up to the year 2000 are as follows:
Base Closure Date Service Personnel Civilian Personnel

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth has recently negotiated the sale of Newington to the NSW Government. Under the terms of the sale, Defence will have access to the depot until 1997 and access to the ammunitioning wharf until 1999.

Service personnel will be redeployed to other establishments. Reductions in civilian personnel are expected to be achieved through attrition and redeployment within the Sydney area in the first instance. Redundancy payments to civilian personnel may be considered if the reductions are not achieved.

As part of the ongoing Commercial Support Program, the ADF plans to continue to test support functions at its bases where it is practicable and cost-effective so to do. Whilst this process has the potential to result in further reductions of personnel and funding at NSW bases, it is not possible to quantify the extent of these until individual functions have been tested and contracts awarded.

(2) The Government's northern basing initiatives will see the relocation of the 1st Brigade from Holsworthy to Darwin by the year 2000, with approximately 1300 Regular Army personnel being relocated. The effect of this initiative on the Holsworthy area is being partly offset by the progressive re-establishment of the 4th Battalion, the Royal Australian Regiment, with a strength of over 700 personnel. In addition, other Regular and General Reserve elements will move to Holsworthy Barracks, predominantly from Ingleburn and Randwick. Vacant facilities at Holsworthy will be used to accommodate these elements where possible. There will, however, be a requirement for some new facilities to be provided, whilst upgrade of others will be needed. It is intended that, by the year 2002, some $90m will have been spent on new and upgraded facilities at Holsworthy. By that time, Holsworthy will house approximately 3000 Regular and Reserve personnel, which will represent a substantial increase over the 1995 strength at the base. Funding associated with Holsworthy is not expected to be reduced as a result of these changes.

(3) Some minor reduction in land holdings is proposed with the sale of 165 hectares of the Holsworthy firing range to the New South Wales Government to establish an International Shooting Complex to be used as part of the Sydney 2000 Olympics. The ongoing management of the Defence estate at Holsworthy may result in minor parcels of land being made available for disposal. Any such disposal would be carried out under the normal Commonwealth procedures and future uses would need to be compatible with the continuing Defence presence at Holsworthy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the reason for the use of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Falcon 900 special purpose flights between Port Hedland and Canton shown on pages 6, 7 and 8 of the Schedule of Special Purposes Flights for July 1994 to December 1994.
(2) What was the cost of these flights between Port Hedland to Canton, in terms of additional costs, direct costs and full costs for the use of RAAF personnel and assets.
(3) Have any of those costs been met by an agency or authority other than the RAAF.

(4) What was the reason for the use of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) Falcon 900 special purpose flights between Port Hedland and Canton, and Port Hedland and Batam, shown on page 35 of the Schedule of Special Purpose flights for July 1994 to December 1994.
(5) What was the cost of these flights between Port Hedland and Canton, and Port Hedland and Batam, in terms of additional costs, direct costs and full costs for the use of RAAF personnel and assets.
(6) Have any of those costs been met by an agency or authority other than the RAAF.
(7) In respect of questions (1) and (4), what is the reason for approval of the special purpose flights by the Prime Minister.
(8) What alternative transportation options were investigated before approval was given for the special purpose flights.
(9) Has there been any investigation into the use of chartered civil aircraft for the purposes mentioned above; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The flights were to transport detainees from Port Hedland to Guangzhou (Canton), China.

(2) Use of the Falcon 900 aircraft for special purpose flights is cost recovered from the agency requesting the special purpose flight. The cost recovery rate charged to special purpose users is calculated to recover the full costs of operating the aircraft. These costs include aircraft lease and maintenance, fuel, rations, crew allowance, training by the special purpose squadron, ground-handling fees and other day-to-day operating expenses. The cost recovery rate set for the Falcon 900 in 1994-95 was $2,800 per hour. The special purpose flights from Port Hedland to Guangzhou (Canton) referred to above took a total of 42.7 hours flying time and the cost of $119,560 was recovered.
(3) The cost of $119,560 was met by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(4) The flights were used to transport detainees from Port Hedland to Guangzhou (Canton) and from Port Hedland to Batam, Indonesia.

(5) The special purpose flight from Port Hedland to Guangzhou (Canton) referred to above took 17.8 hours flying time and the cost of $49,840 was recovered. The special purpose flight from Port Hedland to Batam, Indonesia referred to above took 11.5 hours flying time and the cost of $32,200 was recovered.
(6) The costs of $49,840 and $32,200 were met by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

(7) Scheduled airline services were considered inappropriate as civil airlines would normally limit the number of detainees to two per flight. The use of RAAF special purpose aircraft on a full cost recovery basis was less expensive than special civil charters.
(8) The decision to request the use of RAAF special purpose aircraft on a cost recovery basis was made by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(9) Nil by the Department of Defence. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs may be able to advise.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 19 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What measures are being taken to upgrade security for the detention of illegal immigrants at the RAAF base Curtin.
(2) What is the total estimated cost of these measures.
(3) What effect will these measures have on the normal operations of RAAF base Curtin.
(4) What impact will these measures have on the ability to activate RAAF base Curtin to meet operational requirements above the normal `bare base' level.
(5) Given that illegal immigrants were only to be detained on a temporary basis, is it not a fact that new security measures will change the status of the accommodation to a more permanent basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) has been given permission to install some additional security measures in facilities leased from the RAAF. Action being taken is the responsibility of DIEA.
(2) Nil to Defence.
(3) None.
(4) None.
(5) Security measures are a matter for DIEA. The agreement between DIEA and RAAF is valid to 31 March 1996.
